Title: Vehicle wireless charging protection method and device, storage medium and wireless charging vehicle
Inventor:
SONG JIANGZHU
JIANG TAO
LI WEI
LIANG SHIFU
Abstract: The invention discloses a vehicle wireless charging protection method and device, a storage medium and a wireless charging vehicle. The method comprises the steps of firstly obtaining wireless charging calibration data, first coil temperature and target impedance of a target vehicle, further calculating to obtain second coil temperature of the target vehicle based on the wireless charging calibration data and the target impedance, and finally performing wireless charging adjustment on the target vehicle according to the first coil temperature and the second coil temperature to obtain a target charging result. The invention solves the technical problems of low detection accuracy and poor reliability of the method for carrying out wireless charging protection by detecting the temperature of the vehicle-mounted coil in the prior art.

Title: Battery health state detection method and system
Inventor: YU YAN
Abstract: The invention discloses a method and a system for detecting the health state of a battery, and relates to the technical field of detection of batteries for vehicles. The method comprises the following steps: step S1, acquiring the accurate frequency of the battery; step S2, applying the alternating current with the accurate frequency to the battery to enable the battery to generate impedance response; step S3, obtaining impedance data of impedance response; and step S4, acquiring a battery classification area according to the acquired impedance value. According to the battery health state detection method, the impedance response is generated by applying the alternating current with the accurate frequency, and the battery classification region information is acquired according to the impedance data of the impedance response, so that the real-time monitoring of the health state of the battery is realized, and the charging and discharging safety and the operation reliability of the battery in the electric vehicle are effectively guaranteed.

Title: Method for Monitoring Battery Cells of a Primary On-Board Electrical System Battery, On-Board Electrical System and Motor Vehicle
Inventor:
LOPEZ DE ARROYABE JOSE 
WOELFL GERHARD
Abstract: A method for monitoring battery cells of a primary on-board electrical system battery of a motor vehicle by galvanostatic impedance spectroscopy is provided. An AC signal having alternating currents of different frequencies is impressed onto the battery cells as an excitation signal, cell voltage signals of the battery cells are detected as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal, impedance spectra of the battery cells are determined depending on the excitation signal and the response signals, and the primary on-board electrical system battery is divided into at least two subsections each having at least one battery cell in order to provide the excitation signal. The primary on-board electrical system battery is electrically connected to a secondary on-board electrical system battery of the motor vehicle.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method for monitoring battery cells of a primary on-board electrical system battery of a motor vehicle by galvanostatic impedance spectroscopy, the method comprising:
  impressing an AC signal having alternating currents of different frequencies onto the battery cells as an excitation signal,
  detecting cell voltage signals of the battery cells as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal,
  determining impedance spectra of the battery cells depending on the excitation signal and the response signals, and
  dividing the primary on-board electrical system battery into at least two subsections each having at least one battery cell in order to provide the excitation signal, wherein:
  the primary on-board electrical system battery is electrically connected to a secondary on-board electrical system battery of the motor vehicle,
  two cycles alternating at the different frequencies are carried out, in which at least one of:
  two different currents are drawn in alternation from the subsections and a secondary-side constant current formed from the two currents over the cycles is supplied to the secondary on-board electrical system battery, or
   a constant current provided on the secondary side by the secondary on-board electrical system battery is provided on the primary side and two different currents formed from the constant current are supplied to the subsections in alternation, and
  a differential current formed on the primary side from the two currents is supplied to the battery cells as the excitation signal, wherein the direction of the differential current alternates with the cycles.
2. The method according to claim 1,
  wherein at least one frequency-dependent characteristic variable of one of the battery cells is determined from the impedance spectrum of the battery cell.
3. The method according to claim 2,
  wherein at least one of a temperature, a state of charge, or an aging of the battery cell is determined as at least one frequency-dependent characteristic variable of the battery cell.
4. An on-board electrical system comprising:
  a primary on-board electrical system battery comprising a plurality of interconnected battery cells,
  a secondary on-board electrical system battery,
  a vehicle-internal on-board diagnostic device,
  a control apparatus, which is configured to impress an AC signal having alternating currents of different frequencies onto the battery cells as an excitation signal, and
  a measurement apparatus, which is configured to detect cell voltage signals of the battery cells as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal and to determine impedance spectra of the battery cells depending on the excitation signal and the response signals, wherein:
  the primary on-board electrical system battery is divided into at least two subsections each having at least one battery cell and is electrically connected to the secondary on-board electrical system battery via the control apparatus,
  the control apparatus is configured to carry out two cycles alternating with the different frequencies,
  the control apparatus is further configured to at least one of:
  draw two different currents in alternation from the subsections and supply a secondary-side constant current formed from the two currents over the cycles to the secondary on-board electrical system battery, or
   provide a constant current provided on the secondary side by the secondary on-board electrical system battery on the primary side and to supply two different currents formed from the constant current to the subsections in alternation, and
  the control apparatus is further configured to supply a differential current formed on the primary side from the two currents and the direction of which alternates with the cycles to the battery cells of the primary on-board electrical system battery as the excitation signal.
5. The on-board electrical system according to claim 4,
  wherein the control apparatus has a DC-DC voltage conversion apparatus, which is electrically connected to the subsections and to the secondary on-board electrical system battery, and the DC-DC voltage conversion apparatus is configured to at least one of:
  draw the different currents from the subsections, feed the different currents to the subsections same thereto and feed the constant current to the secondary on-board electrical system battery, or draw the different currents from the subsections.
6. The on-board electrical system according to claim 5, wherein
  the DC-DC voltage conversion apparatus has a first DC-DC voltage converter, the primary side of which is electrically connected to the first subsection, and a second DC-DC voltage converter, the primary side of which is electrically connected to the second subsection, and
  the DC-DC voltage converters are electrically interconnectable on the secondary side to one another and to the secondary on-board electrical system battery.
7. The on-board electrical system according to claim 4,
  wherein the primary on-board electrical system battery has a center tap, via which the primary on-board electrical system battery is divided into the two subsections.
8. The on-board electrical system according to claim 4, wherein:
  the primary on-board electrical system battery is configured as a high-voltage battery for supplying at least one high-voltage component of the motor vehicle, and
  the secondary on-board electrical system battery is configured as a low-voltage battery for supplying at least one low-voltage component of the motor vehicle.
9. The on-board electrical system according to claim 4,
  wherein the primary on-board electrical system battery is configured as a traction battery for driving the motor vehicle.
10. A motor vehicle comprising the on-board electrical system according to claim 4.

Title: Lithium battery SOH detection method of BMS
Inventor:
SHANG DEHUA
DU PENGFEI
Abstract: The invention discloses a lithium battery SOH detection method of a BMS, and the method comprises the steps: employing the frequency domain response characteristics of a lithium battery AC small signal, applying specific frequency excitation through scanning, respectively detecting the AC small signal voltage response and current response of the lithium battery at a specific frequency, carrying out the superposition calculation with an excitation signal, and obtaining the SOH of the lithium battery. AC small signal impedance data of the battery under the frequency is obtained, and even an impedance angle, a quality factor, a loss factor and the like can be further calculated. By analyzing impedance data under multiple groups of frequencies, an alternating-current small-signal impedance Nyquist diagram of the battery within a section of frequency can be fitted. And comparing the impedance diagram when the battery leaves the factory with the impedance diagram after multiple times of charging and discharging to obtain the aging condition of the battery, namely SOH. The method has the beneficial effects that the alternating-current small signal impedance of the battery in a frequency range is scanned by utilizing the alternating-current small signal impedance frequency domain response characteristic of the battery to obtain the Neydeclite diagram, and the SOH of the battery can be calculated by comparing the Neydeclite diagram with data when the battery leaves a factory.

Title: Method for managing storage battery, device for managing storage battery, and storage battery system
Inventor:
FUKUI, Masahiro
NISHIMURA YUICHIRO
Hidenori Ito
Abstract: [Problem] To improve the accuracy of impedance acquired from an equivalent circuit identified using operation data. [Resolution Means] a method for managing a battery, the method comprising: identifying a first equivalent circuit of the battery using operation data that includes current data of the battery; and based on the first equivalent circuit, Obtaining an impedance of the accumulator at one or more operating frequencies of the accumulator, wherein the one or more operating frequencies are determined by frequency analysis of the current data. Selected Drawing: FIG.5
Claims:
1. A method for managing a storage battery, comprising: identifying a first equivalent circuit of the storage battery using operation data that includes current data of the storage battery; and obtaining an impedance of the storage battery at one or more operating frequencies of the storage battery on the basis of the first equivalent circuit, wherein the one or more operating frequencies are determined by performing a frequency analysis on the current data.
2. The power generation system according to claim 1, wherein the operation data includes at least first operation data that includes first current data in a first operation of the battery, and second operation data that includes second current data in a second operation that is different from the first operation, and the impedance is at least one of: At least a first impedance of the first equivalent circuit identified using the first operational data and a second impedance of the first equivalent circuit identified using the second operational data, wherein the first impedance is at least one of: Wherein the second impedance is an impedance at one or more first operating frequencies in the first operation and the second impedance is an impedance at one or more second operating frequencies in the second operation; The method for managing a storage battery according to claim 1, whereinthe one or more first operating frequencies are determined by performing frequency analysis on the first current data; andthe one or more second operating frequencies are determined by performing frequency analysis on the second current data.
3. The method for managing a battery according to claim 1 or 2, further comprising identifying a second equivalent circuit different from the first equivalent circuit using the impedance.
4. The method for managing a storage battery according to any one of claims 1 to 3, further comprising: obtaining an impedance at a frequency other than the operating frequency by AC impedance measurement of the storage battery.
5. Identifying a second equivalent circuit, different from the first equivalent circuit, using the impedance at the operating frequency and impedances at frequencies other than the operating frequency, wherein the impedances at the frequencies other than the operating frequency include: The method for managing a storage battery according to any one of claims 1 to 3, wherein the measurement is performed by measuring an AC impedance of the storage battery.
6. The method for managing a storage battery according to claim 4 or 5, whereinthe frequency other than the operating frequency is higher than the operating frequency.
7. The method for managing a storage battery according to any one of claims 1 to 6, whereinthe first equivalent circuit is identified by a sequential least squares method using the operation data.
8. The method of managing an accumulator according to claim 3 or 5, wherein the second equivalent circuit comprises two or more RC parallel circuits and a constant phase element connected in series with the two or more RC parallel circuits.
9. Identifying a first equivalent circuit of an accumulator using operation data that includes current data of the accumulator; and obtaining an impedance of the accumulator at one or more operating frequencies of the accumulator based on the first equivalent circuit. Wherein the one or more operating frequencies are determined by performing a frequency analysis on the current data.
10. A storage battery system comprising: a storage battery; and the management device according to claim 9.

Title: Battery management system with onboard limited energy excitation and real-time AC impedance detection
Assignee: HONG KONG APPLIED SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH INSTITUTE
Inventor:
DING WENLONG
CHEN MENG
SUN YAOFENG
CHEN MANXIN
Abstract: A battery management system (BMS) that detects a battery pack using alternating current impedance. The BMS controller generates a pulse modulation signal to an onboard excitation regulator of a synchronous buck converter and the like, and performs sweep frequency control on the modulation signal to modulate a limited energy unit of a capacitor and the like. The capacitance modulation signal is applied as an AC excitation to the terminals of the battery pack. The voltage of the battery pack obtained by synchronous sampling is a response to the AC excitation signal. The AC excitation signal current and the response signal battery voltage are processed and subjected to Fourier transform to obtain a corresponding Nyquist diagram. The curve offset may indicate an aging condition of the battery cell. The capacitor that generates the AC excitation signal draws little energy from the battery pack only, so AC impedance detection may be performed in all modes, including charge, discharge, and idle modes, without the need for an external power source.

Title: Portable impedance spectroscope and method for measuring impedance spectrum of high-voltage battery pack
Inventor: Ko,Young-Hwii
Abstract: A portable impedance spectroscope for measuring the impedance spectrum of a high-voltage battery pack comprises: an initializing unit for initializing a DAC unit and ADC unit, if a command is delivered by means of a provided GUI; the DAC unit for generating a sine wave perturbation signal in accordance with different frequencies on the basis of a set perturbation amplitude; the ADC unit for obtaining a voltage and current waveform generated by means of the perturbation signal; and an impedance measurement unit for deriving the impedance in a particular frequency on the basis of the obtained voltage and current waveform. Therefore, a portable EIS device can be provided which is capable of measuring the impedance spectrum of a high-voltage battery pack without a separate external power supply.
Claims:
1. An initialization unit configured to initialize the DACunit and the ADCunit when a command is transmitted through the provided guide;
 An apparatus comprising: a DACunit configured to generate sinusoidal perturbation signals according to different frequencies according to a set perturbation amplitude;
 An ADCs to obtain a voltage and current waveform generated by the perturbation signal; and
 An impedance measurement unit deriving an impedance at a specific frequency based on the obtained voltage and current waveforms.
2. The semiconductor device of claim 1, wherein the DACunit comprises:
 A portable impedance spectrometer for measuring the impedance spectrum of a high-voltage battery pack that generates two sinusoidal sweep reference signals superimposed on a DC signal.
3. The semiconductor device of claim 2, wherein the DACunit comprises:
 Control logic for controlling the perturbation signal, the control logic comprising a switch, a comparator, a current sensor and an amplifier.
4. The method of claim 3, wherein the DACunit comprises:
 Compares the gate voltage of the switch with the generated sinusoidal sweep reference signal via feedback of the current sensor to control the perturbation signal.
5. The semiconductor device of claim 1, wherein the ADCs further comprise:
 A portable impedance spectrometer for impedance spectrum measurement of a high-voltage battery pack, comprising a passive high-pass filter and an active low-pass filter and an operational amplifier.
6. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 A portable impedance spectrometer for measuring the impedance spectrum of a high-voltage battery pack, wherein the portable impedance spectrometer is connected with an external device via a USB port.
7. The method of claim 6, further comprising:
 A portable impedance spectrometer for measuring impedance spectrum of a high-voltage battery pack, wherein the portable impedance spectrometer transmits an impedance result calculated to enable the impedance of a specific frequency to be displayed to the external device in real time at the external device.
8. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 At least one of a microcontroller, a high-voltage protection circuit, a signal conditioning circuit, and a sensing circuit.
9. Initializing the DACunit and the ADCunit when a command is communicated to a portable impedance spectrometer coupled with the battery pack;
 Generating sinusoidal perturbation signals according to different frequencies according to perturbation amplitudes set through the DACunit;
 Obtaining a voltage and a current waveform generated by the perturbation signal via the ADCs; and
 Deriving an impedance at a specific frequency based on the obtained voltage and current waveforms.
10. The method defined in claim 9, wherein generating the sinusoidal perturbation signal comprises:
 Wherein a gate voltage of the switch is compared with the generated sinusoidal sweep reference signal through feedback of the current sensor to control the perturbation signal.
11. The method of claim 9, further comprising:
 Transmitting a result of the calculated impedance to the external device such that the impedance of the specific frequency can be displayed in real time on the external device.

Title: Battery temperature management method, battery temperature test method, battery temperature management system, battery temperature test device and storage medium
Inventor:
LIU RUTAO
HOU TIANHONG
XIE JIE
Abstract: The invention discloses a battery temperature management method and system, a battery temperature test method and system, a device and a storage medium. The battery temperature management system comprises a battery, a battery management module and an EIS test module connected with the battery and the battery management module, wherein the EIS test module is located outside the battery. The EIS test module collects a first EIS parameter value of the battery at a first frequency point; the EIS test module transmits the collected first EIS parameter value to the battery management module; the battery management module obtains a first battery internal temperature corresponding to a first EIS parameter value according to the corresponding relation between the one or more battery internal temperatures and the one or more EIS parameter values under the first frequency point set, the EIS parameter value is a parameter related to the state of an internal active material of the battery, and the EIS parameter value corresponds to the change of the battery internal temperature. By adopting the scheme of the invention, the relatively accurate internal temperature of the battery can be obtained without changing the internal structure of the battery.

Title: Battery cell end of life and defect detection system
Inventor:
FASCHING RAINER 
ZERKALOV GEORGY
Abstract: An integrated circuit device includes a controller, an optional current source coupled to the controller, a voltage sampler coupled to the controller, a current detector coupled to the controller, and memory coupled to the controller, where memory includes code segments executable by the controller to: (a) apply a current pulse to a cell; (b) measure a voltage of the cell during the current pulse; (c) calculate an impedance of the cell from the measured voltage; and (d) determine an operational state of the cell from the impedance.

Title: 12v battery end of life prediction with connected services
Inventor:
MARTIN PASCAL STEPHAN 
SCHILLING TROY 
MOTZ JUERGEN 
SCHMUCKER CLEMENS HERMANN 
KOLLER OLIVER DIETER 
HEIDINGER FREDERIC
Abstract: In a number of embodiments, mathematical certainty and confidence to the prediction of battery failure due to a predicted future temperature drop is provided. A connected service may be used by a vehicle to obtain an accurate temperature forecast that will help predict a discrepancy between needed and available cold cranking amps to start a vehicle engine. If a determination is made, based at least upon a temperature forecast and battery health, that the battery will yield insufficient cranking amps to start a vehicle engine in the near future and may not be sufficiently rechargeable, a recommendation that the battery be replaced may be made in advance of the battery's end of life.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A vehicle battery failure estimator comprising;
 an electronic processor configured to:
   produce a model of a vehicle battery as battery state variables and battery model parameters;
  receive a temperature forecast from a connected service;
   predict an end of life of the vehicle battery based upon the model of the vehicle battery and the temperature forecast;
   based on the predicted end of life, generate a notification that the vehicle battery should be replaced; and
   transmit the notification, via the connected service, to a user.
2. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 wherein producing the model of the vehicle battery includes determining an internal impedance of the vehicle battery.
3. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 2 wherein determining the internal impedance for the vehicle battery includes
  measuring a quiescent voltage of the vehicle battery;
 measuring a voltage of the vehicle battery under load;
  measuring an amperage output of the vehicle battery under load; and
 solving for the internal impedance of the vehicle battery based upon the quiescent voltage, the voltage under load, and the amperage output under load.
4. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 wherein notifying the user that the battery should be replaced includes notifying the user of time by which the battery should be replaced.
5. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 further comprising notifying the user that the battery should be recharged.
6. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 wherein receiving the temperature forecast includes
  communicating a request for the temperature forecast, a geographical location for which the temperature forecast is requested, as well as a predetermined span of time for which the temperature forecast is requested; and
  receiving a response to the request.
7. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 wherein the temperature forecast includes a plurality of forecasted temperatures.
8. The vehicle battery failure estimator of claim 1 wherein notifying the user that the vehicle battery should be replaced comprises sending the user one of an SMS message or an email via the connected service.
9. A method comprising:
 determining, by an electronic battery sensor, an internal impedance for a vehicle battery;
  receiving, by an electronic processor, a temperature forecast comprising a plurality of forecasted temperatures from a connected service;
  predicting, by an electronic processor, an end of life of the vehicle battery based upon a correlation of the internal impedance and the temperature forecast; and
  notifying, by an electronic processor, a user of the predicted end of life via a connected service,
  wherein the vehicle battery is constructed and arranged to deliver a required amount of cranking amperage to a starter motor of a vehicle, and
  wherein the predicted end of life manifests as the vehicle battery becoming incapable of maintaining enough charge to deliver the required amount of cranking amperage to the starter motor at a forecasted temperature selected from the plurality of forecasted temperatures.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein notifying the user of the end of life includes illuminating an indicator light or a display in a manner that indicates the end of life.
11. The method of claim 9, wherein notifying the user of the end of life includes sending the user one of an SMS or an email that indicates the an end of life.
12. The method of claim 11, wherein notifying the user of the end of life further comprises a message suggesting to the user that the battery should be replaced within specified time span.
13. The method of claim 9, wherein determining the internal impedance for the vehicle battery includes
  measuring, by the electronic battery sensor, a quiescent voltage of the vehicle battery;
 measuring, by the electronic battery sensor, a voltage of the vehicle battery under load;
  measuring, by the electronic battery sensor, an amperage output of the vehicle battery under load; and
  solving, by the electronic battery sensor, for the internal impedance of the vehicle battery based upon the quiescent voltage, the voltage under load, and the amperage output under load.
14. The method of claim 9, wherein receiving the temperature forecast includes
  communicating a request for the temperature forecast, a geographical location for which the temperature forecast is requested, as well as a predetermined span of time for which the temperature forecast is requested; and
  receiving a response to the request.
15. The method of claim 9, wherein the plurality of forecasted temperatures comprises daily forecasted average temperatures for each day in a span of three days.
16. The method of claim 9, wherein the plurality of forecasted temperatures comprises a collection of lowest reasonably possible temperatures at a geographical location and over a time span for which the temperature forecast is requested.
17. The method of claim 9, wherein predicting an end of life of the vehicle battery further comprises predicting an increase in the cranking amperage required to be delivered to the starter motor in light of the plurality of forecasted temperatures due to a probability of mechanical drag on an internal combustion engine of the vehicle.
18. A method comprising:
 determining, by an electronic battery sensor, an internal impedance for a vehicle battery;
  transmitting, by a connected system of a vehicle, the determined internal impedance to a central computing system;
  correlating, by the central computing system, the transmitted internal impedance to a temperature forecast comprising a plurality of forecasted temperatures;
  predicting, by the central computing system, an end of life of the vehicle battery based upon a correlation of the internal impedance and the temperature forecast; and
  notifying, by the central computing system, a user of the predicted end of life,
 wherein the vehicle battery is constructed and arranged to deliver a required amount of cranking amperage to a starter motor of the vehicle, and
  wherein the predicted end of life is in the form of the vehicle battery becoming incapable of maintaining enough charge to deliver a required amount of cranking amperage to the starter motor at a forecasted temperature selected from the plurality of forecasted temperatures.
19. The method of claim 18, wherein notifying the user of the predicted an end of life includes sending the user one of an SMS or an email notification that indicates the predicted end of life and a message suggesting to the user that the battery should be replaced within specified time span.
20. The method of claim 19, wherein the notification is sent after the vehicle is turned off.

Title: Battery assessment for electric vehicle fleet
Inventor: FERGUSON KENNETH RAMON
Abstract: A battery assessment station for an electric vehicle (EV) battery includes an impedance spectroscopy device that applies an electrical signal at a set of frequencies and measures the impedance response of the battery. A battery analyzer determines a battery parameter, such as remaining useful life or state-of-health, based on the impedance response. A fleet management system manages a fleet of EVs according to their determined battery parameters. For example, the fleet management system applies operational rules regarding the use or charging of the EVs in order to respond to battery degradation and improve battery life.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A system for assessing battery health of a battery-powered electric vehicle (EV) comprising:
  a battery analyzer configured to:
  receive data describing a battery of the EV, the data generated by an impedance spectroscopy device at a battery assessment station; and
   determine at least one parameter describing the battery based on the received data, the at least one parameter determined using a machine-learned model trained using battery assessment data obtained from a plurality of EV batteries; and
  a battery planning module configured to set an operational rule for the EV based on the at least one parameter determined by the battery analyzer; and
  a vehicle manager configured to instruct the EV to perform autonomous driving tasks, the vehicle manager configured to instruct the EV according to the operational rule.
2. The system of claim 1, wherein the impedance spectroscopy device is configured to supply an electrical stimulus comprising a plurality of electrical signals at a corresponding plurality of frequencies, and to measure electrical signals generated by the battery in response to the electrical stimulus.
3. The system of claim 1, wherein the battery analyzer is implemented by the battery assessment station, the battery assessment station comprising communications circuitry configured to transmit the at least one parameter to a fleet management system implementing the battery planning module and the vehicle manager.
4. The system of claim 1, wherein the battery analyzer is further configured to:
  receive on-board sensor data describing the battery from a measurement system on-board the EV; and
  determine the at least one parameter describing the battery further based on the on-board sensor data.
5. The system of claim 1, wherein the battery analyzer is further configured to:
  receive acoustic sensor data describing an acoustic signal propagated through the battery from an acoustic sensor; and
  determine the at least one parameter describing the battery further based on the acoustic sensor data.
6. The system of claim 1, further comprising a degradation analyzer configured to determine a cause of battery degradation based on the at least one battery parameter, wherein the battery planning module is configured to set the operational rule for the EV based on the cause of battery degradation.
7. The system of claim 1, wherein the operational rule comprises a rule related to at least one of an upper charge bound and a lower charge bound for the battery, the upper charge bound comprising a maximum charging level for charging the battery less than a full charge, and the lower charge bound comprising a minimum charge level greater than zero charge at which the vehicle manager instructs the EV to recharge its battery.
8. The system of claim 1, wherein the operational rule comprises a rule related to operation of the EV in an environmental condition, and the vehicle manager is configured to instruct the EV to drive when the environmental condition is present.
9. The system of claim 1, wherein the operational rule comprises a maximum charging rate for the EV, and the vehicle manager is configured to instruct the EV to autonomously drive to a charging station configured to deliver charge at or below the maximum charging rate.
10. The system of claim 1, wherein the operational rule comprises a maximum rate of power draw for the EV to draw power from the battery, and the vehicle manager is configured to instruct the EV to operate in a manner that is expected to draw power at a rate below the maximum rate of power draw.
11. A system for assessing battery health of a battery-powered electric vehicle (EV) comprising:
  a plurality of battery assessment stations, each battery assessment station comprising:
   a battery connection configured to electrically couple the battery assessment station to a battery of an EV;
   a stimulus receive configured to apply an electrical stimulus to the battery of the EV through the battery connection;
   an impedance sensor configured to measure an impedance response of the battery to the electrical stimulus; and
   communications circuitry configured to transmit data based on the measured impedance response;
  a fleet management system configured to:
  instruct the EV to autonomously maneuver to a selected one of the plurality of battery assessment stations for battery assessment;
   receive, from the selected battery assessment station, data based on the measured impedance response of the battery; and
   set an operational rule for the EV based on the data.
12. The system of claim 11, wherein each battery assessment station further comprises a charging module configured to charge the battery through the battery connection.
13. The system of claim 11, wherein each battery assessment station further comprises a battery analyzer configured to determine at least one parameter describing the battery based on the measured impedance response, the at least one parameter determined using a machine-learned model trained by the fleet management system using battery assessment data obtained from a plurality of EV batteries.
14. The system of claim 11, the fleet management system comprising a vehicle manager configured to instruct the EV to perform autonomous driving tasks, the vehicle manager configured to instruct the EV according to the operational rule.
15. The system of claim 11, wherein the electrical stimulus comprises a plurality of electrical signals at a corresponding plurality of frequencies, and the impedance sensor is configured to measure the impedance response of the battery to the electrical stimulus at each of the plurality of frequencies.
16. A method for assessing an electric vehicle (EV) battery and adjusting operation of the EV comprising:
  receiving data generated by an impedance spectroscopy device at a battery assessment station, the data describing an impedance response of the battery to an electrical stimulus;
  determining at least one parameter describing the battery based on the received data, the at least one parameter determined using a machine-learned model trained using battery assessment data obtained from a plurality of EV batteries;
  setting an operational rule for the EV based on the at least one parameter; and
 instructing the EV to perform an autonomous driving according to the operational rule.
17. The method of claim 16, further comprising instructing the EV to autonomously drive to the battery assessment station.
18. The method of claim 16, further comprising:
  applying an electrical stimulus comprising a plurality of electrical signals at a corresponding plurality of frequencies to the battery;
  measuring electrical signals generated by the battery in response to the electrical stimulus at each of the plurality of frequencies; and
  deriving the data describing the impedance response of the battery from the measured electrical signals.
19. The method of claim 16, further comprising:
  receiving acoustic sensor data describing an acoustic signal propagated through the battery from an acoustic sensor; and
  determining the at least one parameter describing the battery further based on the acoustic sensor data.
20. The method of claim 16, further comprising determining a cause of battery degradation based on the at least one battery parameter, wherein the operational rule for the EV is based on the cause of battery degradation.

Title: Oxygen sensor adaptive impedance control
Inventor:
GOODWIN WILLIAM 
BRODESSER SCOTT ECKSTEIN 
BEHR KENNETH JOHN 
VIRGA JOHN JOSEPH
Abstract: Methods and systems are provided for adapting a target impedance of an oxygen sensor. In one example, a method may include updating a target impedance of an oxygen sensor based on a difference between an estimated voltage across a sensing element of the oxygen sensor and a reference RMS voltage of the sensing element. The temperature of the oxygen sensor may be adjusted based on the updated target impedance.
Claims:
The invention claimed is:
1. A method for an engine of a vehicle, comprising:
 updating an initial target impedance of an oxygen sensor based on a difference between a commanded root mean square (RMS) voltage across a sensing element of the oxygen sensor and a reference RMS voltage of the sensing element corresponding to the initial target impedance, and adjusting a temperature of the oxygen sensor based on the updated target impedance.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the commanded RMS voltage is determined across the sensing element during vehicle operation with a first set of operating conditions and while adjusting the temperature of the oxygen sensor based on the initial target impedance.
3. The method of claim 2, wherein the reference RMS voltage is looked up corresponding to the initial target impedance and the first set of operation conditions from a first pre-calibrated table.
4. The method of claim 2, wherein the first set of operating conditions includes one or more of an engine speed, an engine load, an engine temperature, an exhaust flow, and an odometer reading.
5. The method of claim 4, wherein the updated target impedance is estimated based on the difference between the commanded RMS voltage and the reference RMS voltage and the initial target impedance.
6. The method of claim 5, further comprising, in response to the updated target impedance being higher than a threshold impedance, capping the updated target impedance to the threshold impedance.
7. The method of claim 5, further comprising, updating a second pre-calibrated table with an exponentially weighted moving average of the updated target impedance and the odometer reading.
8. The method of claim 1, wherein the temperature of the oxygen sensor is closed loop controlled based on the initial target impedance upon initiation of a drive cycle with the initial target impedance as a setpoint of a proportional integral (PI) controller adjusting power supplied to an oxygen sensor heater.
9. The method of claim 8, further comprising, updating the setpoint of the PI controller to the updated target impedance.
10. The method of claim 8, further comprising, updating a counter for a number of impedance updates being carried out during the drive cycle, and in response to a value of the counter exceeding a threshold, disabling further target impedance updates during a remaining portion of the drive cycle.
11. The method of claim 1, further comprising, in response to the updated target impedance being lower than the initial target impedance by over a threshold amount, indicating a part change in the oxygen sensor.
12. The method of claim 1, wherein the oxygen sensor is coupled to an intake passage or an exhaust passage of the engine.
13. A method for an oxygen sensor in an engine, comprising:
 upon conditions for target impedance adaptation being met,
  estimating a commanded RMS voltage across a sensing element of the oxygen sensor corresponding to a set of current vehicle operating conditions and a current, first target impedance;
  retrieving a reference RMS voltage of the sensing element corresponding to the set of current vehicle operating conditions and the first target impedance;
  estimating a second target impedance as a function of a difference between the commanded RMS voltage and the reference RMS voltage; and
  adjusting a temperature of the oxygen sensor based on the second target impedance.
14. The method of claim 13, wherein adjusting the temperature includes using the second target impedance as a setpoint of a proportional integral (PI) controller adjusting power supplied to an oxygen sensor heater in thermal communication with the sensing element.
15. The method of claim 13, wherein the retrieving the reference RMS voltage includes looking up the reference RMS voltage from a look-up table with the current vehicle operating conditions as input and the reference RMS voltage as output, the current vehicle operating conditions including one or more of an engine speed, an engine load, an engine temperature, and an exhaust flow.
16. The method of claim 13, wherein the second target impedance is further based on the first target impedance and the current vehicle operating conditions.
17. The method of claim 13, wherein the conditions for target impedance adaptation includes one or more of the temperature of the oxygen sensor being within a first threshold range, an air/exhaust flow through the oxygen sensor being within a second threshold range, and a lower than threshold rate of change in engine speed and engine load.
18. A system for an engine in a vehicle, comprising:
 an oxygen sensor; and
  a controller storing instructions in non-transitory memory that, when executed, cause the controller to:
   at an initiation of a drive cycle, adjust power supplied to a heating element in thermal contact with a sensing element of the oxygen sensor based on an initial target impedance; and
   upon a temperature of the oxygen sensor increasing to an operating temperature range during a steady engine speed and engine load condition,
    estimate a difference between a weighted, commanded RMS voltage across the sensing element of the oxygen sensor and a weighted, reference RMS voltage corresponding to the initial target impedance and current vehicle operating conditions;
    update the initial target impedance based on the difference; and
   adjust power supplied to the heating element based on the updated target impedance.
19. The system of claim 18, wherein the updated target impedance is higher than the initial target impedance.
20. The system of claim 18, wherein updating the initial target impedance based on the difference includes estimating the updated target impedance as a function of the difference, a weighted factor, and the initial target impedance, and wherein the controller includes further instructions to:
  during an immediately subsequent engine operation, adjust power supplied to the heating element based on the updated target impedance.

Title: Supplying power to an electric vehicle
Inventor: IJAZ MUJEEB
Abstract: A power supply system that utilizes a hybrid architecture to enable low cycle-life, high energy density chemistries to be used in rechargeable batteries to extend the range of a traction battery.
Claims:
1-45. (canceled)

  a first battery having a first chemistry type and a cell energy density of not more than 500 Wh/L; and
  a second battery having a second chemistry type that is different than the first chemistry type and having a cell energy density of not less than 1000 Wh/L.

49. The battery system of claim 46, wherein the second battery has a cell energy density of at least 1200 Wh/L.

61. The method of claim 57, wherein the first battery has an energy density per cycle (EDC) rating of 0.12-0.16 Wh/L/cycle.

Title: Battery parameter correction system and method and storage medium
Inventor: WANG MENGCHUN
Abstract: The embodiment of the invention discloses a battery parameter correction system and method and a storage medium. The system comprises charging equipment and a power battery, the power battery comprises at least two battery monomers connected in series and a battery management system; the charging equipment is connected in series with the power battery and is used for injecting a harmonic current signal with a preset frequency into the power battery; wherein the preset frequency is a frequency value which is not repeatedly selected in a preset frequency set; and the battery management system is used for sampling a single current signal and a single voltage signal of each single battery corresponding to the harmonic current signal of each preset frequency, and correcting battery parameters of the power battery according to each single current signal and each single voltage signal. The power battery parameters are corrected through the obtained multiple single current signals and single voltage signals, the accuracy of the correction result is improved, the stability of the correction process is improved, and the correction cost and the calculated amount are reduced.

Title: Battery management circuit, battery management device, and battery management network
Inventor:
OKADA YU 
KOBAYASHI HITOSHI 
FUJII KEIICHI
Abstract: A battery management circuit (105) includes: a reference signal generator (109) that generates a first reference frequency signal and a second reference frequency signal having a phase different from a phase of the first reference frequency signal; an alternating-current superimposer (104) that superimposes an alternating current on the secondary battery, the alternating current having a frequency component of the first reference frequency signal; a voltage measurer (115) that measures a voltage of the secondary battery by performing sampling using a frequency higher than a frequency of the first reference frequency signal; a current measurer (112) that measures a current of the secondary battery by performing sampling using a frequency higher than the frequency of the first reference frequency signal; and a converter (118b) that converts each of results of measurements by the voltage measurer (115) and the current measurer (112) into a real part component and an imaginary part component of each of a complex voltage and a complex current, by multiplying the result of the measurement by the first reference frequency signal and the second reference frequency signal.
Claims:
1. A battery management circuit that manages a secondary battery, the battery management circuit comprising:
  a reference signal generator that generates a first reference frequency signal and a second reference frequency signal having a phase different from a phase of the first reference frequency signal;
  an alternating-current superimposer that superimposes an alternating current on the secondary battery, the alternating current having a frequency component of the first reference frequency signal;
  a voltage measurer that measures a voltage of the secondary battery by performing sampling using a frequency higher than a frequency of the first reference frequency signal;
  a current measurer that measures a current of the secondary battery by performing sampling using a frequency higher than the frequency of the first reference frequency signal; and
  a converter that converts each of results of measurements by the voltage measurer and the current measurer into a real part component and an imaginary part component of each of a complex voltage and a complex current, by multiplying the result of the measurement by the first reference frequency signal and the second reference frequency signal.
2. The battery management circuit according to claim 1,
 wherein the voltage measurer and the current measurer repeatedly measure a voltage and a current of the secondary battery, respectively, and
  the battery management circuit comprises an integrator that averages real part components and imaginary part components of complex voltages and complex currents, respectively, the complex voltages and the complex currents corresponding to the repeated measurements.
3. The battery management circuit according to claim 1 or claim 2,
 wherein the voltage measurer includes at least one analog-to-digital converter for measuring a voltage of the secondary battery,
  the current measurer includes an analog-to-digital converter for measuring a current of the secondary battery, and
  the battery management circuit comprises a reference voltage circuit that supplies a common reference voltage to the at least one analog-to-digital converter of the voltage measurer and the analog-to-digital converter of the current measurer.
4. The battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 3,
 wherein the secondary battery includes a plurality of battery cells connected in series, and
  the voltage measurer includes, as at least one analog-to-digital converter, as many analog-to-digital converters as the plurality of battery cells and measures a voltage of each of the plurality of battery cells.
5. The battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 3,
 wherein the secondary battery includes a plurality of battery cells connected in series,
  the battery management circuit comprises a multiplexer that selects one battery cell from the plurality of battery cells, and
  at least one analog-to-digital converter of the voltage measurer is one analog-to-digital converter and measures a voltage of the one battery cell selected by the multiplexer.
6. The battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 5,
 wherein the battery management circuit is a single semiconductor integrated circuit.
7. The battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 5, comprising:
  a first semiconductor integrated circuit and a second semiconductor integrated circuit,
 wherein the first semiconductor integrated circuit includes the voltage measurer, a first reference signal generator that is the reference signal generator, and a first signal synchronizer,
  the second semiconductor integrated circuit includes the current measurer, a second reference signal generator equivalent to the reference signal generator, and a second signal synchronizer,
  the first signal synchronizer causes the first reference signal generator to perform phase matching between the first reference frequency signal in the first semiconductor integrated circuit and the first reference frequency signal in the second semiconductor integrated circuit, and
  the second signal synchronizer causes the second reference signal generator to perform phase matching between the first reference frequency signal in the first semiconductor integrated circuit and the first reference frequency signal in the second semiconductor integrated circuit.
8. The battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 7,
 wherein the second reference frequency signal has the phase orthogonal to the phase of the first reference frequency signal.
9. A battery management system comprising:
 the battery management circuit according to any one of claim 1 to claim 8; and
  an integration controller that specifies the frequency of the first reference frequency signal to the battery management circuit,
  wherein the battery management circuit transmits the real part component and the imaginary part component of each of the complex voltage and the complex current to the integration controller, and
  the integration controller calculates a complex impedance of the frequency specified, from the real part component and the imaginary part component of each of the complex voltage and the complex current transmitted.
10. The battery management system according to claim 9, comprising:
 at least one battery management circuit that is the battery management circuit; and
  a communication cable that daisy chains the integration controller and the at least one battery management circuit,
  wherein the integration controller collects the real part component and the imaginary part component from the at least one battery management circuit via the communication cable.
11. The battery management system according to claim 9 or claim 10,
 wherein the integration controller specifies the frequency of the first reference frequency signal multiple times while changing the frequency of the first reference frequency signal, and calculates a change in the complex impedance corresponding to a change in the frequency specified.
12. The battery management system according to claim 11,
 wherein the integration controller generates drawing data indicating a Cole-Cole plot in which a locus of a complex impedance is traced on a complex plane.
13. The battery management system according to claim 11,
 wherein the integration controller generates drawing data indicating a Bode plot in which a complex impedance is converted into a magnitude and a phase.
14. The battery management system according to any one of claim 9 to claim 13,
 wherein the integration controller obtains a temperature of the secondary battery and converts the complex impedance into a complex impedance corresponding to a predetermined temperature, based on the temperature obtained.
15. The battery management system according to any one of claim 9 to claim 14,
 wherein the integration controller estimates a temperature of the secondary battery at a time of measurement, from the complex impedance calculated, a previously converted complex impedance, and information indicating a temperature of the secondary battery.
16. The battery management system according to claim 14,
 wherein the integration controller calculates an element constant of circuit elements constituting an equivalent circuit model representing the secondary battery, based on the complex impedance corresponding to the predetermined temperature.
17. The battery management system according to any one of claim 9 to claim 16,
 wherein the integration controller adds identification information for identifying the secondary battery to measurement information including the complex impedance calculated, and transmits the measurement information to which the identification information has been added to a server device via a network.
18. The battery management system according to claim 17,
 wherein the integration controller receives battery information from the server device, the battery information including a result of estimating a state of the secondary battery based on the measurement information.
19. The battery management system according to claim 18,
 wherein the server device is included in a server device group sharing the battery information on the network.
20. The battery management system according to claim 19,
 wherein the integration controller causes the server device group to share an aggregate of block data including the measurement information or the battery information, by transmitting the block data to the server device.
21. A battery management network comprising:
 the battery management system according to any one of claim 18 to claim 20; and
  the server device,
 wherein the server device generates the battery information, based on the measurement information.

Title: Method for analysing an on-board electrical system of an at least partially electrically operated motor vehicle by means of an electronic computing device, and electronic computing device
Inventor:
BAUMANN MARTIN 
WEISSINGER CHRISTOPH
Abstract: The invention relates to a method for analysing an on-board electrical system (10) of an at least partially electrically operated motor vehicle, in which a high-voltage energy store (14) is arranged in a high-voltage path (24), at least one first electrical component (16) is arranged in a low-voltage path (18), at least one second electrical component (20) in the low-voltage path (18) and a high-voltage/low-voltage converter (22) are provided, wherein a mathematical model (26) for an impedance (Z) of the first electrical components (16) is generated by means of an impedance analysis, wherein the impedance (Z) is simulated as an electrical circuit (28) in the mathematical model (26) and the first electrical component (16) is replaced by the mathematical model (26) during the analysis, wherein an adaptation of at least one parameter value of an ohmic resistance (R) and/or a capacitance (C) and/or an inductance (L) of the electrical circuit (28) is carried out, and an effect on the second electrical component (20) is simulated as an analysis as a function thereof. The invention also relates to an on-board electrical system (10).
Claims:
1. Method for analysing an electrical on-board electrical system (10) of an at least partially electrically operated motor vehicle by means of an electronic computing device (12), in which a high-voltage energy store (14) is arranged in a high-voltage path (24) of the electrical on-board electrical system (10), at least one first electrical component (16) is arranged in a low-voltage path (18) of the electrical on-board electrical system (10), at least one second electrical component (20) in the low-voltage path (18) and a high-voltage/low-voltage converter (22) between the high-voltage path (24) and the low-voltage path (18) are provided, wherein a mathematical model (26) for an impedance (Z) of the first electrical components (16) is generated by means of an impedance analysis, characterized in thatIn that the impedance (Z) is simulated as an electrical circuit (28) in the mathematical model (26) and the first electrical component (16) is replaced by the mathematical model (26) during the analysis, wherein an adaptation of at least one parameter value of an ohmic resistance (R) and/or a capacitance (C) and/or an inductance (L) of the electrical circuit (28) is carried out, and an effect on the second electrical component (20) is simulated as an analysis as a function thereof.
2. The method of claim 1, characterized in thatIn that the impedance (Z) of the first electrical component (16) is determined as a function of frequency.
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, characterized in thatIn that the impedance (Z) of the first electrical component (16) is determined at different ambient temperatures.
4. Method according to one of the preceding claims, characterized in thatIn that the impedance (Z) is determined at different operating points of the first electrical component (16).
5. Method according to one of the preceding claims, characterized in thatCharacterized in that the adaptation of the at least one parameter value is carried out by means of a bott-duffin method.
6. Method according to one of the preceding claims, characterized in thatCharacterized in that an electrical filter component (30) for at least the first electrical component (16) is proposed as a function of the evaluation of the on-board electrical system (10) by means of the mathematical model (26) in order to reduce interference by means of the electronic computing device (12).
7. Method according to one of the preceding claims, characterized in thatIn that at least one operating point-dependent parameter in the electrical circuit (28) and/or at least one temperature-dependent parameter in the electrical circuit (28) is identified by means of the electronic computing device (12).
8. The method of claim 7, characterized in thatIn that the identification of the at least one parameter is carried out by means of a frequency-dependent pole position investigation and a frequency-dependent zero position investigation of the impedance (Z) in scatter parameter form.
9. Method according to one of the preceding claims, characterized in thatIn such a way that the on-board electrical system (10) is provided and evaluated in a low-voltage storage-free manner.
10. Electronic computing device (12) for analyzing an on-board electrical system (10) of an at least partially electrically operated motor vehicle, wherein the electronic computing device (12) is designed to carry out a method according to one of Claims 1 to 9.

Title: Board charger controller for vehicle, system including the same, and method thereof
Inventor:
LEE SANG KYU 
LIM JIN GYU 
CHUNG SEUNG MYUN
Abstract: An OBC controller for vehicle, a system including the same, and a method thereof are provided. The OBC controller includes a measurement device that measures a voltage of each phase of a three-phase OBC and a controller that calculates an impedance of each phase using a voltage of each phase. The voltage is measured before charging of the three-phase OBC starts. The controller also calculates a charging amount for each phase, the charging amount corresponding to the impedance of each phase, and adjusts charging based on the calculated charging amount for each phase.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. An on board charger (OBC) controller for vehicle, comprising: 
 a measurement device configured to measure a voltage of each phase of a three-phase OBC; and 
 a controller configured to: 
  calculate an impedance of each phase using a voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured before charging of the three-phase OBC starts; 
  calculate a charging amount for each phase, the charging amount corresponding to the impedance of each phase; and 
  adjust charging based on the calculated charging amount for each phase.
2. The OBC controller of claim 1, wherein the controller is configured to increase current supplied to each phase, after measuring the voltage of each phase before the charging starts.
3. The OBC controller of claim 2, wherein the controller is configured to operate the measurement device to measure a voltage of each phase of the three-phase OBC, after increasing the current.
4. The OBC controller of claim 3, wherein the controller is configured to calculate a voltage drop value which is a difference value between the voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured before the charging starts and the voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured after the current is increased.
5. The OBC controller of claim 4, wherein the controller is configured to calculate a phase difference between a voltage of each phase and a current of each phase.
6. The OBC controller of claim 5, wherein the controller is configured to calculate an impedance of each phase of the three-phase OBC based on the voltage drop value and the phase difference between the voltage and the current.
7. The OBC controller of claim 1, wherein the controller is configured to calculate the charging amount inversely proportional to the impedance.
8. The OBC controller of claim 7, wherein the controller is configured to calculate the charging amount for each phase using the voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, and the impedance of each phase.
9. The OBC controller of claim 8, wherein the controller is configured to: 
 divide a value, obtained by subtracting a voltage of a first phase, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, from the amount of current obtained by uniformly distributing a total supplied charging amount, by an impedance of the first phase to calculate a charging amount supplied to the first phase, in response to determining that the voltage of the first phase among three phases, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, is less than a predetermined reference value.
10. The OBC controller of claim 8, wherein the controller is configured to: 
 divide a value, obtained by adding a voltage of a second phase, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, to the amount of current obtained by uniformly distributing a total supplied charging amount, by an impedance of the second phase to calculate a charging amount supplied to the second phase, in response to determining that the voltage of the second phase among the three phases, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, is greater than the predetermined reference value.
11. The OBC controller of claim 8, wherein the controller is configured to set a middle value among voltage values of three phases, the voltage values being measured before the charging starts, as a reference value for calculating the charging amount.
12. A vehicle system, comprising: 
 a three-phase on board charger (OBC); and 
 an OBC controller configured to calculate an impedance of each phase using a voltage of each phase, before charging of the three-phase OBC starts, calculate a charging amount for each phase, the charging amount corresponding to the impedance of each phase, and adjust charging based on the calculated charging amount for each phase.
13. A method for controlling an on board charger (OBC) for vehicle, comprising: 
 measuring, by a controller, a voltage of each phase of a three-phase OBC; 
 calculating, by the controller, an impedance of each phase using the voltage of each phase; and 
 calculating, by the controller, a charging amount for each phase, the charging amount corresponding to the impedance of each phase, and adjusting charging based on the calculated charging amount for each phase.
14. The method of claim 13, wherein the measuring of the voltage includes: 
 measuring, by the controller, a voltage of each phase before charging of the three-phase OBC starts; and 
 adjusting, by the controller, a level of current supplied to each phase depending on a voltage unbalance degree of each phase before the charging of the three-phase OBC starts.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein the calculating of the impedance of each phase includes: 
 increasing, by the controller, the current supplied to each phase.
16. The method of claim 15, wherein the calculating of the impedance of each phase further includes: 
 measuring, by the controller, a voltage of each phase of the three-phase OBC, after increasing the current.
17. The method of claim 16, wherein the calculating of the impedance of each phase further includes: 
 calculating, by the controller, a voltage drop value which is a difference value between the voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured before the charging starts, and the voltage of each phase, the voltage being measured after the current is increased.
18. The method of claim 17, wherein the calculating of the impedance of each phase further includes: 
 calculating, by the controller, a phase difference between a voltage of each phase and a current of each phase.
19. The method of claim 18, wherein the calculating of the impedance of each phase further includes: 
 calculating, by the controller, an impedance of each phase of the three-phase OBC based on the voltage drop value and the phase difference between the voltage and the current
20. The method of claim 19, wherein the adjusting of the charging includes: 
 calculating, by the controller, the charging amount inversely proportional to the impedance.

Title: Sensor for a vehicle electrical system
Inventor:
MARIEN JAN 
SEEL BENJAMIN 
LEPPER ANDREAS 
LEBEAU FELIX 
WASSMANN ALEXANDER 
LEHR MARIO 
WLFEL DANIEL 
BRCKMANN ECKHARD 
WEISS CARSTEN 
GRN MATTHIAS
Abstract: The invention relates to a sensor (S), in particular for a vehicle electrical system of an electrically driven vehicle, in particular in an electric car. The sensor according to the invention first of all comprises a measuring device (ME) for measuring the current and/or voltage in the electrical system, in particular using a low-impedance current measuring resistor for measuring the current using four-wire technology. The sensor (S) according to the invention also comprises an integrated insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) for monitoring electrical insulation of the high side and/or low side of the electrical system. The sensor (S) according to the invention is distinguished by the fact that the insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) operates actively and injects measurement pulses into the electrical system for the purpose of monitoring the insulation.
Claims:
CLAIMS
1. sensor (S) for an electrical network, in particular for an on-board electrical network of an electrically driven vehicle, in particular in an electric car, having a) a measuring device (ME) for measuring current and/or for measuring voltage in the electrical network, in particular having a low-impedance current measuring resistor for measuring current in accordance with four-conductor technology, and b) an integrated insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) for monitoring electrical insulation from high-sides and/or low-sides of the electrical network, characterized in that c) the insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) operates actively and impresses measurement pulses into the electrical network for insulation monitoring.
2. sensor (S) according to Claim 1, characterized by a) a resistive coupling of the insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) to the electrical network, wherein the measurement pulses are DC measurement pulses, or b) a capacitive coupling of the insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) to the electrical network, wherein the measurement pulses are optionally AC measurement pulses, or c) a resistive coupling of the insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) to the electrical network, wherein the measurement pulses are AC measurement pulses.
3. sensor (S) according to Claim 2, characterized a) in that the electrical network has a high-side which can be connected to a positive pole (+) of a battery (BAT), b) in that the electrical network has a low-Side, which can be connected to a negative pole (+) of the battery (BAT), c) in that a chassis ground (GNDCHASSIS) is provided, in particular on the vehicle, d) in that the active insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) determines a leakage capacitance (Cyl, Cy2, Cy3, Cy4) between the low-Side and/or the high-side of the electrical network on the one hand and the chassis ground (GNDCHASSIS) of the electrical network on the other hand, and e) in that the active insulation monitoring device (ME, IQ, Rk, S3) adapts the frequency of the measurement pulses as a function of the leakage capacitance (Cyl, Cy2, Cy3, Cy4) determined.
4. sensor (S) according to one of the preceding claims, characterized by a) a first current connection (Al) for introducing a mains current (I) of the electrical mains into the sensor (S), b) a second current connection (A2) for discharging the mains current (I) of the electrical mains from the sensor (S), c) wherein the measuring device (ME) measures the mains current (I).
5. sensor (S) according to one of the preceding claims, characterized by a) a first voltage measurement connection (M1) for voltage measurement at a first measurement point (1) at the high side of the electrical network downstream of a switchable high-side contactor (RHV+) at the high side of the electrical network, and b) a second voltage measurement connection (M2) for voltage measurement at a second measurement point (2) on the low-Side of the electrical network downstream of a switchable low-side contactor (RHV-) on the low-Side of the electrical network, and c) a third voltage measurement connection (M3) for voltage measurement at a third measurement point (3) at the high side of the electrical network between the battery (BAT) and the high-side contactor (RHV+) at the high side of the electrical network.
6. sensor (S) according to Claim 5, characterized by a) a controllable, high-voltage resistant first isolating switch (S1) at the first voltage measurement connection (M1), wherein the first isolating switch (S1) optionally enables a measurement interrogation at the first voltage measurement connection (M1) or isolates the first voltage measurement connection (M1), and/or b) a controllable, high-voltage resistant second isolating switch (S2) at the second voltage measurement terminal (M2), wherein the second isolating switch (S2) optionally enables a measurement interrogation at the second voltage measurement terminal (M2) or isolates the second voltage measurement terminal (M2).
7. sensor (S) according to one of the preceding claims, characterized by a) a coupling output (AK) for coupling the sensor (S) to a chassis ground (gnd CHASSIS), in particular to the vehicle, wherein the coupling output (AK) is preferably high-impedance, 
2 b) a pulsed voltage source (IQ.) for active insulation monitoring, wherein the pulsed voltage source (IQ) generates the measurement pulses during the active insulation monitoring and outputs them at the coupling output (AK), C) optionally a controllable, high-voltage resistant third isolating switch (S3) at the coupling output (AK) of the sensor (S), wherein the third isolating switch (S3) selectively couples the pulse voltage source (IQ) to the electrical network or isolates it from the electrical network.
8. sensor (S) according to Claim 7, characterized by a computing unit for calculating at least one resistance value (Rfl, Rf2, Rf3, Rf4) and/or one capacitance value (Cyl, Cy2, Cy3, Cy4) in the context of insulation monitoring.
