Title: Battery cell unit and method for determining a complex impedance of a battery cell arranged in a battery cell unit
Inventor: FINK HOLGER
Abstract: A battery cell unit includes a battery cell and a monitoring device for monitoring the state of the battery cell. The monitoring device comprises an actuating device configured to activate an impedance spectroscopy mode provided by the battery cell unit, in which impedance spectroscopy mode measurement currents can be applied to the battery cell to perform impedance spectroscopy of the battery cell, said measurement currents flowing through the battery cell and comprising alternating currents at different frequencies. The monitoring device also comprises a sensor device designed to detect the measurement currents and the corresponding measurement voltages, each of which is a battery cell voltage arising as a response to a measurement current, such that a complex impedance of the battery cell can be determined from the measured values of the measurement currents and the measurement voltages as a function of the frequency of the measurement currents within predetermined tolerance limits.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A battery cell unit comprising: 
 a battery cell having positive and negative battery cell poles; 
 a sensor device configured to detect measurement currents of the battery cell and a measurement voltages of the battery cell; 
 an actuator device comprising at least one power semiconductor switch connected between the positive and negative battery cell poles of the battery cell; and 
 a monitoring device programmed to, in an impedance spectroscopy mode, (i) operate the at least one power semiconductor switch of the actuator device in a linear region to apply impedance spectroscopy currents to the battery cell, the impedance spectroscopy currents including at least a first alternating current at a first frequency and a second alternating current at a second frequency, the second frequency being different than the first frequency, and (ii) determine a complex impedance of the battery cell based on the measurement currents and the measurement voltages provided by the sensor device that arise in response to the application of the impedance spectroscopy currents.
2. The battery cell unit according to claim 1, wherein the sensor device is configured to detect the measurement currents and measurement voltages at least one of simultaneously, with a predetermined repetition rate, and with a predetermined measurement accuracy.
3. The battery cell unit according to claim 1, wherein the monitoring device is further programmed to: 
 determine, based on the measurement currents and measurement voltages provided by the sensor device, amplitudes of the measurement currents and the measurement voltages and phase shifts between the measurement currents and corresponding measurement voltages; 
 determine, from the determined amplitudes and phase shifts, the complex impedance of the battery cell as a function of frequencies of the measurement currents; 
 record the complex impedance of the battery cell as a function of the frequencies of the measurement currents; and 
 evaluate a dependency of the complex impedance on the frequencies of the measurement currents.
4. The battery cell unit according to claim 3, wherein the monitoring device is further programmed to obtain information about a present or future state of the battery cell based on the evaluation of the dependency of the complex impedance on the frequencies of the measurement currents.
5. The battery cell unit according to claim 1, wherein the actuator device is at least one of: 
 an discharge device configured to discharge the battery cell with a predetermined discharge current, and having a power semiconductor switch connected to battery cell poles; 
 a first voltage setting device configured to set a voltage present at battery cell terminals that corresponds to a battery cell voltage in positive orientation or to a voltage of 0 V, and having a half-bridge having two power semiconductors switches that are in each case directly connected to one of the battery cell poles; and 
 a second voltage setting device configured to set a voltage present at the battery cell terminals, the voltage corresponding to the battery cell voltage in positive or negative orientation, having has two half-bridges each including two power semiconductors switches that are in each case directly connected to one of the battery cell poles.
6. The battery cell unit according to claim 5, wherein: 
 a first power semiconductor of the first voltage setting device is directly connected to the positive battery cell pole and is configured for operation in the linear region and a second power semiconductor of the first voltage setting device is directly connected to the negative battery cell pole and is configured to conduct an external current flowing between the battery cell terminals via a first current path external to the battery cell; or 
 at least one of a first and a second power semiconductor of the second voltage setting device is directly connected to the positive battery cell pole or the negative battery cell pole and is configured for operation in the linear region, and a third and fourth power semiconductor of the second voltage setting device is directly connected to the negative battery cell pole or the positive battery cell pole and is configured to conduct an external current flowing between the battery cell terminals via a second current path external to the battery cell.

Title: Battery power capability estimation at vehicle start
Inventor:
WANG XU 
LI YONGHUA 
ANDERSON RICHARD DYCHE 
VANDER LAAN KEVIN 
CHANG XIAOGUANG
Abstract: A vehicle is disclosed comprising a battery and a controller. Projected battery impedance parameters are calculated based on predetermined parameter values and historical parameter values generated by a battery parameter estimation model. The values may be weighted according to time data associated with the historical impedance parameter values and a temperature of the battery. Recent historical impedance parameter values may affect the projected battery impedance parameter values more than older historical impedance parameter values. The model is initialized with projected parameter values at vehicle initialization. Battery power capability is calculated using the projected parameter values for a period of time following vehicle initialization. After the period of time following vehicle initialization, battery power capability is calculated using impedance parameters generated by the model. The period of time following vehicle initialization may end when the model output has converged to a stable solution.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A vehicle comprising: 
 a battery; and 
 at least one controller programmed to, operate the vehicle, for a period of time immediately following vehicle initialization, according to a battery power capability that is based on battery impedance parameters derived from (i) a weighted function of selected predetermined impedance parameters and historical impedance parameters, and (ii) a weighting factor that is based on time data associated with the historical impedance parameters and a temperature of the battery.
2. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein the at least one controller is further programmed to, in response to values of the temperature of the battery being less than a predetermined value during the period of time, calculate the battery power capability based on the predetermined impedance parameters.
3. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein the period of time ends when battery impedance parameters output by a battery parameter estimation model have converged to stable values.
4. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein the at least one controller is further programmed to, after the period of time, calculate the battery power capability based on battery impedance parameters output by a battery impedance parameter estimation model.
5. The vehicle of claim 4 wherein the at least one controller is further programmed to store battery impedance parameters output by the model with associated time data as additional historical impedance parameters.
6. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein the predetermined impedance parameters are selected based on impedance parameters learned during an immediately preceding ignition cycle.
7. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein values of the selected predetermined impedance parameters are based on battery state of charge and battery temperature.
8. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein the historical impedance parameters do not affect battery impedance parameter values when values of the temperature of the battery are less than a threshold.
9. The vehicle of claim 1 wherein recent historical impedance parameters affect values of the impedance parameters more than older historical impedance parameters.

Title: Power battery system for determining the impedance of a module
Assignee: CEA - COMMISSARIAT A L ENERGIE ATOMIQUE & AUX ENERGIES ALTERNATIVES
Inventor:
CATTIN VIVIANE 
AL NAZER ROUBA 
MONTARU MAXIME
Abstract:
The invention relates to a storage battery system (1), comprising: A plurality of serially connected stages including an electrochemical storage battery (4) and a switch; an electrical power connection (71,72); a control device (52) connected to the stages by the electrical connection.
The system includes a plurality of circuits (3), each associated with a stage and configured to generate a voltage amplitude variation across the stage by applying to a switch a binary sequence at a first frequency, each binary sequence being different to discriminate a stage.
The control device (52) is programd to: Measure a variation in the voltage across the terminals of the stage in response to the application of the binary sequence; identify the stage at the origin of the voltage variation; determining the impedance of the identified stage for the first frequency from the measured voltage variation.

Title: Integrated control system for power generation devices
Inventor:
KAI TAKESHI 
OHHIRA MASARU
Abstract: In case different kinds of power generation modules are mounted on a vehicle, an internal impedance and an availability condition varies by each, therefore a control circuit is needed for each of them. As the number of modules and control circuits grow, the cost and the power consumption increase and the efficiency decreases. The present invention solves these issues for multiple power generation modules, composed of different power-harvesting media from each other, with an integrated control system for power generation devices that is configured for generating, charging and consuming the power with the most appropriate distribution ratio, by monitoring an internal impedance thereof and of the battery in real time, and then controlling the impedance-matching units so that each internal impedance of the multiple power generation modules becomes almost equal to that of the battery, for drawing the maximum efficiency out of the modules.
Claims:
1. An integrated control system, for power generation devices, comprising: 
 a plurality of power generation modules composed of different power-harvesting media from each other; 
 a plurality of impedance matching units, each of which is configured to match an internal impedance of one of the power generation modules; 
 a control unit for monitoring and controlling the plurality of impedance-matching units; and 
 a battery which is charged with the plurality of power generation modules
 and supplying the power charged in the battery or generated by the power generation modules to be consumed by loads,
 
 wherein 
 the control unit monitors the internal impedance of each of the power generation modules and an internal impedance of the battery in real time, and then controls the impedance-matching units so that each internal impedance of the plurality of the power generation modules becomes almost equal to the detected internal impedance of the battery.
2. The integrated control system for power generation devices according to claim 1, wherein a solar power generation module is included in the plurality of the power generation modules.
3. The integrated control system for power generation devices according to claim 1, wherein a radio-wave power generation module is included in the plurality of the power generation modules.
4. The integrated control system for power generation devices according to claim 1, wherein a thermal power generation module is included in the plurality of the power generation modules.
5. The integrated control system for power generation devices according to claim 1, wherein a vibration power generation module is included in the plurality of the power generation modules.
6. The integrated control system for power generation devices according to claim 1, wherein the power generation device is mounted on a vehicle.

Title: Battery recharge estimator using battery impedance response
Inventor: HARIHARAN KRISHNAN S
Abstract: An exemplary embodiment includes a method for determining a time to recharge a rechargeable battery system including providing impedance data over a frequency range, said impedance data characterizing the operation of a rechargeable battery within a selected time window; analyzing said impedance data for predetermined behavior of said impedance data indicating an approaching state of discharge of said battery; and, determining from said predetermined behavior of said impedance data whether a recharge of said rechargeable battery is indicated.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method for determining whether a recharge of a rechargeable battery system is indicated comprising: 
 providing impedance data over a frequency range, said impedance data characterizing operation a rechargeable battery within a selected time window; 
 analyzing said impedance data for predetermined behavior of said impedance data indicating an approaching state of discharge of said battery; and, 
 determining from said predetermined behavior of said impedance data whether a recharge of said rechargeable battery indicated; and 
 recharging said rechargeable battery if a recharge of said rechargeable battery is indicated by said impedance data.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein said impedance data is calculated from a Fourier transform of current and voltage data characterizing discharge behavior of said battery system.
3. The method of claim 1, wherein said step of analyzing comprises presenting said impedance data as imaginary impedance versus frequency data and characterizing a slope of said data near zero frequency.
4. The method of claim 3, wherein said characterizing comprises determining whether said slope is negative.
5. The method of claim 3, wherein said step of analyzing comprises presenting said impedance data as imaginary impedance versus real impedance plot over said frequency range and characterizing a low frequency portion of said plot.
6. The method of claim 5, wherein said characterizing comprises determining whether said low frequency portion extends outward of a radius of a semicircle comprising said plot.
7. The method of claim 1, wherein said step of analyzing comprises presenting said impedance data as imaginary impedance versus real impedance plot over said frequency range and characterizing a low frequency portion of said plot.
8. The method of claim 1, wherein said rechargeable battery comprises a lithium containing cathode on discharge.
9. The method of claim 1, wherein said rechargeable battery comprises a vehicle battery system.
10. The method of claim 1, wherein said steps of providing, analyzing, and determining are implemented by programmable instructions executed by one or more on board vehicle controllers.
11. The method of claim 1, further comprising determining an estimated time within which said recharge should take place.
12. A method for determining whether a recharge of a rechargeable battery system is indicated comprising: 
 providing impedance data over a frequency range, said impedance data characterizing operation a rechargeable battery within a selected time window; 
 analyzing said impedance data for predetermined behavior of said impedance data indicating an approaching state of discharge of said battery; and, 
 determining from said predetermined behavior of said impedance data whether a recharge of said rechargeable battery is indicated including determining an estimated time within which said recharge should take place; and 
 recharging said rechargeable battery at said estimated time if a recharge of said rechargeable battery is indicated by said impedance data.
13. The method of claim 12, wherein said impedance data is calculated from a Fourier transform of current and voltage data characterizing discharge behavior of said battery system.
14. The method of claim 12, wherein said step of analyzing comprises characterizing a slope of an imaginary portion of said impedance data versus frequency data near zero frequency.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein said characterizing comprises determining whether said slope is negative.
16. The method of claim 12, wherein said step of analyzing wherein said step of analyzing comprises presenting said impedance data as imaginary impedance versus real impedance plot over said frequency range and characterizing a low frequency portion of said plot.
17. The method of claim 12, wherein said rechargeable battery comprises a lithium containing cathode on discharge.
18. The method of claim 12, wherein said rechargeable battery comprises a vehicle battery system.
19. The method of claim 12, wherein said steps of providing, analyzing, and determining are implemented by programmable instructions executed by one or more on board vehicle controllers.
20. A vehicle system for determining whether a recharge of a rechargeable battery system is indicated comprising: 
 an on-board controller in communication with a vehicle battery system, said controller programmed to determine impedance data over a frequency range, said impedance data characterizing operation a rechargeable battery within a selected time window; 
 said controller further programmed to analyze said impedance data for predetermined behavior of said impedance data indicating an approaching state of discharge of said battery system; 
 said controller further programmed to determine from said predetermined behavior of said impedance data whether a recharge of said rechargeable battery is indicated; 
 wherein said controller is further programmed to output at least one of a signal and a numerical value in response to a determination that said recharge is indicated by said impedance data.

Title: Method for estimating good condition state of e.g. lithium-ion battery, nickel-metal hydride battery of electric vehicle, involves estimating life duration of battery with respect to values of estimating magnitude and real capacity
Inventor: PORCELLATO DENIS
Abstract: The present invention has as an aim a process of estimate of the health status of an electrochemical source of energy, more particularly of a battery (13) intended for the electric traction. The battery is managed by a management system (14) comprising means (16) ready to receive measurements, at the boundaries of the battery, sizes environmental such as the tension, the current and the temperature. The Aforementioned system comprises means (18) of determination of a size of estimate of the lifetime of the battery according to the measured environmental sizes. A real capacity of the battery is determined by the aforementioned system starting from the size of estimate of the lifetime of the given battery. The system considers finally a lifetime of the battery by means of a cartography (38, 39) preestablished connecting values of the size of estimate of the lifetime of the battery and values of the real capacity to estimates of lifetime.
Claims:
1. Method for estimating a state of health of a battery of an automotive vehicle (13) integrated in an electric architecture fitted with an electric circuit (10) for supplying high voltage electric traction (11) motor via an inverter (12), wherein - the measurement (30, 40) magnitudes of the terminals of the battery environmental, - determining (32, 43) a magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery as a function of the measured environmental parameters, characterized in that - evaluating (35, 46) an actual capacity of the battery, from the magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery determined, - estimates (36, 47) a lifetime of the battery by means of a map (38, 39) connecting the values of the preset magnitude estimate the lifetime of the battery and values of the actual capacity to life estimates.
2. Method according to the preceding claim, wherein the evaluation of the actual capacity of the battery comprises the following steps: - determining ((33, 44) a percentage of an increase in the magnitude of estimation of the lifetime of the battery in relation to the value of the internal resistance at the beginning of life of said battery, - determining (34, 45) a loss of capacity of the battery by means of a map (36, 37) connecting the preset percentage of an increase in the magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery capacity loss, - determining the actual capacity of the battery with respect to the determined actual losses and the capacitance value at the beginning of life of said battery.
3. Method according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein a percentage of life of the battery is estimated by means of a preestablished map connecting a percentage variation of the actual capacity of the battery and a change in percentage of the magnitude of the estimation to a percentage of life.
4. Method according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the preset maps are based on data relating to a calendar age and/or age of use in the battery. sec
5. Method according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery is the internal resistance or impedance of the battery.
6. Method according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the measured environmental parameters correspond to the voltage, current and temperature.
7. Method according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said method is performed (42) at the end of a countdown timer initiated automatically and in a loop and whose duration is predefined.
8. System for managing (14) a battery (13) for the electric traction, comprising means for implementing a method of estimating the lifetime of said battery according to one of the preceding claims.
9. Electric or hybrid vehicle characterized in that it comprises a control system according to the preceding claim.

Method for estimating a state of health of a battery of an automotive vehicle (13) integrated in an electric architecture fitted with an electric circuit (10) for supplying high voltage to an electric traction motor (11) via an inverter (12), wherein - the measurement (30, 40) of the terminals of the environmental quantities battery, - determining (32, 43) a magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery according to the quantities measured environmental, characterized in that - evaluating (35, 46) an actual capacity of the battery, from the quantity of estimating the lifetime of the battery determined, - estimates (36, 47) a useful life of the battery by means of a map (38, 39) connecting the values of the preset magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery and the values of the actual capacity to estimates of life, the evaluation of the actual capacity of the battery comprising the steps of: - determining ((33, 44) a percentage of an increase in the magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery in relation to the value of the internal resistance at the beginning of life of said battery, - determining (34, 45) a loss of capacity of the battery by means of a map (36, 37) connecting the preset percentage of an increase in the magnitude of estimating the lifetime of the battery capacity loss, - determining the actual capacity of the battery with respect to the determined actual losses and the capacitance value at the start of life of said battery.

Title: Battery charging method and battery charging device
Assignee: KOOKMIN UNIVERSITY INDUSTRY ACADEMIC COOPERATION FOUNDATION
Inventor: CHOI, WOONG CHUL
Abstract: Disclosed is a battery charging method and a battery charging device. Provided according to one aspect of the present invention is a battery charging method comprising the steps of measuring impedance for each frequency by sequentially applying an alternating current having a different frequency with respect to a battery; from the measured impedances for each frequency, a step for setting the frequency of the alternating current at which chemical diffusion initiates in the battery as a diffusion resistance frequency; and a step for charging the battery by applying thereto a pulse charging current at a charging frequency that is higher than the diffusion resistance frequency.
Claims:
1. A method for
 manufacturing a battery, comprising: Measuring an impedance by frequency by sequentially applying alternating currents of different frequencies to a battery; setting a frequency of the alternating current at which chemical diffusion starts in the battery to a diffusion resistance frequency based on the measured impedance by frequency;
 Applying a pulse charging current to the battery at a charging frequency that is higher than the diffusion resistance frequency to charge the battery.
2. The method of charging a battery according to claim 1, wherein the battery is a lithium ion battery.
3. The battery charging method according to claim 1, wherein the pulse charging current is equal to or higher than 1 C-rate.
4. The battery charging method according to claim 1, wherein the pulse of the pulse charging current is a rectangular pulse waveform that intercharges the charging current.
5. Method according to claim 1, further comprising the step of applying a constant current to the battery to perform constant current charging prior to the step of applying the pulsed charging current to the battery to charge the battery.
6. The battery charging method according to claim 1, wherein the step of charging the battery includes charging the pulse charging current while gradually decreasing or increasing the pulse charging current such that a charging voltage of the battery cell is maintained below a predetermined maximum charging voltage of the battery cell.
7. Method of charging a battery according to claim 1, characterized in that the step of measuring the per-frequency impedance comprises applying alternating currents sequentially from high frequencies to low frequencies for the battery to determine resistance R, capacitance C, inductance L of the per-frequency impedance.
8. The method of charging a battery according to claim 7, wherein the step of measuring the per-frequency impedance further comprises forming a Nyquist Plot according to resistance R, capacitance C, inductance L of the per-frequency impedance.
9. The battery charging method according to claim 8, wherein the step of setting the diffusion resistance frequency of the alternating current includes setting the frequency of the alternating current at which chemical diffusion starts in the Nyquist plot as the diffusion resistance frequency.
10. Method according to claim 9, wherein the starting point of the chemical diffusion is the starting point of the Warburg impedance in the Nyquist plot.
11. A charger body having a charging connector electrically connected to terminals of the battery;
 A battery state information measuring unit including an alternating current power unit applying alternating currents of different frequencies to the battery, an impedance measuring unit measuring impedance per frequency according to application of the alternating current, and a charging frequency setting unit setting a frequency of the alternating current at which chemical diffusion starts in the battery from the measured impedance per frequency as a diffusion resistance frequency;
 And a pulse charging section provided in the charging device main body and configured to apply a pulse charging current to the battery at a charging frequency of higher frequency than the diffusion resistance frequency to charge the battery.
12. The battery charging device as claimed in claim 11, wherein the battery is a lithium ion battery.
13. The battery charging device according to claim 11, wherein the pulse charging current is equal to or higher than 1 C-rate.
14. The battery charging device according to claim 11, wherein the pulse of the pulse charging current is a rectangular pulse waveform that intercharges the alternating current.
15. The battery charging apparatus as claimed in claim 11, wherein the pulse charging power supply part performs constant current charging by applying a constant current to the battery before applying the pulse charging current to the battery.
16. The battery charging apparatus as claimed in claim 11, wherein the pulse charging power supply unit is configured to charge the pulse charging current while gradually decreasing or increasing the pulse charging current such that the charging voltage of the battery cell is maintained below a predetermined maximum charging voltage of the battery cell.
17. The device for charging a battery according to claim 11, wherein the impedance measurement unit calculates the resistance R, capacitance, and inductance L of the per-frequency impedance by sequentially applying alternating currents from high frequency to low frequency to the battery.
18. The
 battery device according to claim 17, wherein the impedance measuring unit prepares a Nyquist plot according to resistance R, capacitance C, and inductance L of impedance per frequency, and the charging frequency setting unit sets the frequency of the alternating current at which chemical diffusion starts in the Nyquist plot as the diffusion resistance frequency.
19. The apparatus of claim 18, wherein the starting point of the chemical diffusion is the starting point of a Warburg impedance in the Nyquist lead.

Title: Battery impedance spectrum in-situ online measurement system and measurement method
Inventor:
CAI TAO
WEI BANGDA
YUAN AOTE
Abstract: The invention provides a battery impedance spectrum in-situ online measurement system and a measurement method, which belong to the field of battery impedance spectrum detection. Compared with the prior art, the measurement system provided by the invention can realize in-situ online detection under the condition that the normal charge-discharge operation of a battery system is not influenced; the current disturbance energy is generated by using reactive power, so that the active power consumption is reduced; the impedance spectrum detection of each single battery cell in the battery system can be realized in a lower cost, higher precision and inspection mode.

Title: Battery management system, temperature measurement device, and control method
Assignee:
SUMITOMO ELECTRIC INDUSTRIES 
AUTONETWORKS TECHNOLOGIES 
SUMITOMO WIRING SYSTEMS
Inventor:
ZHENG, Xiaoguang 
SONODA Fujio 
KOMATSU, Yutaka
Abstract: This battery management system comprises: a linear member attached to each of a plurality of cells included in a battery unit; a detection unit which calculates an impedance change of the linear member on the basis of a reflected wave propagating through the linear member, and detects a temperature change in the plurality of cells on the basis of the calculated impedance change; and a determination unit which determines whether or not there is an abnormality in the plurality of cells in accordance with the detection result of the detection unit.
Claims:
1. A power generation apparatus comprising: a linear member attached to each of a plurality of cells included in a battery unit; and an impedance change calculating unit configured to calculate an impedance change of the linear member on the basis of a reflection wave propagating through the linear member, A detection unit configured to detect a change in temperature of the plurality of cells on the basis of the calculated impedance change; and a determination unit configured to determine the presence or absence of an abnormality in the plurality of cells on the basis of a detection result from the detection unit.
2. The connector according to claim 1, wherein the linear member includes a base material portion having insulating properties, and a first conductor portion and a second conductor portion having conductive properties disposed facing each other with the base material portion interposed therebetween, and the connector further includes: a first direction that is a longitudinal direction of the linear member; The first conductor portion has a smaller width than the second conductor portion in a third direction, the third direction intersecting a second direction being a normal direction of a surface in which the linear member is in contact with the plurality of cells.
3. The battery management system of claim 2 wherein the substrate portion is formed of polyamide.
4. A thickness of the base material portion in the second direction is not less than 100 ?m and not more than 600 ?m, a width of the base material portion in the third direction is not less than 5 mm and not more than 15 mm, and a width of the first conductor portion in the third direction is not less than The battery management system of claim 3, wherein a width of the second conductor portion in the third direction is equal to a width of the base material portion in the third direction.
5. The battery management system according to any one of claims 2 to 4, wherein the first conductor portion is disposed at a position closer to the cell than the second conductor portion.
6. The battery management system according to any one of claims 1 to 5, further comprising: two heat dissipation sheets disposed along the first direction and sandwiched between each of the plurality of cells and the linear member, separated from each other in the third direction.
7. The battery management system of any one of claims 1 to 6, further comprising the battery unit.
8. A temperature measurement device comprising: a linear member attached to each of a plurality of cells included in a battery unit; anda detection unit configured to calculate an impedance change of the linear member on the basis of a reflection wave propagating through the linear member, and to detect a temperature change of the plurality of cells on the basis of the impedance change that is calculated.
9. A power generation method comprising: an input step of inputting an AC signal to a linear member attached to each of a plurality of cells included in a battery unit; a measurement step of measuring a change in impedance of the linear member on the basis of a reflection wave propagating through the linear member due to the input of the AC signal; A detection step of detecting a change in temperature of the plurality of cells on the basis of the measured impedance change; and a determination step of determining presence or absence of abnormality in the plurality of cells on the basis of a detection result of the detection step.

Title: Battery state estimation method and system based on neural network and impedance identification correction
Inventor:
PENG CHENG
LI RUI
Abstract: The invention provides a battery state estimation method and a system based on a neural network and impedance identification correction, wherein the method comprises the following steps: randomly sampling the battery cells of the same batch to obtain a test sample, performing cycle life test on the test sample, and collecting electrochemical impedance spectrums under different temperatures, charge states and battery aging states; fitting a function of any 3 parameters to another parameter by using a neural network; carrying out primary mixed power pulse test on the battery cell used for the energy storage system, calibrating each parameter, and carrying out contrast correction on the parameter and the obtained electrochemical impedance spectrum function; the assembled battery core obtains an energy storage system and is put into operation, and a particle filter is adopted to obtain the charge state and the aging state of the battery during operation; and regularly measuring or correcting the electrochemical impedance of the battery on line, correcting parameters by using the function, and judging whether an abnormal battery exists. The method has the characteristics of easy fitting, strong interpretability, high estimation accuracy, capability of monitoring the state of the battery in real time and the like.

Title: Impedance measuring device based on interleaved boost circuit and measuring method thereof
Inventor:
LIU FURONG
LU ZHONGCHANG
XIE ZHANGJUN
YANG YANG
ZHU WENCHAO
SHI YING
DU BANGHUA
Abstract: The invention relates to the technical field of fuel cells, and discloses an impedance measuring device based on a staggered parallel boost circuit, which is characterized in that: the device comprises an interleaved boost main circuit, a boost disturbance circuit, a PI controller, a driving circuit, a signal acquisition module and an impedance calculation module, wherein the PI controller compares a load signal fed back and a given reference signal, and calculates an obtained error value to obtain a duty ratio which is used as the duty ratio of a PWM (pulse width modulation) module in the PI controller. The invention also discloses a measuring method of the impedance measuring device based on the staggered parallel boost circuit. The impedance measuring device and the impedance measuring method based on the staggered parallel boost circuit realize the measurement of the impedance of the fuel cell without an external excitation source while realizing the boost of the fuel cell of the electric automobile through the staggered parallel boost circuit.

Title: Cloud-device synergy-based battery management system, vehicle, and battery management method
Inventor:
YU WEI 
LONG GANG 
LI ZHIRUN
Abstract: This application relates to the field of artificial intelligence technologies, and in particular, to a cloud-device synergy-based battery management system, a vehicle, and a battery management method.The system includes a vehicle and a cloud BMS. The vehicle includes a vehicle BMS, and the vehicle BMS includes a sensor and a decision processing module. The vehicle BMS is configured to: measure a battery parameter of the vehicle by using the sensor, and send first battery parameter data obtained through measurement to the cloud BMS. The cloud BMS is configured to: train second battery parameter data, and send a first training result obtained through training to the vehicle BMS, where the second battery parameter data includes the first battery parameter data and historical battery parameter data. The vehicle BMS is further configured to update the decision processing module based on the first training result.The system implements vehicle battery management through cooperation of the vehicle BMS and the cloud BMS. This improves real-time performance and reliability of vehicle battery management.
Claims:

  the vehicle battery management system is configured to: measure a battery parameter of the vehicle by using the sensor, and send first battery parameter data obtained through measurement to the cloud battery management system;
  the cloud battery management system is configured to: train second battery parameter data, and send a first training result obtained through training to the vehicle battery management system, wherein the second battery parameter data comprises the first battery parameter data and historical battery parameter data; and
  the vehicle battery management system is further configured to update the decision processing module based on the first training result.
2. The system according to claim 1, wherein the first training result comprises a cloud pre-training model; and
 the vehicle-end battery management system is specifically configured to: perform fine-tuning or transfer learning on the cloud pre-training model to obtain a second training result, and update the decision processing module based on the second training result.

The system according to claim 1, wherein the first training result comprises a global model or a local model, a global model is used for a plurality of different vehicle types comprising a type to which the vehicle belongs, and a local model is used for the vehicle or a vehicle type to which the vehicle belongs; and
 the vehicle battery management system is specifically configured to: update the decision processing module based on the global model or the local model; or perform fine-tuning or transfer learning on the global model or the local model to obtain a third training result, and update the decision processing module based on the third training result.

A cloud-device synergy-based battery management method, applied to a cloud-device synergy-based battery management system, wherein the cloud-device synergy-based battery management system comprises a vehicle and a cloud battery management system, the vehicle comprises a vehicle battery management system, and the vehicle battery management system comprises a sensor and a decision processing module; and

Title: Inspection device, inspection method, and program
Inventor:
Masashi Doi 
ASHIDA, Takeshi 
TOKUSAKI, Hiroyuki 
Sinking ** Good ** Feather
Abstract: Provided is an inspection device for a supply path that includes an LC circuit comprising inductance and a capacity of a smoothing capacitor, and that supplies DC current to an inverter that supplies AC current converted from DC current to a motor. The inspection device includes: a measurement unit that measures the impedance of the LC circuit in a case in which a second voltage is applied to the supply path, the second voltage being different from a first voltage that has a slight fluctuation when the motor is stopped and is applied to the supply path when the motor is driven; a determination unit that, in a case in which the motor is driven by the application of the first voltage to the supply path, uses a measurement result of the impedance of the LC circuit to determine whether an oscillation phenomenon caused by interaction between the impedance of the LC circuit and a control response of the inverter is possible; and an output unit that outputs a determination result of the determination unit.
Claims:
1. An inspection device for a supply path that supplies a direct current to an inverter that supplies an alternating current converted from the direct current to a motor, the inspection device comprising: A measurement unit that measures an impedance of the LC circuit when a second voltage is applied to the supply path, the second voltage having minute variations and being different from a first voltage applied to the supply path when the motor is driven; and A determination section that determines, using a measurement result of an impedance of the LC circuit, whether an oscillation phenomenon due to interaction between the impedance of the LC circuit and a control response of the inverter can occur when the motor is driven by application of the first voltage to the supply path; and an output section that outputs a determination result of the determination section.
2. The inspection device according to claim 1, wherein the determination unit determines whether a peak of an impedance measurement result of the LC circuit exceeds an absolute value of a minimum value of negative resistance values equivalent to the inverter and the motor, and the output unit outputs that the oscillation phenomenon is likely to occur when the peak exceeds the absolute value of the minimum value of the negative resistance values.
3. The device according to claim 1, wherein the measurement unit measures a voltage between both ends of the smoothing capacitor when the second voltage is applied, and calculates a voltage value of minute fluctuations included in the second voltage; The impedance of the LC circuit is calculated using a voltage value of minute fluctuations corresponding to a voltage value of minute fluctuations of the second voltage included in the voltage between both ends of the smoothing capacitor.
4. The inspection device according to claim 1 or 2, wherein the measurement unit is connected to a predetermined resistor, measures a current flowing in the resistor when the second voltage is applied, and calculates an impedance of the LC circuit using a value of the predetermined resistor, a voltage value of minute variation included in the second voltage, and a value of the current.
5. The inspection device according to claim 4, wherein the measurement unit measures a current flowing through a brake resistor configured to absorb regenerated energy from the motor when the brake resistor is connected to the supply path as the predetermined resistor.
6. The inspection device according to any one of claims 1 to 5, wherein the output unit outputs a capacitance to be added to the smoothing capacitor when the determination unit determines that the oscillation phenomenon can occur.
7. The inspection device according to claim 2, wherein when the determination unit determines that the peak exceeds an absolute value of a minimum value of the negative resistance value, the output unit calculates a capacitance to be added to the smoothing capacitor by using a target value of impedance of the LC circuit, a value indicating the peak, and an angular frequency at the peak, and outputs the capacitance.
8. A method for inspecting a supply path that supplies a direct current to an inverter that supplies an alternating current converted from the direct current to a motor, the inverter having a LC circuit including inductance and a capacitance of a smoothing capacitor, the method comprising: Measuring an impedance of the LC circuit when the motor is stopped when a second voltage is applied to the supply path, the second voltage having minute variations and being different from a first voltage applied to the supply path when the motor is driven; Determining, using a measurement result of an impedance of the LC circuit, whether an oscillation phenomenon due to interaction between the impedance of the LC circuit and a control response of the inverter may occur when the motor is driven by application of the first voltage to the supply path; and outputting a result of the determination.
9. A program for inspecting a supply path that supplies a direct current converted from the direct current to an inverter that supplies the direct current to a motor, the inverter having a LC circuit including inductance and a capacitance of a smoothing capacitor, the program comprising: Measuring an impedance of the LC circuit when the motor is stopped when a second voltage is applied to the supply path, the second voltage having minute variations and being different from a first voltage applied to the supply path when the motor is driven; When the motor is driven by the application of the first voltage to the supply path using the measurement result of the impedance of the LC circuit, Determining whether an oscillation phenomenon due to interaction of an impedance of the LC circuit and a control response of the inverter may occur; and outputting a result of the determination.

Title: Battery model estimation based on battery terminal voltage and current transient due to load powered from the battery
Inventor: MARCHAIS EMMANUEL
Abstract: A method for estimating parameters of a battery impedance model that models an output impedance of a battery may include dividing the battery impedance model into a plurality of separate impedance stages, wherein each separate impedance stage approximates the battery impedance model within a particular frequency range, the respective impedance in each separate impedance stage comprises a primary impedance model with a primary set of defining impedance parameters and a secondary impedance model with a secondary set of impedance parameters, and the battery impedance model is defined by a series connection of the respective primary impedance models of the plurality of impedance stages. The method may also include monitoring operation of the battery to determine the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method for estimating parameters of a battery impedance model that models an output impedance of a battery, comprising:
  dividing the battery impedance model into a plurality of separate impedance stages, wherein:
  each separate impedance stage approximates the battery impedance model within a particular frequency range;
   the respective impedance in each separate impedance stage comprises a primary impedance model with a primary set of defining impedance parameters and a secondary impedance model with a secondary set of impedance parameters; and
   the battery impedance model is defined by a series connection of the respective primary impedance models of the plurality of impedance stages; and
  monitoring operation of the battery to determine the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein monitoring operation of the battery comprises monitoring a terminal voltage and a terminal current of the battery associated with a transient response of the battery for powering a load that is drawing a current on the battery to provide power to a component of a device.
3. The method of claim 2, wherein the load is an actual load of a mobile device having components powered from the battery.
4. The method of claim 2, further comprising for each separate impedance stage of the plurality of separate impedance stages, in order to estimate the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage, band-pass filtering the terminal voltage and the terminal current in the particular frequency range associated with such separate impedance stage.
5. The method of claim 4, wherein:
 band-pass filtering of the terminal voltage and the terminal current forms a sequence; and
  the method further comprises using the sequence to perform a least squares fit to estimate the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
6. The method of claim 5, wherein performing the least squares fit comprises:
  in a first estimation step, estimating the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage; and
  in a second estimation step, presetting the secondary set of impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage and estimating only the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
7. The method of claim 6, further comprising:
  performing the first estimation step only once for such separate impedance stage; and
 repeatedly performing the second estimation step to dynamically update the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
8. The method of claim 4, further comprising estimating the primary set of defining impedance parameters of the plurality of separate impedance stages using a multi-rate process wherein, for each separate impedance stage, a sampling rate is used which is sufficient to adequately fit such separate impedance stage of the battery impedance model over the particular frequency range of the separate impedance stage.
9. The method of claim 2, further comprising reducing an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a signal-to-noise ratio of either or both of the terminal voltage and the terminal current is below a threshold ratio.
10. The method of claim 1, further comprising reducing an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a load of the battery is idle.
11. The method of claim 1, further comprising reducing an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a load of the battery has significant spectral content outside of a frequency band of interest.
12. The method of claim 1, wherein monitoring operation of the battery comprises applying a broadband test excitation to the battery.
13. The method of claim 1, wherein for each of the plurality of separate impedance stages, the primary impedance model for such separate impedance stage defines a main feature of an impedance of the battery impedance model for the particular frequency range of such separate impedance stage.
14. The method of claim 1, wherein for each of the plurality of separate impedance stages, the secondary impedance model for such separate impedance stage defines a residual feature of the primary impedance models of the other separate impedance stages.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein the secondary impedance model for such separate impedance stage is a lumped model of impedance of the primary impedance models of the other separate impedance stages.
16. The method of claim 1, wherein determining the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters for each separate impedance stage comprises constraining at least one parameter of either or both of the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters based on a priori knowledge of the valid range of the respective parameter.
17. The method of claim 16, wherein the constraining is based on characterization of a population of samples of the battery.
18. The method of claim 1, further comprising using the battery impedance model to predict battery characteristics.
19. The method of claim 18, wherein the battery characteristics include at least one of: a maximum available power of the battery, a state of charge of the battery, a state of health of the battery, and an internal state of the battery.
20. The method of claim 19, wherein the internal state may include at least one of an open-circuit voltage of the battery, an internal overpotential states of the battery, a lithium-ion anode potential of the battery, and some other state representing a condition of the battery that may lead to degradation of its chemistry.
21. A system for estimating parameters of a battery impedance model that models an output impedance of a battery, comprising:
  one or more inputs configured to receive information regarding operation of the battery; and
 battery monitoring circuitry configured to:
   divide the battery impedance model into a plurality of separate impedance stages, wherein:
   each separate impedance stage approximates the battery impedance model within a particular frequency range;
    the respective impedance in each separate impedance stage comprises a primary impedance model with a primary set of defining impedance parameters and a secondary impedance model with a secondary set of impedance parameters; and
    the battery impedance model is defined by a series connection of the respective primary impedance models of the plurality of impedance stages; and
   monitor operation of the battery to determine the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters.
22. The system of claim 21, wherein monitoring operation of the battery comprises monitoring a terminal voltage and a terminal current of the battery associated with a transient response of the battery for powering a load that is drawing a current on the battery to provide power to a component of a device.
23. The system of claim 22, wherein the load is an actual load of a mobile device having components powered from the battery.
24. The system of claim 22, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to, for each separate impedance stage of the plurality of separate impedance stages, in order to estimate the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage, band-pass filter the terminal voltage and the terminal current in the particular frequency range associated with such separate impedance stage.
25. The system of claim 24, wherein:
  band-pass filtering of the terminal voltage and the terminal current forms a sequence; and
 wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to use the sequence to perform a least squares fit to estimate the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
26. The system of claim 25, wherein performing the least squares fit comprises:
  in a first estimation step, estimating the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage; and
  in a second estimation step, presetting the secondary set of impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage and estimating only the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
27. The system of claim 26, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to:
  perform the first estimation step only once for such separate impedance stage; and
 repeatedly perform the second estimation step to dynamically update the primary set of defining impedance parameters of such separate impedance stage.
28. The system of claim 24, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to estimate the primary set of defining impedance parameters of the plurality of separate impedance stages using a multi-rate process wherein, for each separate impedance stage, a sampling rate is used which is sufficient to adequately fit such separate impedance stage of the battery impedance model over the particular frequency range of the separate impedance stage.
29. The system of claim 22, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to reduce an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a signal-to-noise ratio of either or both of the terminal voltage and the terminal current is below a threshold ratio.
30. The system of claim 21, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to reduce an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a load of the battery is idle.
31. The system of claim 21, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to reduce an adaptation rate of the primary set of defining impedance parameters when a load of the battery has significant spectral content outside of a frequency band of interest.
32. The system of claim 21, wherein monitoring operation of the battery comprises applying a broadband test excitation to the battery.
33. The system of claim 21, wherein for each of the plurality of separate impedance stages, the primary impedance model for such separate impedance stage defines a main feature of an impedance of the battery impedance model for the particular frequency range of such separate impedance stage.
34. The system of claim 21, wherein for each of the plurality of separate impedance stages, the secondary impedance model for such separate impedance stage defines a residual feature of the primary impedance models of the other separate impedance stages.
35. The system of claim 34, wherein the secondary impedance model for such separate impedance stage is a lumped model of impedance of the primary impedance models of the other separate impedance stages.
36. The system of claim 21, wherein determining the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters for each separate impedance stage comprises constraining at least one parameter of either or both of the primary set of defining impedance parameters and the secondary set of impedance parameters based on a priori knowledge of the valid range of the respective parameter.
37. The system of claim 36, wherein the constraining is based on characterization of a population of samples of the battery.
38. The system of claim 21, wherein the battery monitoring circuitry is further configured to use the battery impedance model to predict battery characteristics.
39. The system of claim 38, wherein the battery characteristics include at least one of: a maximum available power of the battery, a state of charge of the battery, a state of health of the battery, and an internal state of the battery.

The system of claim 39, wherein the internal state may include at least one of an open-circuit voltage of the battery, an internal overpotential state of the battery, a lithium-ion anode potential of the battery, and some other state representing a condition of the battery that may lead to degradation of its chemistry.

Title: Simulation prediction method, system, computer device and storage medium for modeling coupling characteristic of automobile wire harness
Inventor:
JIANG YICHI
GU YUANYE
LI ZHIGANG
SUN YUNXI
MA LIANG
SONG XIGANG
ZHANG BAOGUO
GAO CHAO
SUN ZICHAO
ZHAO XU
Abstract: The invention provides a method, a system, computer equipment and a storage medium for modeling and simulating the coupling characteristics of an automobile wire harness, which comprises the steps of collecting real automobile port data; the method comprises the steps of obtaining S parameters, equivalent impedance of an interference source Thevenin, equivalent impedance of the interference source port looking to the direction of a wire harness and current of the interference source port; step two, calculating the Thevenin equivalent impedance of the data interference source, the equivalent impedance of the interference source port looking to the wire harness direction and the current of the interference source port in the step one to obtain the Thevenin equivalent voltage of the interference source; step three, converting the data S parameters to obtain Z parameters, substituting the Z parameters and thevenin equivalent voltage of the interference source in the step two into a prediction formula, and predicting to obtain port voltage and current at two ends of the interference source and port voltage and current at two ends of the sensitive element; the original qualitative experience judgment is converted into quantitative objective judgment, the judgment accuracy is improved, the risk is effectively avoided, and the project later-stage modification and test cost is reduced.

Title: Status Diagnosis and Disability Prediction System for Moving Objects Battery and thereof Method
Inventor: PARK, Changseo
Abstract: A state diagnosis and failure prediction system of a moving object battery and a method thereof are provided. the state diagnosis and failure prediction system includes a battery actual measurement module that individually measures battery cells/modules/packs, a battery management module that manages a current state of a battery embedded in the moving object, A cloud server generating state diagnosis data and failure prediction data of a battery by establishing a learning result dB by an AI learning process according to measurement data measured from the battery actual measurement module and analyzing current state data of a battery of the battery management module through big data in which DBs are established through AI learning of the measurement data, A battery state inquiry module configured to inquire a state of the battery according to state diagnosis data and failure prediction data of the battery generated by analysis in the cloud server to preclude the battery predicted failure, and a user terminal of a mobile body configured to receive the state diagnosis data and failure prediction data of the battery analyzed from the cloud server, by analyzing the state of the moving object battery in more detail, it is possible to accurately predict a point of occurrence of a failure with respect to the moving object battery. In addition, the battery state inquiry module performs preventive maintenance on failure according to the battery state of the moving object input from the cloud server, and transmits the battery state to the cloud server through the battery actual measurement module. accordingly, it is possible to continuously predict accurate failure of the battery.
Claims:
1. AMEND STATUS: Delete
2. AMEND STATUS: Delete
3. AMEND STATUS: Delete
4. A battery management system comprising: a battery actual measurement module that individually measures battery cells/modules/packs; a battery management module of the battery pack that manages a current state of a battery embedded in a moving body; Title: Lithium ion battery interface impedance nondestructive separation method
Inventor:
ZHANG CAIPING
CAI XUE
ZHANG LINJING
ZHANG WEIGE
ZHANG YANRU
RUAN HAIJUN
SUN BINGXIANG
Abstract: The invention discloses a lithium ion battery interface impedance nondestructive separation method, which reconstructs real impedance reflecting interface dynamics based on total impedance and a high-frequency inductive reactance and low-frequency diffusion model, uses a relaxation time deconvolution technology and an equivalent circuit to identify model parameters of an interface, realizes the nondestructive separation of electrode interface dynamics model parameters through 50% and 5% SOC impedance data, and verifies the effectiveness of the technology in three-electrode impedance. Meanwhile, the separable SOC charge transfer internal resistance is transferred to the comparative SOC according to the conversion coefficient of the charge transfer internal resistance, so that the characteristic parameter evolution law analysis at the same SOC point is realized. The method has simple steps, is easy to operate, has high reliability, and is suitable for the dynamic nondestructive diagnosis of the electrode interface of the power battery of the electric automobile.

Title: Lithium ion battery AC impedance on-line measurement method and measurement system
Inventor:
LIU XINLE
LI RUI
XIE HONGYANG
PENG CHENG
Abstract: The invention provides a lithium ion battery AC impedance on-line measurement method and system, and the method comprises the steps: injecting a duty ratio disturbance signal with a corresponding amplitude and frequency into a PWM control signal according to the size and frequency of an excitation current needed by the measurement of the AC impedance of a lithium ion battery, and controlling the generation of the needed excitation current; in the normal charging or discharging process of the lithium ion battery, excitation current is provided for the battery; collecting a current signal flowing through the battery and voltage signals at two ends of the battery, and performing signal processing to obtain a current sampling signal and a voltage sampling signal; and calculating alternating current impedance information of the lithium ion battery according to the current sampling signal and the voltage sampling signal. According to the invention, a large DC signal in the to-be-measured signal is removed, an AC signal is accurately sampled and measured, the sampling precision of the voltage and current of the battery is improved, and the impedance measurement precision of the battery is further improved. Alternating-current impedance under multiple frequencies can be obtained through one-time excitation, and the impedance measurement time is shortened.

Title: Charge/discharge management in electrochemical cells, including partial cycle control
Inventor:
MIKHAYLIK YURIY V 
SCORDILIS-KELLEY CHARICLEA
Abstract: Electrochemical cell and battery management systems are generally provided. The systems can comprise an electrochemical cell and a controller. In some cases, the controller can be used to control various aspects of the charge and/or discharge of the electrochemical cell. In some cases, the system can comprise one or more strings of cells.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1-53. (canceled)
54. An electrochemical cell management system comprising:
 an electrochemical cell; and
  at least one controller configured to:
  monitor at least one characteristic of the cell indicating a loss of lithium in the cell; and
   based on the at least one monitored characteristic of the cell, control a charging rate or a discharging rate of the cell.
55. An electrochemical cell management method comprising:
 monitoring at least one characteristic of the cell indicating a loss of lithium in the cell; and
  based on the at least one monitored characteristic of the cell, controlling a charging rate or a discharging rate of the cell.

  wherein the at least one characteristic indicates a parasitic reaction between the lithium in the cell and at least one other material in the cell.
57. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 56,
  wherein the at least one other material in the cell comprises part of an electrolyte of the cell or part of a counter electrode of the cell.
58. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 54,
  wherein the cell comprises metallic lithium at at least one point during discharge of the cell.
59. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 54,
  wherein the loss of lithium in the cell comprises a loss of metallic lithium in the cell.
60. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 54,
  wherein the at least one monitored characteristic comprises at least one morphological characteristic of the cell.
61. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 60,
  wherein the at least one morphological characteristic of the cell comprises a value or change in at least one of:
   pressure,
  thickness,
  volume,
  deflection,
  conductivity,
  resistance, or
  temperature.

  wherein, for at least a portion of the discharge that covers a first state of charge range having breadth of at least 2% and at most 60%, an average discharging rate over the portion of the discharge is at least 2 times an average charging rate during at least a portion of the charge.
75. An electrochemical cell management method comprising:
 controlling an electrochemical cell such that the cell is discharged and then charged,
  wherein, for at least a portion of the discharge that covers a first state of charge range having breadth of at least 2% and at most 60%, the average discharging rate over the portion of the discharge is at least 2 times an average charging rate during at least a portion of the charge.
76. The electrochemical cell management system of claim 74,
  wherein the portion of the charge comprises a second state of charge range having breadth of at least 2% and at most 60%.

Title: Battery impedance measuring method, device, equipment and medium
Inventor:
GUO YI
CAO BIN
Abstract: The invention discloses a battery impedance measurement method and device, equipment and a medium, and the method comprises the steps: obtaining first working condition data of a battery in a use process, and the first working condition data is used for reflecting the working state of the battery; when the impedance of the battery is measured, a proper length range of a sampling time window is determined, and the sampling time window meeting the time length range is determined. And determining second working condition data corresponding to the sampling time window according to the obtained first working condition data. And judging whether the sampling time window meets a preset condition based on the second working condition data. If the sampling time window meets the preset condition, the impedance of the battery can be determined based on the second working condition data. According to the method for measuring the impedance of the battery, the impedance of the battery can be measured in an online application scene of the battery, a special current excitation mode does not need to be introduced, and the method is convenient for a user to use.

Title: Lithium battery fault identification method based on isolated forest algorithm
Parent Assignee: CHINESE ACADEMY OF SCIENCES, STATE GRID CORP
Assignee:
ELECTRIC POWER SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF STATE GRID ZHEJIANG ELECTRIC POWER 
GUANGZHOU INSTITUTE OF ENERGY CONVERSION - CHINESE ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
Inventor:
LIN DA
WANG XIANGJIN
DONG TI
LI ZHIHAO
GONG DIYANG
ZHANG LEIQI
Auspicious book
JIANG FANGMING
CHEN LINGYU
MA YUHAN
CHEN ZHE
Abstract: The invention belongs to the technical field of lithium battery management, and particularly relates to a lithium battery fault identification method based on an isolated forest algorithm. In order to overcome the defect that basic parameters of a fault battery are difficult to obtain in an existing lithium battery fault recognition method, the invention adopts the following technical scheme: the lithium battery fault recognition method based on the isolated forest algorithm comprises the following steps: acquiring basic operation data of a training set A and a training set B, the training set A comprises a healthy battery and an evolutionary fault battery obtained by performing external short circuit artificial simulation on the healthy battery, the training set B is a healthy battery, and the basic operation data comprises voltage U, temperature T and impedance Z; training the data set, generating an isolated tree, and forming an isolated forest; calculating an abnormal value to obtain a critical abnormal value score SC; and S4, analyzing and processing abnormal information. The method has the beneficial effects that the evolutionary fault battery is obtained through artificial simulation, so that the required basic data of the fault battery can be quickly and stably obtained.
