The battery module according to any one of claims 1 to 5, wherein the first impedance characteristic, the second impedance characteristic, the first reference impedance characteristic, and the second reference impedance characteristic are at least one of a resistance, a reactance, an absolute impedance value, and a phase angle.

Title: Method and device for testing impedance spectrum of battery
Parent Assignee: AQUILARIA SINENSIS POWER GRID LTD RESPONSIBILITY
Inventor:
HUANG QINGKENG
LIANG YONGCHANG
WANG CHUANXU
QIAN YUXI
Abstract: The invention discloses a battery impedance spectroscopy test method and device, and the method comprises the steps: making two same batteries, one is a test battery, and the other is a verification battery; charging the test battery and the verification battery to a first set SOC value at a first constant current, and then standing for a first set time; discharging the test battery and the verification battery to a second set SOC value at a second constant current, and then standing for a second set time; and discharging the test battery and the verification battery to a third set SOC value at the first set current, charging the test battery and the verification battery to a fourth set SOC value at the second set current, discharging the test battery and the verification battery to the third set SOC value at the first set current, charging the test battery and the verification battery to the fourth set SOC value at the second set current, and respectively testing impedance spectrums of the test battery and the verification battery in the charging and discharging process. The invention provides a test method and a test device for a battery impedance spectrum, which can improve the test precision of the impedance spectrum and verify the stability of the impedance spectrum.

Title: Battery diagnostic apparatus and method
Inventor: PARK, JUN CHEOL
Abstract: Disclosed in the present invention is a technology capable of diagnosing a battery with high accuracy by using a Nyquist plot. A battery diagnosis apparatus according to one aspect of the present invention comprises: an impedance measuring module configured to measure an impedance according to a change in frequency while applying an AC voltage to a target battery; a memory module that stores a frequency-specific impedance reference value; and a processor configured to generate a Nyquist plot for an impedance measurement value of the target battery measured by the impedance measurement module, extract an inflection point from the generated Nyquist plot, and diagnose the target battery by comparing a value within a predetermined frequency range on the basis of the extracted inflection point with the frequency-specific impedance reference value stored in the memory module.
Claims:
1. An impedance measuring module configured to measure impedance according to a change in frequency while applying an alternating voltage to a target battery;
 A memory module storing an impedance reference value per frequency; and
 Generate a Nyquist plot of the impedance measurement value of the target battery measured by the impedance measurement module, extract an inflection point from the generated Nyquist plot, and compare a value within a predetermined frequency range based on the extracted inflection point with an impedance reference value for each frequency stored in the memory module to diagnose the target battery.
 And a battery diagnostic device, wherein the battery diagnostic device comprises a battery.
2. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 Wherein the processor is configured to shift the generated Nyquist plot so that the extracted inflection point becomes an origin point, and compare the shifted Nyquist plot with the impedance reference value for each frequency.
3. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 Wherein the processor is configured to diagnose the target battery using a magnitude and an angle of an impedance measurement value of the target battery.
4. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 Wherein the memory module divides and stores the impedance reference value per frequency for each of a plurality of battery classes, and
 Wherein the processor is configured to classify the grade of the target battery by matching the impedance measurement value of the target battery with the battery grade stored in the memory module.
5. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 Wherein the processor is configured to extract a point where the charge transfer resistance region is inflected by a diffusion resistance region in the generated Nyquist plot as the inflection point.
6. The method of claim 5, further comprising:
 Wherein the processor is configured to extract the inflection point by searching for the generated Nyquist plot in a direction in which a frequency increases from a low frequency region.
7. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
 Wherein the memory module stores preliminary frequency information about the inflection point in advance.
8. A battery pack comprising the battery diagnostic device according to claim 1.
9. An energy storage system comprising the battery diagnostic device according to claim 1.
10. Storing an impedance reference value per frequency;
 Measuring impedance according to a change in frequency while applying an alternating voltage to a target battery;
 Generating a Nyquist plot of the impedance measurement value of the target battery measured at the measuring step;
 Extracting an inflection point in the Nyquist plot produced in the producing step;
 Comparing the impedance measurement value within a predetermined frequency range about the inflection point extracted in the extracting step with the impedance reference value per frequency stored in the storing step; and
 Diagnosing the target battery based on a result compared in the comparing step;
 A method of diagnosing a battery comprising the steps of:

Title: Battery detection method and device, electronic equipment and storage medium
Inventor:
JI HUANJI
MENG FANAO
CHEN WEIMING
Abstract: The embodiment of the invention relates to a battery detection method and device, electronic equipment and a storage medium, and the method comprises the steps: determining an impedance set of a battery in to-be-charged equipment based on a preset method after a detection confirmation message from the to-be-charged equipment is received; wherein the impedance set comprises a plurality of impedances; receiving battery information from the to-be-charged equipment, and determining a first health degree of a battery in the to-be-charged equipment according to the impedance set and the battery information; wherein the first health degree represents the health state of the battery; sending the first health degree to the to-be-charged equipment, so that the to-be-charged equipment updates the second health degree according to the first health degree; wherein the second health degree represents the health state of the battery, and the second health degree is determined by the to-be-charged equipment. Therefore, according to the embodiment of the invention, the accuracy of battery health state detection is improved, and the convenience and practicability of battery health state detection are improved.

Title: Battery impedance spectra measurement
Inventor:
BARSUKOV YEVGEN PAVLOVICH 
MAGEE DAVID PATRICK 
SESTOK IV CHARLES KASIMER
Abstract: From a current measurement circuit, digital samples are received of a current signal that flows through a battery cell within a measurement period. From a voltage measurement circuit, digital samples are received of a voltage signal across the battery cell within the measurement period. First voltage spectral components are generated based on performing a first transform operation on the digital samples of the voltage signal. A current spectrum is generated based on performing a second transform operation on the digital samples of the current signal. Second voltage spectral components are generated based on a first condition of the battery cell before the measurement period and a second condition of the battery cell after the measurement period. A voltage spectrum is including the first voltage spectrum and the second voltage spectrum is generated. An impedance spectrum of the battery cell is generated based on the voltage spectrum and the current spectrum.

Title: Battery management system for an electric air vehicle
Inventor:
KURTZ JOHANNES 
BRONSKI BARTLOMIEJ
Abstract: The present invention relates to a battery management system for an electric air vehicle such as an eVTOL aircraft for observing a battery system state and optionally a battery health state of an energy storage system of the air vehicle. Based on an observation result, a state prediction, in particular, a prediction of the remaining accessible energy, can be carried out during a flight according to a planned flight profile and a range of the flight is determined. Hence, it can be confirmed during the flight that the intended destination can be safely reached with the remaining accessible energy. Otherwise, an alert to an operator is issued. State observation according to the present invention is performed using a two-lane architecture, wherein vehicle management computers are integrated in each of two independent and dissimilar lanes each including battery cell measurement equipment and independently performing a state observation using dissimilar algorithms.
Claims:
1. A battery management system for an electric air vehicle, said battery management system being adapted for battery cell state monitoring and/or health parameter monitoring of a battery system forming an energy storage system of the air vehicle, said battery management system comprising
 two independent and dissimilar lanes for battery cell state and/or health parameter determination, each of said lanes including:
  battery cell measurement equipment for obtaining battery cell measurement data of each of a plurality of battery cells constituting the battery system;
  a vehicle management computer; and
  a digital bus connecting said vehicle management computer and said battery cell measurement equipment, wherein
  the vehicle management computers of the two lanes are independent from each other and adapted to calculate a battery cell state and/or at least one health parameter based on the battery cell measurement data obtained by the battery cell measurement equipment of the respective lane by using dissimilar algorithms, respectively, and
  said vehicle management computers are provided outside of and separately from the battery system forming the energy storage system.
2. The system according to claim 1, adapted for battery cell state monitoring, wherein said battery cell state includes at least one of a cell state of charge, a cell core temperature or a cell tab temperature.
3. The system according to claim 1 or 2, wherein said battery cell measurement data obtained by said battery cell measurement equipment includes at least one of cell terminal voltage, current and surface temperature.
4. The system according to any of claims 1 to 3, wherein, in each of said lanes, said battery cell measurement equipment is arranged in a master-slave architecture, wherein a battery measurement master unit aggregates battery cell measurement data obtained by a plurality of battery measurement slave units and forwards the aggregated battery cell measurement data via the respective digital bus to the respective vehicle management computer of the respective lane.
5. The system according to any of claims 1 to 4, adapted for health parameter monitoring, wherein health parameters include at least one of cell capacity and cell impedance.
6. The system according to any of claims 1 to 5, wherein the battery cell measurements performed by the battery cell measurement equipment of each of the independent lanes are dissimilar to each other.
7. The system according to any of claims 1 to 6, further comprising a flight control computer system adapted to receive battery cell state data and/or health data calculated by each of said vehicle management computers.
8. The system according to claim 7, wherein said flight control computer system comprising two independent computers and one dissimilar computer.
9. The system according to claim 7 or 8, wherein said flight control computer system being adapted to continually compare the respective data received from each of said vehicle management computers with each other.
10. The system according to claim 9, wherein an error is detected and an alert to an operator is issued if a deviation of data obtained from the vehicle management computers of the two lanes exceeds a predetermined threshold.
11. The system according to any of claims 1 to 10, wherein a cell with a minimum value of a battery cell state and/or health parameter is taken as a basis for an overall battery state and/or health assessment.
12. The system according to any of claims 1 to 11, wherein said air vehicle is an electric vertical take-off and landing aircraft, eVTOL.
13. The system according to any of claims 1 to 12, adapted for battery cell state monitoring, wherein the battery cell state determination by the two independent and dissimilar lanes is based on two out of
 a model based state-of-charge, SOC, estimation algorithm,
 an algorithm using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy, EIS, and
 a Coulomb Counting algorithm, wherein
 each of the two lanes uses a different one out of the above algorithms,
 in a lane using the model based SOC estimation algorithm, the battery cell measurement equipment is adapted to measure a current, a voltage and a temperature of each of the plurality of battery cells,
 in a lane using EIS, the battery cell measurement equipment is adapted to individually excite the battery cells with sinusoidal current of variable frequency and to measure a voltage response of each cell, and the vehicle management computer is adapted to calculate a complex system impedance based on a ratio between an input excitation current and a voltage response, and
 in a lane using the Coulomb Counting algorithm, the battery cell measurement equipment is adapted to determine the charging current for each individual cell of the plurality of battery cells during ground operation and to determine the overall load currents of each individual cell and the vehicle management computer is adapted to calculate a state-of charge based on the determined charging currents and overall load currents of each individual cell.
14. The system according to any of claims 1 to 13, adapted for health parameter monitoring, wherein the at least one health parameter is calculated by the two independent and dissimilar lanes based on two out of
 a model based cell parameter estimation algorithm,
 an algorithm using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy, EIS,
 a dedicated maintenance procedure and/or a dedicated charging procedure, and
 an empirical ageing model, wherein
 each of the two lanes uses a different one out of the above algorithms,
 in a lane using the model based cell parameter estimation algorithm, the maintenance procedure, dedicated charging procedure and/or or the empirical ageing model, the battery cell measurement equipment is adapted to measure a current, a voltage and a temperature of each of the plurality of battery cells, and
 in a lane using EIS, the battery cell measurement equipment is adapted to individually excite the battery cells with sinusoidal current of variable frequency and to measure a voltage response of each cell, and the vehicle management computer is adapted to calculate a complex system impedance based on a ratio between an input excitation current and a voltage response.
15. An air vehicle comprising a battery management system according to any of claims 1 to 14.

Title: Battery management system for an electric air vehicle
Inventor:
KURTZ JOHANNES 
SCHUHMANN MORITZ
Abstract: The present invention relates to a battery management system and method for performing a battery health parameter observation, in particular cell impedance observation, with two redundant, independent and dissimilar lanes. Specifically, a cell impedance observation in a first one of the lanes is based on Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy, EIS. The other lane employs a different algorithm than EIS. In embodiments, a battery state observation is further performed independently by the two lanes, wherein again the first lane employs EIS and the other lane a different (dissimilar) algorithm). On the basis of state and health observation, state (state of function) of the battery system can be predicted to determine a range of flight in accordance with a predetermined flight profile.
Claims:
1. A battery management system for an electric air vehicle, said battery management system being adapted to observe a current battery health of a battery system forming an energy storage system of the air vehicle, said battery management system comprising
 two redundant and dissimilar lanes for battery cell measurements, wherein
 a first lane of the two lanes comprises equipment for determining a cell impedance as a battery health parameter for each individual battery cell of a plurality of battery cells of the battery system by using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy, EIS, and
 a second lane of the two lanes comprises equipment for performing cell impedance determination using a different algorithm than EIS.
2. The system according to claim 1, further being adapted for battery state observation, wherein
 each of said lanes comprises equipment for performing a state-of charge, SOC, and/or a cell core temperature determination of each individual battery cell,
 the determination by the first lane is based on EIS, and
 the determination by the second lane is based on a different algorithm than EIS.
3. The system according to claim 1 or 2, wherein said second lane uses a model-based cell impedance estimation algorithm and optionally a model-based cell SOC and/or cell core temperature estimation algorithm.
4. The system according to claim 3, wherein said model-based algorithms used by the second lane are based on using a dual Kalman filter.
5. The system according to any of claims 1 to 4, wherein said second lane comprises equipment for measuring at least one of a current, a voltage and a temperature of each individual cell of the plurality of battery cells of the battery system.
6. The system according to any of claims 1 to 5, wherein said first lane comprising equipment for exciting battery cells of the battery system with sinusoidal current of variable frequency and equipment for measuring a voltage response of each cell.
7. The system according to claim 6, wherein said first lane further comprising processing circuitry for calculation of a system impedance spectrum based on a ratio between an input excitation current and a voltage response.
8. The system according to any of claims 1 to 7, wherein said air vehicle is an electric vertical take-off and landing aircraft, eVTOL.
9. An air vehicle comprising a system according to any of claims 1 to 8.
10. A battery management method of observing a current battery health of a battery system forming an energy storage system of an electric air vehicle, said battery management method comprising the steps of
 performing a determination of a cell impedance as a battery health parameter for each individual battery cell of a plurality of battery cells of the battery system by using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy, EIS, and
 independently determining the cell impedance for each individual battery cell of the plurality of battery cells as the battery health parameter based on a different algorithm than EIS.
11. The method according to claim 10, further observing a battery state of the battery system and comprising the steps of
 performing a state-of-charge, SOC, and/or a cell core temperature determination of each individual battery cell based on EIS, and
 independently determining the state-of-charge and/or the cell core temperature determination of each individual battery cell based on a different algorithm than EIS.
12. The method according to claim 10 or 11, wherein said different algorithm is a model-based cell impedance estimation algorithm, the method optionally determining the state-of-charge and/or the cell core temperature by a model-based cell SOC and/or cell core temperature estimation algorithm.
13. The method according to claim 12, wherein said model-based algorithms used by the second lane are based on using a dual Kalman filter.
14. The method according to claim 12 or 13, wherein model-based estimation comprises measuring at least one of a current, a voltage and a temperature of each individual cell of the plurality of battery cells of the battery system.
15. The method according to any of claims 10 to 14, wherein said EIS based determination comprising the steps of exciting battery cells of the battery system with sinusoidal current of variable frequency and measuring a voltage response of each cell.

Title: Battery management system, battery current detection method thereof and vehicle
Inventor:
TAO MENGFENG
CAO BAOJIAN
LU LIANJUN
WU BIN
CHEN YI
JIANG LONGCHAO
LI PENG
TANG SHANZHENG
Abstract: The invention discloses a battery management system, a battery current detection method thereof and a vehicle. The battery management system comprises an impedance acquisition module which is suitable for acquiring the impedance of a preset length section of a bus where a battery pack is located; the battery pack comprises a plurality of battery packs, and each battery pack comprises a plurality of single batteries; all single batteries in the battery pack are connected in series on a bus; the voltage detection module is suitable for detecting the voltage of the bus of the preset length section; and the current calculation module is suitable for taking the ratio of the voltage value of the bus of the preset length section to the impedance value of the bus of the preset length section as the current current value of the battery pack. By applying the scheme, the current detection result is not limited by the precision and the measuring range of the current sensor, and the user demand can be better met.
Claims:
1. A battery management system, comprising:
 the impedance obtaining module is suitable for obtaining the impedance of a preset length section of a bus where the battery pack is located; the battery pack comprises a plurality of battery packs, and each battery pack comprises a plurality of single batteries; all the single batteries in the battery pack are connected in series on the bus;
 the voltage detection module is suitable for detecting the voltage of the bus with the preset length section;
 and the current calculation module is suitable for taking the ratio of the voltage value of the bus of the preset length section to the impedance value of the bus of the preset length section as the current value of the battery pack.
2. The battery management system according to claim 1, wherein a product of an impedance value of the bus bar of the predetermined length and a maximum current value flowing through the bus bar is equal to or less than a maximum voltage value detectable by the voltage detection module.
3. The battery management system of claim 1, wherein the bus bar comprises: the positive bus bar is connected with the anode of the battery pack, and the negative bus bar is connected with the cathode of the battery pack.
4. The battery management system of claim 3, wherein the bus bar of the predetermined length segment is located on the negative bus bar.
5. The battery management system of claim 3, wherein the positive bus bar is provided with a first charge-discharge control module; a second charge and discharge control module is arranged on the negative bus; the first charge-discharge control module and the second charge-discharge control module are suitable for receiving the switch control signal output by the battery management system and controlling the battery pack to be charged or discharged.
6. The battery management system of claim 5, wherein the positive bus further comprises a pre-charge circuit coupled in parallel with the first charge-discharge control module.
7. The battery management system of claim 1, wherein the impedance of the bus bars of the predetermined length varies by less than a predetermined drift threshold at different temperatures.
8. A vehicle characterized by comprising the battery management system of any one of claims 1 to 7.
9. A battery current detection method of a battery management system is characterized by being used for detecting the current value of a battery pack; the battery pack comprises a plurality of battery packs, and each battery pack comprises a plurality of single batteries; all the single batteries in the battery pack are connected in series on the bus; the battery management system comprises a voltage detection module; the method comprises the following steps:
 the battery management system acquires the impedance of a preset length section of a bus where the battery pack is located;
 the voltage detection module of the battery management system detects the voltage of the bus of the preset length section;
 and the battery management system takes the ratio of the voltage value of the bus of the preset length section to the impedance value of the bus of the preset length section as the current value of the battery pack.
10. The battery current detection method of a battery management system according to claim 9, wherein a product of the impedance value of the bus bar of the predetermined length section and the maximum current value flowing on the bus bar is equal to or less than a maximum voltage value detectable by the micro-voltage detection module.

Title: Method and device for predicting state of health and remaining lifetime for used electric vehicle batteries
Inventor: BURCHARDT TRYGVE
Abstract: Understanding a health status and expected remaining lifetime of an EV (electric vehicle) battery is important before repurposing the battery for second life applications. A device for connecting to an unopened EV battery pack via operable coupling to signal and power wiring is disclosed. The device enables access to diagnostic information from the unopened EV battery. The device measures cell and/or module voltages and currents within the battery pack for several different depths of discharge. A self-learning algorithm implemented by the diagnostic device, which uses historical data and diagnostic information from the battery pack, determines a condition of the battery and provide recommended operational conditions for future use of the battery. For example, a degradation slope and expected capacity loss over time can be determined based on measured variations of cell and/or modular voltages and subsequently used, with cell impedance data, to recommend an operational C-rate for the battery pack.

Title: Method for avoiding a collision during the measurement of loop impedance by several subscribers
Inventor:
PFIZENMAIER TIM 
MAYER FLORIAN
Abstract: A method is provided for collision-free determination of a loop impedance during charging of an electric vehicle connected to a charging point, comprising: Performing a test measurement on the loop impedance-determining circuit to detect an extraneous test signal having a first frequency (S1); injecting a test signal having a frequency into the loop impedance-determining circuit, wherein the frequency of the test signal corresponds to a first frequency (S2) if no extraneous test signal with the first frequency has been detected during the test measurement, and otherwise corresponds to a second frequency different from the first frequency (S3), if an external test signal having the first frequency has been detected in the test measurement; and determining the loop impedance on the basis of a detection of the fed-in test signal (S4). The invention also relates to a corresponding device for collision-free determination of a loop impedance.
Claims:
1. A method for collisionally determining a loop impedance during charging of an electric vehicle connected to a charging point, comprising the steps of: Performing a test measurement on the loop impedance-determining circuit to detect an extraneous test signal having a first frequency (S1); injecting a test signal having a frequency into the loop impedance-determining circuit, wherein the frequency of the test signal corresponds to the first frequency (S2) if no extraneous test signal with the first frequency has been detected during the test measurement, and otherwise corresponds to a second frequency different from the first frequency (S3), if an external test signal having the first frequency has been detected in the test measurement; and determining the loop impedance on the basis of a detection of the fed-in test signal (S4).
2. Method according to claim 1, wherein the second frequency differs from the first frequency by at least 3 Hz, preferably by 5 Hz.
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, further comprising: performing a test measurement to detect a foreign test signal at the second frequency; and changing the second frequency to a third frequency prior to injecting the test signal if a foreign test signal at the second frequency has been detected in the test measurement.
4. Method according to one of Claims 1 to 3, wherein the test measurement for detecting an external test signal is carried out repeatedly at the current frequency of the external test signal fed in at a predetermined time interval.
5. Method according to one of Claims 1 to 4, wherein the test measurement for detecting an external test signal is carried out at the current frequency of the fed-in test signal if the value of the determined loop impedance is implausible.
6. Method according to one of Claims 1 to 5, wherein the signal tapped off for carrying out the test measurement on the circuit determining the loop impedance in order to detect an external test signal is filtered by means of a bandpass filter, wherein the bandpass filter has a centre frequency which is in the range of the first frequency.
7. The method according to any one of claims 1 to 6, further comprising: varying the frequency of the injected test signal, preferably periodically, during its injection.
8. Method according to one of Claims 1 to 7, further comprising: opening contactors which are arranged in the charging line between the electric vehicle and the charging point if the determined loop impedance value exceeds a predetermined limit value.
9. A device for collision-free determination of a loop impedance, comprising: test inputs, by means of which the device is able to measure the loop impedance at its coupling point to the power network; a test signal generator, generate a test signal having a frequency and inject it into the power grid via the test inputs; and a control circuit coupled to the test signal generator and configured to control operation of the apparatus according to the method of any one of claims 1 to 8.

Title: System and method for diagnosing battery
Inventor:
KIM WOO SUNG 
BAEK KI SEUNG 
LEE SUNG IL
Abstract: The present disclosure relates to a battery diagnosis system including a processor configured to: receive high-voltage battery information of a parked car; measure impedance of a battery through the received battery information; and determine, based on a comparison between a normal battery impedance and an abnormal battery impedance, that a battery having an abnormal battery impedance is an abnormal battery.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A battery diagnosis system comprising a processor configured to:
 receive battery information of a car that is parked;
  measure impedance of a battery through the received battery information; and
 determine, based on a comparison between a normal battery impedance and an abnormal battery impedance, that a battery having the abnormal battery impedance is an abnormal battery.
2. The system of claim 1, wherein the battery information of the car, which is received by the processor, comprises current and voltage flowing in a battery, and temperature information of the battery.
3. The system of claim 1, wherein the processor is configured to measure the impedance of the battery through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.
4. The system of claim 3, wherein the processor is configured to measure the impedance of the battery for each frequency band.
5. The system of claim 1, wherein the processor is further configured to diagnose the battery determined as the abnormal battery malfunctions, and display the malfunction-diagnosed battery through a display of the car.
6. The system of claim 1, further comprising a transfer device configured to transfer normal battery and abnormal battery information when the processor determines that the battery is the abnormal battery.
7. The system of claim 1, wherein the processor is configured to:
  measure a deterioration degree of the battery by measuring the impedance of the battery to, and
 determine, based on the measured battery deterioration degree, that the battery having an abnormal battery deterioration degree is the abnormal battery.
8. The system of claim 1, wherein the battery comprises multiple cells,
  the processor is configured to measure impedance of each of the battery cells, and determine, based on a comparison between a normal battery cell impedance and an abnormal battery cell impedance, that a battery cell having the abnormal battery cell impedance is an abnormal battery cell.
9. A battery diagnosis method comprising steps of:
 receiving battery information of a car that is parked;
  measuring impedance of a battery through the received battery information; and
 determining, based on a comparison between a normal battery impedance and an abnormal battery impedance, that a battery having the abnormal battery impedance is an abnormal battery.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein, in the step of receiving battery information, the battery information comprises current and voltage flowing in a battery, and temperature information of the battery.
11. The method of claim 9, wherein the step of measuring impedance of a battery comprises measuring the impedance of the battery through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.
12. The method of claim 10, wherein the step of measuring impedance of a battery comprises measuring the impedance of the battery for each frequency band.
13. The method of claim 9, further comprising steps of, after the step of determining that a battery having the abnormal battery impedance is an abnormal battery, diagnosing that the battery determined as the abnormal battery malfunctions, and displaying the malfunction-diagnosed battery through a display of the car.
14. The method of claim 9, further comprising, after the step of determining that a battery having the abnormal battery impedance is an abnormal battery, transferring normal battery and abnormal battery information.

Title: Battery Management system based on Cell Charge up Current
Inventor: LEE, JONG-HYUN
Abstract: The present invention relates to a battery management system based on a charge current for controlling charge and discharge to make charge/discharge voltages of a plurality of charge cells uniform when charging the charge cells connected in parallel constituting a battery. According to the present invention, the battery management system utilizes: a battery state of charge (SOC) measurement algorithm including a charge/discharge current measurement algorithm for cells, a charge quantity comparison algorithm for cells, and a voltage and charge quantity measurement algorithm for cells; a battery state of health (SOH) measurement algorithm including an impedance measurement system for cells, an aging measurement algorithm for cells, and a temperature measurement algorithm for cells; and a battery pack monitoring algorithm including a voltage and current comparison/measurement algorithm for cells, and a voltage and current comparison/measurement algorithm for a battery pack. It is possible to improve a battery charge/discharge difference from 5-10% to 3-5% through active battery management based on a cell charge current, thus resulting in a longer battery life and stabilization of a system with such a battery. These enable a high volume of an energy storage system.
Claims:
1. A balancing controller is provided for controlling the operation of the FET composed of p MOSFET and N MOSFET serving as control switch; and a balancing performance part composed of one bidirectional flyback Transformer is connected to the inner winding of the primary coil and the secondary coil. One end of the balancing performing unit is connected between the battery cell BT1-BT2, and the other end is connected between the battery cell BT3-BT4, and the other end of the balancing performing unit is connected between the p MOSFET and N MOSFET Q2-Q1, The other end is provided with a monitoring unit for transmitting to a balancing control unit by monitoring the current and voltage of each battery cell, and provided and connected to the p MOSFET and N MOSFET Q4-Q3; The battery discharge circuit is composed of p MOSFET and high-density low-resistance, and is used for discharging battery by middle flashing manner in order to increase battery balancing effect, and two control switches are simultaneously controlled by one control signal because p MOSFET and N MOSFET. The balancing control unit includes a charging, discharge current measuring algorithm of the battery cell; A battery charging state (SOC) measurement algorithm including a charge amount comparison algorithm of the battery cell, a voltage of the battery cell, a charge amount measurement algorithm, an impedance measurement algorithm of the battery cell; A battery life (SOH, State of Health) measurement algorithm including temperature measurement algorithm of the battery cell and aging measurement algorithm of the battery cell; a voltage of the battery pack (PACK), current comparison measurement algorithm and voltage of the battery cell; And a battery pack monitoring algorithm including a current comparison measurement algorithm for measuring the battery charging status based on the charge current amount of the battery cell, measuring the battery life, and managing the battery in an active manner through the battery pack monitoring.
2. The system of claim 1, wherein the charge-based battery management system measures the overall voltage and current of the battery after initialization, then measures the voltage and current of each battery cell; then measures the maximum charge, minimum charge, average charge, and then measures the maximum charge, minimum charge, average charge of the battery cell of odd number a; and Then, the battery cell required for balancing is selected by determining the minimum charge amount compared to the average charge amount and maximum charge amount in the charge amount of each battery cell, and then performing the balancing by selecting the maximum charge amount and the minimum charge amount continuously by comparing the average charge amount after performing the balancing of the selected battery cell.
3. The battery management system of claim 2, wherein the charging current-based battery management system measures the internal impedance changes of each battery cell to measure the life of the battery cell; And measuring overall temperature affected by external environment and heat generated by internal impedance during charging/discharging of the battery cell by using the NTC device changing resistance value depending on the temperature.

Title: SOC (State Of Charge) estimation method for lithium battery based on electrochemical impedance model and system
Inventor:
CHEN NING
ZHANG PENG
DAI JIAYANG
GUI WEIHUA
YANG CHUNHUA
WANG JIEXI
GUO YUQIAN
CHEN JIAYAO
Abstract: The invention discloses an SOC (State Of Charge) estimation method for a lithium battery based on an electrochemical impedance model and a system. According to the invention, an equivalent circuit model based on electrochemical impedance is constructed through a fractional order theory in allusion to an SOC estimation problem of the lithium battery, CPE is introduced based on the analysis of an electrochemical impedance spectrum, a pure capacitance element in the traditional time domain circuit model is replaced, the polarization resistance in the model is replaced by a Butler-Volmer equationin consideration of the large current and temperature change range in the actual operation process of the electric vehicle, a fractional order observer for estimating the SOC of the lithium ion battery is designed for the established battery electrochemical impedance circuit model, and finally model parameters are identified by using battery characteristic test data to accurate estimate the SOC ofthe battery. Compared with the prior art, the SOC estimation method for the lithium battery based on the electrochemical impedance model and the system take the temperature factor into consideration,so that the measured battery SOC value is more accurate.

Title: Lithium ion battery fault detection method and system based on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test
Inventor:
YANG SHICHUN
ZHOU XINAN
ZHOU SIDA
LIU MINGYAN
LIU XINHUA
YAN XIAOYU
CHEN FEI
CAO YAOGUANG
Abstract: The invention relates to a lithium ion battery fault detection method and system based on an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test, and the method comprises an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test step, an impedance spectroscopy analysis step based on deep learning, and a fault detection step. The electrochemical impedance spectrum is trained by using a deep learning image recognition algorithm or a fault detection algorithm, the real-time measured impedance spectrum is analyzed through the trained model, and the abnormal condition and the abnormal type of the impedance spectrum of the lithium ion battery are identified, so that the nondestructive detection of the lithium ion battery is realized, and the effectiveness and the reliability of the detection are guaranteed.

Title: Lithium ion battery life detection method and system based on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test
Inventor:
YANG SHICHUN
ZHOU SIDA
LU YU
ZHOU XINAN
YAN XIAOYU
LIU XINHUA
CHEN FEI
CAO YAOGUANG
Abstract: The invention relates to a lithium ion battery life detection method and system based on an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test, and the method comprises an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test step, an impedance spectroscopy learning and analysis step based on a neural network, and a life detection step. The electrochemical impedance spectrum is trained through a deep learning image recognition algorithm or a prediction algorithm, the trained model analyzes the real-time measured impedance spectrum, the SOH state of the lithium ion battery impedance spectrum is identified, nondestructive detection of the lithium ion battery is achieved, and the effectiveness and reliability of detection are guaranteed.

Title: Battery status parameter estimation of battery cells, modules or packs in a reconfigurable battery system or modular energy storage direct converter system
Inventor:
KUDER MANUEL 
KERSTEN ANTON
Abstract: Disclosed herein are energy storage systems comprising cascaded energy storages, at least some of which being formed by battery cells or battery packs, and a switching arrangement allowing for establishing selected connection states of said energy storages. Control systems and methods allowing for determining a status parameter of individual energy storages in said energy storage systems are likewise disclosed. In one embodiment, the status parameter is determined based on a current flow into or out of a given energy storage when the given energy storage is connected in parallel with another energy storage. In another embodiment, the status parameter is determined using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, wherein part of the energy storage system and part of an electrical consumer are used for generating an AC current injected into a given energy storage.
Claims:
1. An energy storage system (20) comprising
 a branch comprising a plurality of cascaded energy storages (16), at least some of said energy storages (16) being formed by a battery cell or a battery pack comprising a plurality of battery cells,
 a voltage sensor associated with at least some of said energy storages (16) for determining its voltage,
 a switching arrangement comprising a plurality of switches (18),
 a control system, and
 at least one current meter (31),
 wherein said plurality of switches (18) of said switching arrangement are operable, under control of the control system, such as to establish a selectable connection state for each of said energy storages (16), said connection states being selectable from a series connection with an adjacent energy storage,
 a parallel connection with an adjacent energy storage, and
 a bypass state,
 wherein said control system is configured to select and establish said connection states based on at least one of a total voltage to be generated across the branch, the current voltage and/or state of charge of an individual energy storage (16) and a status parameter of said individual energy storage (16), in particular a power capability, a temperature and/or a state of health,
 wherein said control system is further configured to operate said switching arrangement to carry out an estimation of a status parameter of a given energy storage (16) by connecting said given energy storage (16) and a further energy storage (16) in parallel, to thereby cause a current flow into or out of said given energy storage (16), measuring said current flow and the voltage of said given energy storage (16) using said at least one current meter (31) and the voltage sensor associated with said given energy storage (16), and determining said status parameter based on a time-dependent voltage-current-characteristic.
2. The system (20) of claim 1, wherein said branch comprises a plurality of sequentially interconnected modules (10), wherein each module (10) comprises at least two first terminals (12) and at least two second terminals (14), a corresponding one of said energy storages (16), and a plurality of module switches (18), wherein said module switches (18) of said plurality of modules (10) form said switching arrangement, wherein in each two adjacent modules (10), each of the at least two first terminals (12) of one module (10) is connected either directly or via an intermediate component to a corresponding one of said at least two second terminals (14) of the other module (10).
3. The system (20) of claim 1 or 2, said system (20) comprising one or more modular energy storage direct converter systems (MESDCS) (28), wherein each MESDCS (28) comprises a converter arm having a first end (30) and a second end (32) and comprising a branch of sequentially interconnected modules (10), wherein said control system is configured for controlling the switches (18) of the sequentially interconnected modules (10) such as to establish, for each of said modules (10), connection states selected from
  - said series connection with an adjacent energy storage (16),

 such as to provide said phase voltage to said phase terminal (26) of said electrical consumer (24),

 wherein said control system is configured for controlling the switches (18) of the sequentially interconnected modules (10) such as to additionally selectively establish, for each of said modules (10), a parallel connection state, in which said energy storage (16) is connected in parallel with the energy storage (16) of an adjacent module (10), or

11. The system (20) of one of claims 7 to 10, wherein said estimation of said status parameter of a given energy storage (16) using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) comprises injecting oscillating, in particular sinusoidal currents of various frequencies to said given energy storage (16), wherein preferably, the control system comprises a PR controller for controlling the generation of the oscillating current, wherein said estimation preferably further comprises determining a frequency-dependent impedance based, at least in part, on a relation of the injected current, the monitored voltage of said given energy storage (16) and a phase shift between said injected current and said monitored voltage for each of said various frequencies, and/or

 wherein said equivalent circuit model preferably comprises a series connection of a model resistance Ro and a number of N model RC elements, wherein the i-th model RC element comprises a parallel connection of a resistance Ri and a capacitance Ci, with i = 1, ...,N, wherein preferably, N= 2, or N= 3, or N= 4, wherein preferably, said series connection further comprises a model inductance, and/or
 wherein said control system uses the status parameter of a given energy storage (16) when selecting the connection states for this given energy storage (16) in the operation of the energy storage system (20), and/or
 wherein a current meter (31) is associated with each phase terminal (26) of said electrical consumer (24).
12. A method of estimating a status parameter of a given energy storage (16) in an energy storage system (20), wherein said energy storage system (20) comprises a branch comprising a plurality of cascaded energy storages (16), at least some of said energy storages (16) being formed by a battery cell or a battery pack comprising a plurality of battery cells and a switching arrangement comprising a plurality of switches (18), wherein said plurality of switches (18) of said switching arrangement are operable such as to establish a selectable connection state for each of said energy storages (16), said connection states being selectable from

  - a bypass state,
 wherein said method comprises a step of carrying out an estimation of a status parameter of a given energy storage (16) by operating said switching arrangement such as to connect said given energy storage (16) and a further energy storage (16) in parallel, to thereby cause a current flow into or out of said given energy storage (16), measuring said current flow and a voltage of said given energy storage, and determining said status parameter based on a time-dependent voltage-current-characteristic.
13. The method of claim 12, wherein said status parameter is one of a power capability, a temperature and/or a state of health of said individual energy storage (16),
 wherein said method preferably further comprises selecting and establishing connection states in operation of said energy storage system (20) such as to generate a predetermined voltage across the branch, wherein said selecting of connection states is based, at least in part, on the status parameter of said energy storages (16), and/or
 wherein said energy storage system (20) is an energy storage system (20) according to one of claims 1 to 6, and wherein said method is carried out under control of the control system thereof, and/or
 wherein in said step of connecting said given energy storage (16) and a further energy storage (16) in parallel, at least one intermediate energy storage (16) is arranged between said given energy storage (16) and said further energy storage (16), and wherein the method further comprises a step of operating said switching arrangement such as to establish said bypass state for said at least one intermediate energy storage (16), and/or
 wherein said status parameter is determined based on an equivalent circuit model of the energy storage (16), said equivalent circuit model representing the impedance of said energy storage (16) and comprising at least one model resistance and at least one model capacitance, wherein said method comprises determining said model resistance(s) and capacitance(s) to match said time-dependent voltage-current characteristic, and wherein said model resistance(s) and capacitance(s) represent said status parameter or are used for deriving the status parameter therefrom,
 wherein preferably said equivalent circuit model comprises a series connection of a model resistance Ro and a number of N model RC elements, wherein the i-th model RC element comprises a parallel connection of a resistance Ri and a capacitance Ci, with i = 1, ...,N, wherein preferably, N=3, or N=2, or N= 1, wherein preferably, said series connection further comprises a model inductance.
14. A method of estimating a status parameter of a given energy storage (16) in an arrangement comprising an energy storage system (20) and an electrical consumer (24), in particular electric motor, wherein said electrical consumer (24) has a number of M phase terminals (26) for receiving a corresponding AC phase voltage,
 wherein said energy storage system (20) comprises M branches, wherein the i-th branch is associated with a corresponding i-th phase terminal (26) of said electrical consumer (24), with i = 1,..., M,

 wherein said plurality of switches (18) of said switching arrangement are operable such as to establish a selectable connection state for each of said energy storages (16), said connection states being selectable from

 a bypass state,
 wherein said method further comprises a step of carrying out an estimation of a status parameter of a given energy storage (16) located in the i-th branch using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), by operating said switching arrangement such as to inject AC current into said given energy storage (16) while monitoring a time-varying voltage of said energy storage, and deriving said status parameter from the injected current and the monitored voltage,
 wherein said injected current is generated using energy storages of a j-th branch and transmitted through said j-th and said i-th phase terminal of said consumer (24), wherein i, j = 1,... ,M and i?j.

 wherein said method preferably further comprises selecting and establishing connection states in operation of said energy storage system (20) such as to generate a predetermined voltage across each branch, wherein said selecting of connection states is based, at least in part, on the status parameter of said energy storages (16), and/or
 wherein said energy storage system (20) is an energy storage system (20) according to one of claims 7 to 11, and wherein said method is carried out under control of the control system thereof, and/or
 wherein said step of estimating said status parameter of a given energy storage (16) using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy comprises injecting oscillating, in particular sinusoidal currents of various frequencies to said given energy storage (16), wherein preferably a PR controller is used for generating said oscillating currents, and wherein said method preferably further comprises determining a frequency-dependent impedance based, at least in part, on a relation of the injected current, the monitored voltage of said given energy storage (16) and a phase shift between said injected current and said monitored voltage for each of said various frequencies, and/or
