Title: Method for detecting damage mechanisms and/or faults in an electrochemical energy store of a vehicle electrical system
Inventor:
NAUMANN ROLF 
RTTINGER CHRISTIAN
Abstract: The invention relates to a method for detecting damage mechanisms and/or faults in an electronic energy store (2), in particular in a lead-acid battery or a lithium-ion battery, from a vehicle electrical system (1), in that the reaction of the electronic energy store (2) to AC components which are superimposed on a DC current as passive AC disturbances or actively impressed AC excitations in the battery circuit, is determined by measuring current values (5) and voltage values (6) and the impedance of the energy store (2) is calculated therefrom, wherein band-pass-limited frequency windows are determined, and frequency-range-specific impedances are calculated, analysed and evaluated by means of a profile evaluation and/or deviation evaluation.
Claims:
1. Method for detecting damage mechanisms and/or faults in an electrochemical energy store (2), in particular in a lead battery or a lithium ion battery, of a vehicle electrical system (1), in that the reaction of the electrochemical energy store (2) to alternating current components which are superimposed on a direct current as passive alternating current disturbances or actively impressed alternating current excitations in the battery circuit, is determined by measuring current values (5) and voltage values (6) and the impedance of the energy store (2) is calculated therefrom, wherein one or more frequency ranges are selected and determined as band-pass-limited frequency windows from the excitation frequencies of the AC components by band-pass filtering, and current values and voltage values assigned to the specific frequency ranges are measured and frequency-range-specific impedances are calculated, are analysed and evaluated in such a way that, in the case of a profile evaluation, the temporal profile of the frequency-range-specific impedances within a fixed time window is recorded as a measurement window time, in that threshold values assigned to specific determined impedances are defined for the frequency domain, and in that an error signal is generated if a threshold value is exceeded in one or more frequency domains within the measurement window time, and/or in that a continuous comparison of the currently calculated frequency-range-specific impedances with impedance values stored in a characteristic diagram is carried out as reference impedances in the event of a deviation evaluation, for the currently frequency-specifically determined impedances, and in that an error signal (15) is generated if a threshold value is exceeded in one or more frequency ranges.
2. The method of claim 1, characterized in thatIn that a profile evaluation is carried out in a measurement time window in which no change, relevant to the evaluation, in the energy store operating point determined by the temperature and the state of charge of the energy store (2) occurs, wherein, for this purpose, in such a way that such a relevant change does not occur and/or the temperature and the state of charge are measured, and no course evaluation of impedances takes place in the case of relevant operating point changes detected by means of threshold values.
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, characterized in thatIn that, in the case of a course evaluation of impedances, the impedance values are stored in a ring buffer during the measurement and evaluation time.
4. The method of claim 1, characterized in thatIn that the reference impedance values stored in a characteristic diagram for a deviation evaluation are measured in advance as good impedance values for a current energy store (2) or type-specific for an energy store type under disturbance-free operating conditions and are stored in advance in the characteristic diagram.
5. The method of claim 1 or 4, characterized in thatIn such a way that a deviation evaluation is carried out virtually continuously at defined, successive comparison times.
6. The method of any one of claims 1 to 5, characterized in thatIn that the electronic energy store (2) is based on an impedance model or equivalent circuit diagram and the impedances calculated in each case in a type-specific manner are supplied to the equivalent circuit diagram parameters as ohmic components (11; 13)Or capacitive components (14) or inductive components and these components are monitored in conjunction with the calculated impedances for exceeding threshold values, wherein an error signal (15) is generated when one or more of these components exceed a threshold value.
7. The method of any one of claims 1 to 6, characterized in thatIn that a vehicle operating state is detected as driving mode or stationary mode or charging mode for the energy store (2) and alternating current disturbances which occur operationally there in the vehicle electrical system (1) are assigned to the individual operating modes, as continuously or sporadically occurring Ripples, and/or in that alternating current disturbances with known frequencies are continuously impressed on the vehicle electrical system (1) by means of a generator unit.
8. The method of any one of claims 1 to 7, characterized in thatIn that an evaluation is carried out with the profile evaluation and/or with the deviation evaluation for AC disturbances which are detected by measurement technology or are assigned to vehicle operating states and occur continuously, and in that, in the case of AC disturbances which occur sporadically, an evaluation is carried out only with the deviation evaluation.
9. The method of any one of claims 1 to 8, characterized in thatIn that, in the case of an electrochemical energy store (2) as a lead-acid battery, the impedance of the energy store (2) is measured and calculated in a band-pass-limited window of 0.05 kHz to 0.3 kHz, preferably of 0.1 kHz to 0.2 kHz, in order to detect a complete break in a conductive connection in the battery, wherein passive alternating current disturbances occur continuously in this frequency window both in the driving mode and in the charging mode, and in that a threshold value of 100% to 300%, preferably of 200%, for a rise in comparison with a reference impedance and a threshold value for a sudden rise in the course within 1 sec to 3 sec, preferably within 2 sec, is defined.
10. The method of any one of claims 1 to 8, characterized in thatIn that, in the case of an electrochemical energy store (2) as a lead-acid battery for detecting a relevant power loss in a band-pass-limited window of 0.05 kHz to 3 kHz, preferably of 0.1 kHz to 1 kHz, the impedance of the energy store (2) is measured and calculated, wherein passive alternating current disturbances are permanently present and evaluable in this frequency window as excitations in driving operation, but are only partially present in charging operation, characterized in that an evaluation is carried out with the profile evaluation and/or with the deviation evaluation in the driving mode and only with the deviation evaluation in the charging mode, and in that a threshold value of 100% to 200%, preferably of 150%, for a rise in comparison with a reference impedance or a threshold value for a sudden rise in the course within 1 sec to 3 sec, preferably within 2 sec.
11. The method of any one of claims 1 to 8, characterized in thatIn the case of an electrochemical energy store (2) as a lithium-ion battery for detecting a break in individual arrester foils from a current collector in a window bounded by a strip bass of 0.05 kHz to 3 kHz, preferably 0.1 kHz to 1 kHz, the impedance of the energy store is measured and calculated, wherein passive alternating current disturbances are permanently present and evaluable as excitations in driving operation, but are only partially present in charging operation, characterized in that an evaluation is carried out with the profile evaluation and/or with the deviation evaluation in the driving mode and only with the deviation evaluation in the charging mode, in that a threshold value of 80% to 140%, preferably of 110% in comparison with a reference impedance, or a threshold value for a sudden increase in profile within 1 sec to 3 sec, preferably within 2 sec, and in that a threshold value of 100% to 200%, preferably of 150%, in comparison with a reference impedance is determined for the charging mode.
12. The method of any one of claims 1 to 8, characterized in thatIn the case of an electrochemical energy store (2) as a lithium-ion battery for detecting a lithium deposit on an anode by means of high current densities in a band-pass-limited window of 0.05 Hz to 20 Hz, preferably 0.1 Hz to 10 Hz, the impedance of the energy store is measured and calculated, wherein passive alternating current disturbances are permanently present and evaluable as excitations in the charging mode, but are not safely present in the driving mode, characterized in that in the charging mode an evaluation is carried out with the profile evaluation and with the deviation evaluation, whereas in the driving mode only with the deviation evaluation, in that for the charging mode a threshold value of 80% to 160%, preferably of 120% in comparison with a reference impedance without a sudden increase within 7 sec to 13 sec, preferably 10 sec, and in that a threshold value of 100% to 160%, preferably 130%, in comparison with a reference impedance is established for driving operation.

Title: Battery pack simulation apparatus and method of checking battery management unit by using same
Inventor: YI YEON OK
Abstract: A battery pack simulation device according to an embodiment of the present invention includes an input unit that receives voltage values, current values, temperature, and initial impedance values, an output value generation unit that generates an output value based on the input voltage value, current value, temperature, and initial impedance value, an output unit that transmits the generated output value to the battery management unit, and a monitoring unit that monitors the operation of the battery management unit.
Claims:
1. A battery pack simulation device connected to a battery management unit to check a function of the battery management unit, the device comprising:
  an input unit configured to receive initial data of a virtual battery pack including a voltage value, a current value, and an initial impedance value;
  an output value generation unit configured to generate virtual battery pack measurement data including an impedance value and a voltage value varying with respect to a virtual battery based on the received voltage value, current value, and initial impedance value;
  an output unit configured to transmit at least a part of the generated virtual battery pack measurement data to the battery management unit; and
  a monitoring unit configured to receive predetermined information related to the function from the battery management unit and monitor whether the battery management unit operates normally based on the predetermined information.
2. The device of claim 1, wherein the output value generation unit comprises:
 an impedance value variation unit configured to output a variable impedance value obtained by changing the received initial impedance value by a predetermined value at a predetermined time interval; and
  a voltage value recalculation unit configured to recalculate a voltage value based on the input current value and the variable impedance value.
3. The device of claim 2, wherein the virtual battery pack measurement data comprises the recalculated voltage value and the inputted current value as a virtual measurement voltage value and a virtual measurement current value, respectively,
 wherein the monitoring unit receives a calculation impedance value calculated by the battery management unit based on the virtual measurement voltage value and the virtual measurement current value.
4. The device of claim 3, wherein the monitoring unit further comprises a comparison unit for comparing the variable impedance value and the calculation impedance value.
5. The device of claim 2, wherein the monitoring unit receives a battery control signal generated by the battery management unit from the virtual measurement voltage value and the virtual measurement current value.
6. The device of claim 5, wherein the monitoring unit further comprises:
  a protection condition determination unit configured to determine whether a battery protection condition is satisfied from the virtual battery pack measurement data and generate a battery protection required signal; and
  a comparison unit configured to compare the battery control signal received from the battery management unit with the battery protection required signal.
7. The device of claim 4 or 6, wherein a normal or abnormal operation signal of the battery management unit is outputted according to a comparison result of the comparison unit.
8. A method of checking a function of a battery management unit using a battery pack simulation device, the method comprising:
  a battery pack data input step of inputting battery pack data including voltage, current, temperature, and initial impedance value of a battery pack into the battery pack simulation device;
  an output value generation step of generating virtual battery pack measurement data based on the battery pack data inputted into the battery pack simulation device;
  an output value transmission step of transmitting the generated output value from the battery pack simulation device to the battery management unit; and
  a monitoring step of monitoring whether the battery management unit is operating normally in the battery pack simulation device.
9. The method of claim 8, wherein the output value generation step comprises:
 an impedance value variation step of generating a virtual impedance value by changing the received initial impedance value by a predetermined value at a predetermined time interval; and
  a voltage value recalculation step of calculating a virtual battery pack measurement voltage by recalculating a voltage value based on the received current value of the battery pack data and the virtual impedance value.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein as the battery simulation device monitors the operation of the battery management unit,
 the monitoring step outputs a normal signal when the battery management unit normally performs a battery pack protection operation, and outputs an error signal when the battery management unit does not normally perform the battery pack protection operation.
11. The method of claim 9, wherein the monitoring step comprises:
  a step of, by the battery pack simulation device, receiving a calculation impedance value calculated by the battery management unit from the virtual battery measurement voltage; and
  an impedance calculation function monitoring step of comparing the virtual impedance value corresponding to the virtual battery measurement voltage with the calculation impedance value to determine whether an impedance calculation function of the battery management unit operations normally.
12. The method of claim 9, wherein the monitoring step comprises:
 by the battery pack simulation device,
  a protection function execution condition determination procedure for determining whether an execution condition of a battery protection function including at least one among overcharge/overdischarge control or overvoltage/overcurrent control functions is satisfied from the virtual battery pack measurement data;
  a battery protection control signal receiving procedure for receiving a protection control signal for at least one control among the overcharge/overdischarge control or overvoltage/overcurrent control functions generated by the battery management unit from the virtual battery pack measurement data; and
  a determination procedure of determining whether the battery protection function of the battery management unit normally operates based on whether the protection control signal is normally received when a protection function execution condition is satisfied.

Title: Method and apparatus for measuring impedance of battery cell on-line
Parent Assignee: UNIVERSITY OF ULSAN INDUSTRY ACADEMIC COOPERATION FOUNDATION
Assignee: UNIVERSITY OF ULSAN INDUSTRY ACADEMIC COOPERATION FOUNDATION
Inventor:
CHOI, SUNG JIN
La Phuong Ha
Abstract: An apparatus and method for measuring impedance of a battery cell in real time are provided. An apparatus for measuring impedance of a battery cell includes a plurality of battery cells connected in series, a balancing circuit equalizing states of the plurality of battery cells, an impedance measuring circuit connected to the equalizing circuit, and a battery management system controlling the balancing circuit and the impedance measuring circuit. The balancing circuit may include a floating capacitor connected to one of the plurality of battery cells, and a switch-matrix configured to switch the floating capacitor to be connected to one of the plurality of battery cells. The impedance measurement circuit may include a voltage sensor configured to measure a voltage of the floating capacitor, a resistor connected in parallel with the floating capacitor, and a switch configured to switch a connection between the floating capacitor and the resistor.
Claims:
1. An apparatus for measuring impedance of a battery cell, the apparatus comprising: a plurality of battery cells connected in series; a balancing circuit for equalizing states of the plurality of battery cells; an impedance measuring circuit connected to the balancing circuit; And a battery management system configured to control the balancing circuit and the impedance measurement circuit, wherein the balancing circuit includes: a floating capacitor connected to one of the plurality of battery cells; And a switch-matrix for switching the floating capacitor to connect with one of the plurality of battery cells, wherein the impedance measurement circuit includes: a voltage sensor for measuring a voltage of the floating capacitor; A resistor connected in parallel with the floating capacitor; and a switch for switching the connection of the floating capacitor and the resistor, wherein the impedance measurement circuit is activated during a rest period in which the balancing circuit is inoperative.
2. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the measurement circuit alternately measures impedances of the plurality of battery cells.
3. AMEND STATUS: Delete
4. The device according to claim 1, wherein the measurement frequency for measuring the impedance of the battery cell is variable within a specified frequency range.
5. The method of claim 4, wherein the resistance comprises: And the "f.s_max"means the largest frequency in the frequency range, and" C "means the floating capacitor.
6. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the battery management system controls the switch-matrix and the switches using a pulse width modulation (PWM) signal.
7. A method for measuring impedance of battery cells of a battery pack comprising a plurality of battery cells connected in series, a balancing circuit, and a measurement circuit connected to the balancing circuit, Performing charging of the floating capacitor by connecting a first battery cell among the plurality of battery cells and a floating capacitor included in the balancing circuit using a switch-matrix included in the balancing circuit during a quiescent period in which the balancing circuit does not operate; Measuring a voltage of the floating capacitor through a voltage sensor included in the measurement circuit; estimating an impedance of the first battery cell based on the measured voltage; and discharging the floating capacitor by controlling a discharge switch to connect a discharge resistor included in the measurement circuit and the floating capacitor.
8. The method of claim 7, further comprising: switching the switch-matrix to connect a second battery cell of the plurality of battery cells and the floating capacitor to perform charging of the discharged floating capacitor; measuring a voltage of the floating capacitor through the voltage sensor; Estimating an impedance of the second battery cell based on the measured voltage; and discharging the floating capacitor by controlling the discharge switch to connect the discharge resistor and the floating capacitor.

Title: Lithium ion internal temperature prediction method based on dynamic impedance measurement
Inventor:
JIN YANG
L NAWEI
JIANG XIN
Abstract: The invention relates to the technical field of lithium ion battery state monitoring, and discloses a lithium ion internal temperature prediction method based on dynamic impedance measurement. The method comprises the steps of obtaining the target dynamic impedance of a target battery in a target state through employing a target method, and enabling the target state to comprise a charging state, a discharging state and a standing state, wherein the target method is a non-invasive, online and current excitation type dynamic impedance measurement method, the target battery refers to a lithium ion battery, and the target dynamic impedance is the overall impedance of the target battery under current excitation of a certain frequency, and calculating the internal temperature of the battery based on the dynamic impedance in the target state. The internal temperature of the lithium ion battery can be calculated through the measurement of the dynamic impedance, the operation and maintenance operation is guided through the internal temperature, the battery performance is ensured, the service life of the battery is prolonged, and accidents such as thermal runaway and explosion of the battery are avoided.

Title: Cross Spectral Impedance Assessment For Cell Qualification
Inventor: CHRISTOPHERSEN JON P
Abstract: A method for screening and matching cells for qualification and binning can include conducting a first and second impedance-based measurement of a cell separated by a rest interval of the cell and analyzing change/shift in the impedance spectrum obtained before and after the rest interval to afford algorithms to match, categorize, or group cells within a plurality of cells (C1 . . . Cn) that have the same, substantially the same, or fall within a range of structural or functional parameters based on the impedance change/shift in the impedance spectrum.

Title: Device for measuring electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of embedded battery for electric vehicle
Inventor:
XIAO SHUNLI
DING WEILIN
CENG WEIXIONG
CUI WENJUAN
YAO ZHIWEI
LI YONGZHI
Abstract: The embodiment of the utility model discloses a device for measuring electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of an embedded battery for an electric vehicle. The device comprises a central signal processor, a transceiving controller and a plurality of analog signal front ends, the analog signal front end is provided with a connecting part; the central signal processor is used for generating an alternating signal; the transceiving controller is used for transmitting the alternating signal to each analog signal front end; the connecting part of the analog signal front end is used for being connected to a battery monomer; wherein the analog signal front end is close to the battery monomer; the analog signal front end is also used for transmitting the alternating signals flowing through the single batteries to the transceiving controller, and the transceiving controller processes the alternating signals flowing through the single batteries into electrical impedance digital signals and transmits the electrical impedance digital signals to the central signal processor. The electric vehicle comprises the device. The embodiment of the utility model can more accurately obtain the health state of the battery.

Title: Rapid capacity evaluation method based on low-frequency EIS
Inventor:
SUN BINGXIANG
SU XIAOJIA
WANG JIAJU
ZHANG WEIGE
MA SHICHANG
ZHU ZHENLIN
Abstract: The invention relates to a rapid capacity evaluation method based on a low-frequency EIS. The method comprises the following steps: S1, carrying out the low-frequency EIS test of a lithium ion battery in a full-charge state to obtain an original impedance real part and imaginary part set; S2, performing coordinate transformation on the original impedance real part and imaginary part set to obtain an impedance real part and imaginary part set; S3, determining an electrochemical impedance characteristic frequency range and calculating an impedance modulus; S4, calculating a Weber factor Wd according to the corrected Weber impedance formula, and further calculating new health factors: a pseudo lithium ion diffusion coefficient PLDC and a pseudo lithium ion diffusion state PLDS; and S5, rapidly evaluating the capacity state of the lithium ion battery through PLDS. The new health factor provided by the method has relatively strong physical significance, not only can reflect an internal mechanism, but also can avoid dependence on process data, and better characterizes the capacity fading characteristic of the lithium ion battery from the mechanism.

Title: Battery impedance spectrum online detection system and detection method based on DC/AC
Inventor: NI TONG
Abstract: The invention discloses a battery impedance spectrum online detection system and detection method based on DC/AC. The system comprises a battery string unit, a DC-AC converter DC/AC and a microcontroller. The power end of the battery string unit is connected to the DC-AC converter DC/AC, the voltage and current signal output end of the battery string unit is connected to the ADC analog-to-digital conversion end of the microcontroller, and the communication end of the DC-AC converter DC/AC is connected to the communication end of the microcontroller. According to the invention, the excitation signal is coupled to the DC/AC in work, and the battery string units connected in series can still work normally, so that the system can carry out real-time online detection on the tested equivalent battery; through a multi-DC/AC cooperative working mode, the influence on the system is minimized and even eliminated, and normal operation can be continued without changing the external characteristics of the original series power supply system.

Title: Short circuit estimation device of secondary battery, short circuit estimation method, and short circuit estimation system
Inventor:
WADA, Hiroyuki
KOTAKA, Toshikazu
TAKAICHI, Satoshi
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a short circuit estimation device of a secondary battery, which can predict an inside short circuit caused by a lithium dendrite before the generation of the short circuit.
SOLUTION: A short circuit estimation device estimating the presence/absence of the generation of an inside short circuit in a secondary battery having a positive electrode, a solid electrolyte, and a negative electrode containing a lithium alloy, comprises: a measurement instrument 7 that measures a state of the secondary battery 2; and a controller 8 that estimates the inside short circuit in the secondary battery 2. The measurement instrument 7 measures an internal resistance of the secondary battery 2 from an AC impedance of the secondary battery 2, and measures a mechanical characteristic value of an electrolyte indicating a mechanical characteristic of the solid electrolyte and a mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode indicating a mechanical characteristic of the negative electrode. The controller 8 has the internal resistance of the secondary battery 2 of a prescribed resistance threshold value or larger, and estimates that there is a possibility of the generation of the internal short circuit if the mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is equal to the mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode or smaller.
SELECTED DRAWING: Figure 1
COPYRIGHT: (C)2021,JPO&INPIT
Claims:
1. A short circuit estimation device for estimating whether or not an internal short circuit has occurred in a secondary battery having a positive electrode, a solid electrolyte, and a negative electrode containing a lithium alloy, the device comprising: a measuring instrument for measuring a state of the secondary battery; A controller that estimates an internal short circuit in the secondary battery, wherein the measuring instrument measures an internal resistance of the secondary battery from an AC impedance of the secondary battery, and A mechanical characteristic value of an electrolyte indicating mechanical characteristics of the solid electrolyte and a mechanical characteristic value of a negative electrode indicating mechanical characteristics of the negative electrode are measured, and the controller estimates that there is a possibility of the internal short circuit occurring when the internal resistance is greater than or equal to a predetermined resistance threshold and the mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to the mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.
2. The device according to claim 1, whereinthe measuring instrument measures one of an electrolyte resistance and a reaction resistance included in the internal resistance on the basis of an AC signal having a fixed frequency.
3. The short circuit estimation device according to claim 1 or 2, whereinthe controller charges the secondary battery when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is less than the resistance threshold value and/or when a mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is higher than a mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.
4. The short circuit estimation device according to any one of claims 1 to 3, whereinthe controller reduces a charging current of the secondary battery or a C rate of the secondary battery to be lower than a predetermined value when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is greater than or equal to the resistance threshold value and a mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to a mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.
5. The short circuit estimation device according to any one of claims 1 to 3, whereinthe controller stops charging the secondary battery when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is greater than or equal to the resistance threshold value and a mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to a mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.
6. The short circuit estimation device according to any one of claims 1 to 3, whereinin a usage temperature region of the secondary battery, an amount of change in a mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode with respect to temperature changes is greater than that of the solid electrolyte; and The controller increases a temperature of the secondary battery above a predetermined value when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is greater than or equal to a predetermined resistance threshold value and a mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to a mechanical characteristic value of the anode.
7. A short circuit estimation method for estimating the presence or absence of occurrence of an internal short circuit in a secondary battery having a positive electrode, a solid electrolyte, and a negative electrode containing a lithium alloy, the method comprising: measuring AC impedance of the secondary battery, and calculating an internal resistance of the secondary battery from the AC impedance; Measuring a mechanical characteristic value of an electrolyte indicating mechanical characteristics of the solid electrolyte and a mechanical characteristic value of a negative electrode indicating mechanical characteristics of the negative electrode; and estimating that there is a possibility of occurrence of the internal short circuit when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is greater than or equal to a predetermined resistance threshold and the mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to the mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.
8. A rechargeable battery comprising: a rechargeable battery comprising a positive electrode, a solid electrolyte, and a negative electrode comprising a lithium alloy; a measuring instrument that measures AC impedance of the rechargeable battery and mechanical characteristics of the rechargeable battery; anda controller that estimates whether or not an internal short circuit occurs in the rechargeable battery; whereinthe measuring instrument calculates an internal resistance of the rechargeable battery from the AC impedance; A mechanical characteristic value of an electrolyte indicating mechanical characteristics of the solid electrolyte and a mechanical characteristic value of a negative electrode indicating mechanical characteristics of the negative electrode are measured, and the controller estimates that there is a possibility of the internal short circuit occurring when an internal resistance of the secondary battery is greater than or equal to a predetermined resistance threshold and the mechanical characteristic value of the electrolyte is less than or equal to the mechanical characteristic value of the negative electrode.

Title: Impedance Determination With Phase Determination
Inventor: SCHMIDT JAN PHILIPP
Abstract: A method for the correction of synchronization errors ?t in the measurement of the impedance of an electrical or electrochemical component, more particularly a lithium ion cell is provided. In general, synchronization errors in an impedance measurement can arise between the excitation and response signals, which can misrepresent the phase of the impedance value obtained. According to the method, the synchronization error can be determined by measuring the impedance at two different frequencies and solving an optimization problem in respect of the deviation of the phases from an equivalent circuit diagram, which comprises at least one resistance and an inductance. The phase of the impedance value obtained can be corrected in this way.
Claims:
1.-9. (canceled)
10. A method for determining an impedance of an electrical or electrochemical component with correction of a synchronization error, the method comprising:
  choosing an impedance model for the component, which has a resistance and an inductance;
 applying an excitation signal with a first frequency and a second frequency;
  measuring a response signal, which is beset by the synchronization error relative to the excitation signal;
  determining a first impedance at the first frequency and a second impedance at the second frequency from the excitation signal and the response signal;
  determining the synchronization error as a value for which a deviation between a difference between the second impedance and the first impedance and a corresponding value of an impedance difference that is calculated for an equivalent circuit diagram falls below a predetermined threshold value in respect of at least one impedance component; and
  correcting values of the first impedance and the second impedance using the synchronization error.
11. The method of claim 10, wherein the component is a lithium ion cell.
12. The method according to claim 10, wherein:
  determining the synchronization error is carried out iteratively,
 in each iteration the difference is calculated,
  from a phase of the difference a differential is calculated and accumulated, and
 from an accumulated value a phase of the first impedance and the second impedance is corrected.
13. The method according to claim 10, wherein the first frequency and the second frequency are between 1 kHz and 20 kHz.
14. The method according to claim 10, further comprising determining an impedance at one or more further frequencies that are lower than the first and the second frequency.
15. The method according to claim 14, wherein the one or more further frequencies are between 10 and 300 Hz.
16. The method according to claim 10, wherein the excitation signal comprises a superposition of the first frequency and the second frequency.
17. The method according to claim 14, wherein the excitation signal comprises a superposition of the first frequency, the second frequency, and the one or more further frequencies.
18. A battery system comprising:
  a plurality of lithium ion cells, wherein individual cells or blocks composed of a plurality of cells connected in parallel are connected in series;
  one or more signal generators that are configured to apply the excitation signal;
 one or more cell monitoring units that are configured to monitor a cell voltage of the lithium ion cells and to record the response signal; and
  one or more computing units that are configured to carry out the method according to claim 10.
19. The battery system according to claim 18, wherein the one or more signal generators comprise a single signal generator, which impresses the excitation signal globally on a total current.
20. The battery system according to claim 18, wherein the one or more computing units are integrated into the one or more cell monitoring units.

Title: Estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery
Inventor:
BOSS VALENTIN 
BIRTH SREN
Abstract: A computer-implemented method and a battery state estimating system for estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery, including: weighting (S22) the electrical impedance measurements (10) of a provided series of electrical impedance measurements according to a weighting function that is dependent on the index (s) of the series or on the measurement frequency (fs), resulting in at least a series (21) of consecutive elements of the series of measurements (10), when point-to-point connected in the complex plane of the electrical impedance in a sequence according to the index (s) of the series of measurements (10), forming at least one loop (22) in the complex plane; calculating (S24) a measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane; determining (S26) an estimation of a battery state of the electrochemical battery (44) based on the calculated measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane; and outputting (S28) the estimation of the battery state.
Claims:
1. A computer-implemented method of estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery, the method comprising: 
 providing (S12) a series of electrical impedance measurements (10) of an electrochemical battery (44), each electrical impedance measurement (10) being measured at a respective measurement frequency (fs), the series being ordered according to the respective measurement frequencies, 
 optionally, translating (S18) and/or scaling (S20), in the complex plane of the electrical impedance, the series of electrical impedance measurements (10), 
 weighting (S22) the electrical impedance measurements (10) according to a weighting function that is dependent on the index (s) of the series or on the measurement frequency (fs), resulting in at least a series (21) of consecutive elements of the series of measurements (10), when point-to-point connected in the complex plane of the electrical impedance in a sequence according to the index (s) of the series of measurements (10), forming at least one loop (22) in the complex plane, 
 calculating (S24) a measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane, 
 determining (S26) an estimation of a battery state of the electrochemical battery (44) based on the calculated measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane, and 
 outputting (S28) the estimation of the battery state.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the weighting function increases with increasing measurement frequencies (fs).
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, wherein the weighting function corresponds to a logarithm of the measurement frequency (fs).
4. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein calculating (S24) a measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane comprises calculating an area (24) that is enclosed by the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane.
5. The method of claim 4, wherein calculating (S24) a measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane comprises calculating a square root of an area (24) that is enclosed by the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane.
6. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein an estimation of a state of health of the electrochemical battery (44) is determined based on the calculated measure of the size of the at least one loop (22) in the complex plane.
7. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the method comprises: 
 identifying (S16) at least three subseries (16; 18; 20) within the provided series of electrical impedance measurements (10), a first subseries (16) of the three subseries being associated with a battery behavior of the electrochemical battery (44) in which the electrical impedance is dominated by diffusion processes, a second subseries (18) of the three subseries being associated with a battery behavior of the electrochemical battery (44) in which the electrical impedance is dominated by charge transfer processes at the electrodes of the battery, a third subseries (20) of the three subseries being separated from the second subseries at a position that corresponds to a zero-crossing (12) in the complex plane of the imaginary part of electrical impedance, and
 
 translating (S18) the respective electrical impedance measurements (10) corresponding to subtracting an ohmic alternating current resistance value from the real part of electrical impedance, wherein the ohmic alternating current resistance value is determined according to a real part of electrical impedance at the zero-crossing (12) in the complex plane of the imaginary part of electrical impedance which zero-crossing (12) in the complex plane corresponds to the position at which the third subseries (20) of the three subseries is separated from the second subseries (18); and 
 scaling (S24) the respective translated electrical impedance measurements (10), corresponding to scaling the real part and the imaginary part of electrical impedance by respective scaling factors, the absolute values of which are determined based on the absolute values of the real part and the imaginary part, respectively, of an electrical impedance that corresponds to a transition (14) between the translated first subseries (16) of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10) and the translated second subseries (18) of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10).
8. The method of claim 7, wherein the step of identifying (S18) comprises determining a local relative maximum of the imaginary part of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10), the local relative maximum being separated by other elements of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10) from the zero-crossing (12) in the complex plane of the imaginary part of electrical impedance of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10), wherein optionally the local relative maximum is a local relative maximum when smoothing and/or interpolating the series of electrical impedance measurements (10).
9. The method of claim 7 or 8, wherein the step of identifying (S16) comprises determining a transition (14) between one subseries (16) of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10) and a further subseries (18) of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10), wherein the one subseries (16) of electrical impedance measurements has imaginary parts of electrical impedance that are negative and that have a magnitude which basically increases towards the transition (14), and wherein the further subseries (18) of electrical impedance has imaginary parts of electrical impedance that are negative and that have a magnitude which basically increases and then basically decreases towards the transition (14).
10. The method of any one of claims 7, 8, and 9, wherein the first subseries (16) and the second subseries (18) are identified based on the determined local relative maximum of the imaginary part of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10), or based on the determined transition (14) between the one subseries of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10) and the further subseries of the series of electrical impedance measurements (10).
11. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the method further comprises:
 measuring (S10) the electrical impedance of an electrochemical battery (44) at different measurement frequencies (fs) to provide the series of electrical impedance measurements (10).
12. A battery state estimating system for estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery (44), the system comprising means for carrying out the steps of the method of any one of claims 1 to 11.
13. The battery state estimating system of claim 12, the battery state estimating system further comprising:
 electrical impedance measuring means (42) configured for measuring the electrical impedance of an electrochemical battery (44) at different measurement frequencies (fs) to provide the series of electrical impedance measurements (10).

Title: Estimating a battery state from gradients of electrical impedance measurements
Inventor: BOSS VALENTIN
Abstract: A computer-implemented method and a battery state estimating system for estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery, including: calculating (S18) electrical impedance gradients from a provided series of electrical impedance measurements (25) to generate a series of electrical impedance gradients (27); and determining (S22) a battery state of the electrochemical battery (14) using computational means (22) configured to receive as inputs at least the series of electrical impedance gradients (27), the computational means (22) receiving and processing at least the provided series of calculated electrical impedance gradients (27) to generate therefrom at least one output signal representing a battery state (38) associated with the electrochemical battery (14).
Claims:
1. A computer-implemented method of estimating a battery state of an electrochemical battery, the method comprising: 
 providing (S12) a series of electrical impedance measurements (25) of an electrochemical battery (14), each electrical impedance measurement (25) being measured at a respective measurement frequency (fs), the series being ordered according to the respective measurement frequencies (fs), 
 calculating (S18) electrical impedance gradients from the series of electrical impedance measurements (25) to generate a series of electrical impedance gradients (27), 
 determining (S22) a battery state of the electrochemical battery (14) using computational means (22) configured to receive as inputs at least the series of electrical impedance gradients (27), 
 wherein the series of calculated electrical impedance gradients (27) is provided (S20) to the computational means (22), 
 wherein the computational means (22) receives and processes at least the provided series of calculated electrical impedance gradients (27) to generate therefrom at least one output signal representing a battery state (38) associated with the electrochemical battery (14).
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the electrical impedance gradients are calculated with respect to one of the measurement frequency (fs), a logarithm of the measurement frequency (fs), or the index (s) of the elements of the series of electrical impedance measurements (25).
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, wherein the method further comprises:
 adjusting (S16) the number of elements of the series of electrical impedance gradients (27) to a predetermined number of elements.
4. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computational means (22) include artificial neural network means (28) configured to receive as inputs at least the series of electrical impedance gradients (27).
5. The method of claim 4, wherein the artificial neural network means (28) include a deep neural network.
6. The method of claim 4 or 5, wherein the artificial neural network means (28) include a convolutional neural network.
7. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computational means (22) receives and processes the series of electrical impedance gradients (27) to generate therefrom at least one output signal representing a state of charge of the electrochemical battery (14).

Title: Analyzing electrical impedance measurements of an electrochemical battery
Inventor: BOSS VALENTIN
Abstract: A computer-implemented method and an electrical impedance analyzing system for analyzing electrical impedance measurements of an electrochemical battery, including:a translating (S22) of respective electrical impedance measurements (32) that corresponds to subtracting an ohmic alternating current resistance value (R0) from the real part of electrical impedance; anda scaling (S24) using scaling factors, the absolute values of which are based on an electrical impedance that corresponds to a transition (34) between a translated first subseries (38) and a translated second subseries (40) of the series of electrical impedance measurements, the first subseries (38) being associated with a battery behavior of the electrochemical battery in which the electrical impedance is dominated by diffusion processes, the second subseries (40) being associated with a battery behavior of the electrochemical battery in which the electrical impedance is dominated by charge transfer processes at the electrodes of the battery.

Title: Method for determining the state of charge of a low-voltage battery of a motor vehicle
Inventor:
MOHRMANN BJRN 
KURZWEIL DENNIS 
OPREE PATRICK 
SCHMIDT CHRISTIAN
Abstract:
The invention relates to a method for determining the state of charge of a battery of a motor vehicle (2), in particular of a low-voltage battery (14). The method comprises the following steps of (S100) detecting a start (IB) of the motor vehicle (2), (S300) generating a measurement signal (MS) for an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy by using a DC-DC converter (10) of the motor vehicle (2) when a start (IB) of the motor vehicle (2) is detected, and (S400) evaluating the electrical output voltage provided by the DC-DC converter (10) and the electrical terminal voltage of the battery in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the battery.
 (From CN112649748 A)
Claims:
1. Method for determining the state of charge of a low-voltage battery (14) of a motor vehicle (2), having the steps: (S100) detecting a startup (IB) of the motor vehicle (2), (S300) generating a measurement signal (MS) for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy with a DC/DC converter (10) of the motor vehicle (2) in response to the detection of the startup (IB) of the motor vehicle (2), and (S400) evaluate the electrical output voltage provided by the DC/DC converter (10) and the electrical terminal voltage of the battery to determine the state of charge of the battery.
2. Method according to Claim 1, wherein electrical input and output currents of the DC/DC converter (10) and low-voltage battery (14) are additionally detected and evaluated in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14).
3. Method according to Claim 1 or 2, wherein an open-circuit voltage of the low-voltage battery (14) is additionally detected and evaluated in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14).
4. Method according to Claim 1, 2 or 3, wherein, in a further step (S200) for determining the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14), the DC/DC converter (10) and the low-voltage battery (14) are electrically isolated from an electrical load (8) of the motor vehicle (2).
5. A computer program product adapted to perform a method according to any one of claims 1 to 4.
6. Battery management system (4), wherein the battery management system (4) is designed to detect a startup (IB) of the motor vehicle (2), to generate a measurement signal (MS) for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy with a DC/DC converter (10) of the motor vehicle (2) upon detection of the startup (IB) of the motor vehicle (2), and to evaluate the electrical output voltage provided by the DC/DC converter (10) and the electrical terminal voltage of a battery, in particular of a low-voltage battery (14), in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the battery.
7. Battery management system (4) according to Claim 6, wherein the battery management system (4) is designed to additionally detect and evaluate electrical input and output currents of the DC/DC converter (10) and of the low-voltage battery (14) in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14).
8. Battery management system (4) according to Claim 6 or 7, wherein the battery management system (4) is additionally designed to detect and evaluate an open-circuit voltage of the low-voltage battery (14) in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14).
9. Battery management system (4) according to Claim 6, 7 or 8, wherein the battery management system (4) is designed to galvanically isolate the DC/DC converter (10) and the low-voltage battery (14) from an electrical load (8) of the motor vehicle (2) in order to determine the state of charge (LZ) of the low-voltage battery (14).
10. DC/DC converter (10), wherein the DC/DC converter (10) is designed to provide a measurement signal (MS) for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy for determining the state of charge of a low-voltage battery (14) of a motor vehicle (2).
11. Motor vehicle (2) having a battery management system (4) according to one of Claims 6 to 9 and a DC/DC converter (10) according to Claim 10.

Title: Power unit analysis
Inventor:
STOCKER RICHARD 
BRAGLIA MICHELE
Abstract: A method of isolating and quantifying temperature-dependent and temperature-independent contributions to ohmic resistance in a power unit, comprising: obtaining an impedance spectrum from the power unit at a plurality of measured temperatures; determining a total ohmic resistance of the power unit from the impedance spectrum at each temperature; applying a multi-objective fitting process to quantify the temperature-dependent and temperature-independent contributions to the total ohmic resistance wherein an objective is to minimise the disparity between an Arrhenius slope derived at least partially from the impedance spectra and an Arrhenius slope derived solely from modelling; and outputting the quantified temperature-dependent and temperature-independent contributions as ohmic resistance parameters; wherein the Arrhenius slopes are based on the equation: (I) where Rohmic is a total ohmic resistance, R0 is a variable parameter, R1 is a variable parameter, EA is a variable parameter and RT is the gas constant multiplied by temperature.

Claims
1. A method of isolating and quantifying temperature-dependent and temperature-independent contributions to ohmic resistance in a power unit, comprising: obtaining an impedance spectrum from the power unit at a plurality of measured temperatures; determining a total ohmic resistance of the power unit from the impedance spectrum at each temperature; applying a multi-objective fitting process to quantify the temperature-dependent and temperature- independent contributions to the total ohmic resistance wherein an objective is to minimise the disparity between an Arrhenius slope derived at least partially from the impedance spectra and an Arrhenius slope derived solely from modelling; and outputting the quantified temperature-dependent and temperature-independent contributions as ohmic resistance parameters; wherein the Arrhenius slopes are based on the equation:where Rohrlic is a total ohmic resistance, R0 is a variable parameter, /?! is a variable parameter, EA is a variable parameter and RT is the gas constant multiplied by temperature.
2. A method according to claim 1 , wherein the impedance spectra comprise electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data.
3. A method according to any preceding claim, further comprising displaying the ohmic resistance parameters.
4. A method according to any preceding claim, further comprising comparing the ohmic resistance parameters to known values.
5. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein the Arrhenius slope derived at least partially from the impedance spectra is obtained by plotting ln(Rdata - R0 ) againstwhere Rdata is the measured total ohmic resistance at a measured temperature, R0 is a variable parameter and T is the measured temperature.
6. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein the Arrhenius slope derived solely from modelling is obtained by plotting the output of IniR^ + (^) against ^ for a plurality of temperatures.
7. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein an objective is to minimise the disparity between the measured total ohmic resistance and a model total ohmic resistance.
8. A method according to claim 7, wherein the model total ohmic resistance, Rfit, is calculated according to the equation Rfit = R0 + R^RT1.
9. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein the multi-objective fitting process is a dualobjective fitting process, a first objective being to minimise the disparity between an Arrhenius slope derived at least partially from the impedance spectra and an Arrhenius slope derived solely from modelling and a second objective being to minimise the disparity between the measured total ohmic resistance and a model total ohmic resistance.
10. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein the optimisation of the fitting process is carried out using a combination of global optimisation and local optimisation.
11. A method according to claim 10, wherein the global optimisation is performed using particle swarm optimisation and/or genetic algorithm optimisation.
12. A method according to any preceding claim, wherein the initial conditions for the multi-objective fitting process are determined by a combination of a known value and an initial single-objective fit.
13. A method according to claim 12, wherein the objective of the initial single-objective fit is to minimise the disparity between the measured total ohmic resistance and a model total ohmic resistance Rfit at a given temperature using the equation Rfit = R0 + R^RT1.

16. A method of isolating and quantifying individual contributions to dynamic resistance in a power unit, comprising: obtaining an impedance spectrum from the power unit; removing diffusion impedance effects from the impedance spectrum; converting the impedance spectrum into a distribution of relaxation times; isolating individual peaks in the distribution of relaxation times; reconstructing an impedance spectrum for each peak; fitting equivalent circuit elements to the reconstructed impedance spectra to quantify the individual resistance contributions to the dynamic resistance of the power unit; and
 outputting the quantified individual resistance contributions as dynamic resistance parameters.

18. A method according to claim 17, wherein the pulse relaxation data is converted into an impedance spectrum by fitting frequency domain elements to the pulse relaxation data using Laplace inversion, and constructing an impedance spectrum from the frequency domain elements.
19. A method according to claim 17 or 18, wherein the pulse relaxation data is obtained by a galvanostatic intermittent titration technique.
20. A method according to claim 17 or 18, wherein the pulse relaxation data is obtained by hybrid pulse power characterisation.

38. A method according to claim 35 or 36, wherein the pulse relaxation data is obtained by hybrid pulse power characterisation.

A method according to claim 35, wherein the impedance spectrum is obtained from the power unit by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, wherein the pure capacitance term is created using state of charge-open circuit voltage maps by applying coulomb counting to the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy profile.
40. A method according to any of claims 34-39 wherein the impedance spectrum is converted into a distribution of relaxation times and the diffusion impedance parameters obtained from fitting to the impedance spectrum are refined by fitting to the distribution of relaxation times.
41. A method according to claim 40 wherein the diffusion impedance parameters are fitted to a predetermined range of the distribution of relaxation times where diffusion effects are known to be found based on the Nyquist plot profile of the impedance spectrum.

43. A computer-readable medium storing instructions which, when executed by a processor, cause the performance of the method of any of claims 34-42.

A system comprising: an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) instrument for obtaining EIS data from a power unit, and/or a galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) instrument for obtaining GITT data from a power unit and/or a hybrid pulse power characterisation (HPPC) instrument for obtaining HPPC data from a power unit; and a processor programmed to perform the method of any of claims 1-14, 16-32, or 34-42.
45. The system of claim 44, further comprising a display for displaying the ohmic resistance parameters and/or dynamic resistance parameters and/or diffusion impedance parameters.

An electric vehicle comprising a system according to claim 44 or 45, wherein the ohmic resistance parameters and/or dynamic resistance parameters and/or diffusion impedance parameters are input as battery health data to a battery management system which manages a battery according to the battery health data.
47. An electric vehicle according to claim 46, wherein the battery management system is configured to output a notification to a user when the battery health data indicates the battery health has degraded below a predetermined threshold.

A computer-implemented method of comparing power units comprising: obtaining ohmic resistance parameters and/or dynamic resistance parameters and/or diffusion impedance parameters for a plurality of power units according to any of claims 1-14,16-32 or 34-42; inputting the ohmic resistance parameters and/or dynamic resistance parameters and/or diffusion impedance parameters into a power unit degradation model; outputting the results of the degradation model; displaying the results of the degradation model; and ranking the power units by their expected degradation characteristics.
49. A method according to claim 48 further comprising the step of selecting the highest-ranked power unit for use in a vehicle.

Title: Device for detecting variable-frequency alternating-current impedance of battery on line
Inventor:
DONG WEI
TANG JING
YANG XIAOBING
XU ZHENGYI
Abstract: The invention provides a device for detecting variable-frequency alternating-current impedance of a battery on line. The device comprises a processor unit, a battery pack, an excitation load resistor,an excitation generation module, a current sampling resistor, a current sampling module, a multiplexing change-over switch, a voltage sampling module and a communication module, wherein the multiplexing change-over switch is used for carrying out independent opening and closing control on each battery cell of the battery pack; the processor unit comprises an FFT digital circuit, the excitation generation module is connected with the processor unit, and the FFT digital circuit is connected with the voltage sampling module and the current sampling module. Shutdown-free real-time detection of the variable-frequency alternating-current impedance of the battery cell of the battery pack can be realized, the battery maintenance efficiency is improved, and the battery maintenance cost is reduced.The battery management system analyzes the SOH state of the battery cell of the battery pack in real time in the operation process according to the measured data, can give an early warning for the aging of the battery cell in advance, and prevents the aged battery cell from being overheated to cause damage to the whole battery in the charging and discharging process.
Claims:
1. The utility model provides an on-line measuring battery frequency conversion AC impedance device which characterized in that: the device comprises a processor unit, a battery pack, an excitation load resistor, an excitation generation module, a current sampling resistor, a current sampling module, a multiplexing change-over switch, a voltage sampling module and a communication module, wherein the battery pack is connected with the excitation load resistor, the excitation switch, the current sampling resistor, a discharging contactor, a charging contactor, a load and a charging device through a circuit; the multiplexing switch is connected between the voltage sampling module and the battery pack, the battery pack comprises a plurality of battery cells, and each battery cell of the battery pack is controlled to be opened and closed independently by the multiplexing switch; the signal output end of the voltage sampling module is connected with the processor unit; the input end of the current sampling module is connected with the current sampling resistor, and the output end of the current sampling module is connected with the processor unit; the communication module is connected with the processor unit and transmits the signal to the external battery management system host; the processor unit comprises an FFT digital circuit, the excitation generation module is connected with the processor unit, and the FFT digital circuit is connected with the voltage sampling module and the current sampling module.
2. The device for detecting the variable-frequency alternating-current impedance of the battery in the online manner according to claim 1, wherein: the voltage sampling module and the current sampling module respectively comprise a direct current signal acquisition circuit and an alternating current signal acquisition circuit, wherein the alternating current signal acquisition circuit comprises a multistage signal amplification circuit.

Title: SOH estimation method of retired lithium ion battery
Inventor:
HUANG HAIHONG
LUO FAN
NI LIPING
LI TAN
Abstract: The invention discloses an SOH estimation method of a retired lithium ion battery. The method comprises the following steps: obtaining a primary SOC estimation value SOC1 of a retired lithium ion battery through primary impedance measurement; performing short-time constant-current discharge on the retired lithium ion battery to obtain a discharge quantity Q; performing secondary impedance measurement to obtain a secondary SOC estimated value SOC2 of the retired lithium ion battery; and obtaining the SOH estimated value of the retired lithium ion battery by utilizing a formula SOH=Q/(SOC1-SOC2); The method has the advantages that the method is suitable for SOH estimation of the retired lithium ion battery, the SOH estimation speed is high, and energy consumption is low.

Title: Method for monitoring battery cells of a battery, battery system and motor vehicle
Inventor:
DE ARROYABE JOSE LOPEZ 
REUSS JOERG
Abstract: The invention relates to a method for monitoring battery cells (5) of a battery (3) of a motor vehicle by means of electrostatic impedance spectroscopy, wherein in the method - a current signal with currents of different frequencies is impressed on the battery cells (5) as an excitation signal, - cell voltage signals of the battery cells (5) are detected as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal, and - impedance spectra of the battery cells (5) are determined as a function of the excitation signal and the response signals, wherein, in order to provide the excitation signal, the battery (3) is subdivided into at least two subsections (3 a, 3 b) each having at least one battery cell (5), and alternating charge transfers are carried out between the partial strands (3 a, 3 b) at the different frequencies by alternately removing charge from one of the partial strands (3 a, 3 b), which charge is supplied to another partial strand (3 b, 3 a)... The invention also relates to a battery system and to a motor vehicle.
Claims:
1. Method for monitoring battery cells (5) of a battery (3) of a motor vehicle by means of galvanostatic impedance spectroscopy, wherein in the method - a current signal with currents of different frequencies is impressed on the battery cells (5) as an excitation signal, - cell voltage signals of the battery cells (5) are detected as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal, and - impedance spectra of the battery cells (5) are determined as a function of the excitation signal and the response signals, characterized in thatIn such a way that, in order to provide the excitation signal, the battery (3) is subdivided into at least two substrings (3 a, 3 b) each having at least one battery cell (5), and between the substrings (3 a, 3 b) alternating charge transfers with the different frequencies are carried out by alternately removing charge from one of the partial strands (3 a, 3 b), which charge is supplied to another partial strand (3 b, 3 a).
2. The method of claim 1, characterized in thatCharacterized in that at least one frequency-dependent characteristic variable of the battery cell (5) is determined from the impedance spectrum of a battery cell (5).
3. The method of claim 1 or 2, characterized in thatIn that a temperature and/or a state of charge and/or an ageing of the battery cell (5) is determined as the at least one frequency-dependent characteristic variable of the battery cell (5).
4. Battery system (2) having a battery (3) with a plurality of interconnected battery cells (5) and an apparatus (6) which is designed to monitor the battery cells (5) by means of galvanostatic impedance spectroscopy, wherein the apparatus (6) has: - a control device (7) which is designed to determine, to impress on the battery cells (5) a current signal with currents of different frequencies as an excitation signal, and - a measuring device (8), Detect cell voltage signals of the battery cells (5) as frequency-dependent response signals to the excitation signal and determine impedance spectra of the battery cells (5) as a function of the excitation signal and the response signals, characterized in thatCharacterised in that the battery (3) is divided into at least two partial strands (3 a. 3 b) with in each case at least one battery cell (5), and the control device (7) for providing the excitation signal is designed to carry out alternating charge transfers between the substrings (3 a, 3 b) at different frequencies by alternately removing charge from one of the substrings (3 a, 3 b), which charge it feeds back to another substring (3 b, 3 b).
5. Battery system (2) according to Claim 4, characterized in thatCharacterised in that the battery (3) has a centre tap (M) for dividing the battery (3) into the at least two partial strands (3 a, 3 b).
6. Battery system (2) according to Claim 5, characterized in thatCharacterized in that the control device is in the form of a DC/DC converter electrically connected to two connection points of the series circuit and the centre tap.
7. Battery system (2) according to one of Claims 4 to 6, characterized in thatCharacterized in that the measuring device (8) has a voltage sensor for detecting the cell voltage for each battery cell (5).
8. Motor vehicle having a battery system (2) according to one of Claims 4 to 7, wherein the battery (3) is embodied as a traction battery of the motor vehicle.

Title: Power storage system, power storage device, and charging method
Inventor: KOBAYASHI HITOSHI
Abstract: A power storage system (1) includes: a power storage device (100) including a cell stack (101) including power storage cells (B0 to B5) connected in series; and a charging device (200) that supplies a charging current to the power storage device (100). The power storage system (1) further includes: an alternating current excitating circuit (148) in the power storage device (100) or the charging device (200) that excitates the charging current using an alternating current; a complex impedance measuring unit (110) in the power storage device (100) that measures a current value of the alternating current used to excitate the charging current and a voltage value of each of the power storage cells (B0 to B5), and measures a complex impedance of each of the power storage cells (B0 to B5) from the measured current and voltage values; and a charging control unit in the power storage device (100) or the charging device (200) that controls the charging current based on the complex impedance.
Claims:
1. A power storage system comprising:
  a cell stack including a plurality of power storage cells connected in series;
  a charging circuit that supplies a charging current to the cell stack;
 an alternating current excitating circuit that excitates the charging current using an alternating current;
  a complex impedance measuring unit configured to measure a current value of the alternating current used to excitate the charging current and a voltage value of each of the plurality of power storage cells, and measure a complex impedance of each of the plurality of power storage cells from the measured current value and the measured voltage value; and
  a charging control unit configured to control the charging current based on the complex impedance.
2. The power storage system according to claim 1,
 wherein the charging control unit is configured to estimate an internal temperature of each of the plurality of power storage cells based on an external temperature of the cell stack and the complex impedance, and optimize the charging current according to the estimated internal temperature.
3. The power storage system according to claim 2,
 wherein the charging control unit is configured to estimate the internal temperature of each of the plurality of power storage cells according to at least one of temperature characteristic data or temperature distribution data, the temperature characteristic data indicating a correspondence between an internal temperature of the cell stack and the complex impedance, and the temperature distribution data indicating a distribution of the external temperature and the internal temperature of the cell stack.
4. The power storage system according to any one of claims 1 to 3,
 wherein the charging control unit is configured to control the charging current according to a deterioration state of each of the plurality of power storage cells estimated from the complex impedance.
5. The power storage system according to any one of claims 1 to 3,

6. The power storage system according to any one of claims 1 to 5,
 wherein the charging control unit is configured to determine a value of the charging current to shorten a charging time required for a charge level of the cell stack to reach a predetermined level.
7. The power storage system according to claim 2 or 3, wherein the charging control unit is configured to suspend charging when the internal temperature reaches a threshold.
