 generating alternating current to the positive and negative electrodes of the single battery through an alternating current excitation circuit, and collecting alternating current voltage response signals after alternating current excitation; and calculating the internal resistance of the battery monomer through the collected alternating voltage response signal and the input alternating current excitation signal.
10. The method for measuring the internal resistance of the battery cell in the battery box according to claim 9, characterized in that: during measurement, excitation signals are respectively applied to the anode and the cathode of a single battery in the battery pack, and alternating current voltage response signals of the single battery are correspondingly acquired.

Title: System for obtaining battery state information
Inventor:
LEE YOUNG JAE 
MYUNG HEE KYUNG 
HONG SEONG JOON
Abstract: A system for obtaining state information of a battery may be disclosed. The system includes: at least one first harness cable for obtaining, on the basis of a CAN protocol, data indicating state information of the battery from a battery management system of the battery; an analyzer for providing a driving signal for driving the battery management system; and a first junction box for transmitting the data input through the first harness cable to the analyzer, wherein the analyzer may be configured to output the data received from the first junction box to the outside.
Claims:
1. A system for obtaining state information of a battery, the system comprising: 
 at least one first harness cable configured to obtain data indicating state information of the battery from a battery management system of the battery; 
 an analyzer configured to provide a driving signal for driving the battery management system; and 
 a first junction box configured to transmit the data input through the first harness cable to the analyzer, 
 wherein the analyzer is configured to output the data received from the first junction box to the outside.
2. The system of claim 1, further comprising a power supply connected to the first junction box to supply a power to the battery management system.
3. The system of claim 1, wherein the state information of the battery comprises at least one of voltage, temperature, state of charge (SoC), state of health (SoH), state of power (SoP), state of energy (SoE), and state of balance (SoB) of the battery.
4. The system of claim 1, further comprising: 
 a second junction box connected to the battery through at least one second harness cable; and 
 an alternating current (AC) impedance analyzer configured to detect an AC impedance of the battery through the second junction box, 
 wherein the second junction box comprises a circuit configured to detect the AC impedance.
5. The system of claim 4, wherein the AC impedance analyzer measures an AC impedance of the battery in a fully charged state, an AC impedance of the battery in a fully discharged state, and an AC impedance of the battery in a partially charged or partially discharged state.
6. The system of claim 4, wherein the AC impedance analyzer measures the AC impedance by measuring at least one of a resistance, an inductance, and a capacitance at a reference frequency or within a reference frequency range.
7. The system of claim 4, wherein the AC impedance analyzer measures the AC impedance by measuring at least one of a resistance, an inductance, and a capacitance at a reference frequency or within a reference frequency range, and configuring an equivalent circuit corresponding to the measured resistance, inductance, and capacitance.
8. The system of claim 4, whrerein the AC impedance analyzer outputs information on the AC impedance to the outside based on a TCP/IP.
9. The system of claim 4, further comprising a charge/discharge apparatus configured to charge or discharge the battery,
 wherein the charge/discharge apparatus is connected to the battery through the second junction box.
10. The system of claim 4, further comprising an insulation resistor configured to measure an insulation resistance of the battery,
 wherein the insulation resistor is connected to the battery through the second junction box.
11. The system of claim 4, further comprising a voltage meter configured to measure a voltage of the battery,
 wherein the voltage meter is connected to the battery through the second junction box.
12. The system of claim 4, wherein the first junction box comprises a temperature sensor configured to measure a temperature inside the first junction box.
13. The system of claim 1, wherein the analyzer outputs the data based on a control area network (CAN) protocol.
14. A system for obtaining state information of a battery, the system comprising: 
 at least one first harness cable connected to the battery and configured to obtain at least one signal indicating the state information; 
 a first junction box comprising at least one fuse allowing the at least one signal input through the first harness cable to pass through, the first junction box configured to output the at least one signal having passed through the fuse; and 
 an interface device configured to convert the at least one signal input from the first junction box into at least one digital data and output the at least one converted digital data to the outside.
15. The system of claim 14, wherein the state information includes at least one of voltage information and temperature information of the battery, and
 the signal includes at least one of a first signal indicating the voltage information and a second signal indicating the temperature information.
16. The system of claim 14, wherein the battery comprises a plurality of modules, and
 the at least one first harness cable comprises a plurality of harness cables configured to obtain a plurality of signals indicating the state information for the plurality of modules from the plurality of modules, respectively.
17. The system of claim 16, wherein the interface device comprises: 
 input ports configured to receive the plurality of signals from the first junction box, respectively; and 
 at least one analog-digital converter configured to convert the plurality of signals into the at least one digital data, respectively.
18. The system of claim 17, wherein the interface device outputs the at least one digital data based on a control area network (CAN) protocol,
the system further comprising: 
 a first LED indicating a communication state based on the CAN protocol; and 
 a second LED indicating an operation state of the at least one analog-digital converter.
19. The system of claim 14, wherein the at least one fuse is configured to protect the interface device from a short circuit resulting from the at least one signal.
20. The system of claim 16, wherein the first junction box comprises: 
 a plurality of input ports connected to the plurality of harness cables to receive the plurality of signals, respectively; and 
 a plurality of output ports configured to output the plurality of signals to the interface device, respectively.
21. The system of claim 14, wherein one end of the at least one first harness cable includes a first connector for connection with the battery and another end thereof includes a second connector for connection with the first junction box, and
 at least one of the first connector and the second connector is attahced with a protective cap for safety.
22. The system of claim 14, further comprising: 
 a second junction box connected to the battery through at least one second harness cable; and 
 an AC impedance analyzer configured to detect an AC impedance of the battery through the second junction box, 
 wherein the second junction box comprises a circuit configured to detect the AC impedance.
23. The system of claim 22, further comprising: 
 an insulation resistor configured to measure an insulation resistance of the battery; and 
 a voltage meter configured to measure a voltage of the battery, 
 wherein the insulation resistor and the voltage meter are connected to the battery through the second junction box.

Title: Apparatus for battery diagnosis
Inventor:
MYUNG, HUI GYEONG
LEE, YOUNG JAE
HONG, YEONG JIN
LEE, SUNG-GEUN
Abstract: Provided is a battery diagnostic apparatus for diagnosing a condition of a battery which comprises: a charging and discharging device for charging or discharging a battery; an AC impedance analyzer for measuring AC impedance of the battery; a control unit for controlling an operation of the charging and discharging device or the AC impedance analyzer; and a diagnosis unit for diagnosing a condition of the battery based on a capacity value, a DC resistance value, or the AC impedance of the battery.
Claims:
1. A battery diagnosis apparatus connected to a battery, the battery diagnosis apparatus comprising: a charger configured to charge or discharge the battery; an alternating-current impedance analyzer configured to measure an alternating-current impedance considering a temperature of the battery; a controller configured to control an operation of the charger or the alternating-current impedance analyzer; a controller configured to be connected to the controller and the charger, A first connection unit including a circuit for charging or discharging the battery by the charger controlled by the controller; a diagnosis unit for diagnosing a state of the battery based on at least one of a capacity, a direct current resistance, and an alternating current impedance of the battery; A power supply configured to convert external power into voltage and current required by a battery management system of the battery and supply power to the battery management system; And a second connector connected to the controller and the power supply, the second connector being a circuit for the power supply to supply power to the battery management system under the control of the controller, wherein the diagnosis unit receives identification information of the battery, performs an operation on data received from the charger or the alternating-current impedance analyzer, And determines at least one of a State of Charge (SoC), a State of Health (SoH), a State of Power (SoP), and a State of Balance (SoB) of the battery compared to reference data corresponding to identification information of the battery.
2. The battery diagnosis apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the charger/discharger includes a temperature measuring device for measuring a temperature of the battery.
3. The battery diagnosis apparatus of claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance analyzer measures the alternating-current impedance by measuring at least one of a resistor, an inductor, and a capacitor at a reference frequency or a reference frequency range, and configuring an equivalent circuit corresponding to the measured resistor, inductor, and capacitor.
4. The battery diagnostic device according to claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance analyzer includes a temperature measurer that measures a temperature of the battery.
5. The battery diagnosis apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the diagnosis unit diagnoses the state of the battery by comparing reference data corresponding to the identification information with data received from the alternating-current impedance analyzer.
6. The battery diagnostic device according to claim 1, wherein the controller controls the charger and discharger to measure the capacitance and the direct-current resistance.
7. The battery diagnostic device of claim 1, further comprising a battery interface connected to the controller and the terminals of the battery, and configured to measure a temperature and a voltage of the battery.
8. The battery diagnosis apparatus of claim 1, further comprising: a voltmeter for measuring a voltage of a connection circuit to check whether the battery is connected to at least one of the charger, the first connection portion, and the MSD.
9. The battery diagnosis apparatus according to claim 1, further comprising a second diagnosis unit configured to check whether an appearance of the battery or an electrolyte solution of the battery is leaked.

Title: Battery internal short-circuit resistance identification method
Inventor:
LIU LISHUO
FENG XUNING
HAN XUEBING
LU LANGUANG
OUYANG, Minggao
Abstract: The invention provides a battery internal short-circuit resistance identification method. The battery internal short-circuit resistance identification method comprises the following steps: processinga first battery roll core to obtain an internal short-circuit battery corresponding to a preset internal short-circuit type; measuring the alternating-current impedance of the internal short-circuit battery by using electrochemical equipment to obtain first alternating-current impedance data; performing calculation according to the first alternating-current impedance data and a first equivalent circuit model corresponding to a pre-established internal short-circuit battery to obtain the internal short-circuit internal resistance of the internal short-circuit battery, wherein the first equivalent circuit model is obtained by connecting ohmic internal resistance with diffusion impedance in series and then connecting in parallel with the internal short-circuit internal resistance according tothe ohmic internal resistance, the diffusion impedance and the internal short-circuit internal resistance, and the parameters of the ohmic internal resistance and the diffusion impedance in the firstequivalent circuit model are determined according to a battery without internal short circuit. According to the method, the internal short-circuit battery is manufactured, and real internal short circuit is triggered inside the battery in order to obtain the real resistance of the internal short-circuit process. Meanwhile, the equivalent circuit model of the internal short-circuit battery is established according to the battery without internal short circuit, so that the identification precision of the internal short-circuit resistance is improved.

Title: Battery monitoring device, integrated circuit, and battery monitoring system
Inventor:
MATSUKAWA KAZUO 
OKADA YU 
MAKABE YOSHIKAZU 
KOBAYASHI HITOSHI 
MISAKU TAKESHI 
FUJII KEIICHI
Abstract: A battery monitoring device (100) includes a first reference resistor (103) disposed in a path (P2) different from a path (P1) of current flowing from a battery to a load (102); a transistor (104) for passing current from the battery to the first reference resistor (103); and an integrated circuit (105). The integrated circuit (105) includes: a current measurement unit (112) that measures a first current flowing through the first reference resistor (103); a voltage measurement unit (115) that measures a first voltage of the battery (B); and a first calculation unit (118) that calculates an AC impedance of the battery based on the first current measured and the first voltage measured.
Claims:
1. A battery monitoring device, comprising: 
 a resistor disposed in a path different from a path of current flowing from a battery to a load; 
 a transistor for passing current from the battery to the resistor; and 
 an integrated circuit, wherein 
 the integrated circuit includes: 
  a current measurement unit that measures a first current flowing through the resistor; 
  a voltage measurement unit that measures a first voltage of the battery; and 
  a first calculation unit that calculates an AC impedance of the battery based on the first current measured and the first voltage measured.
2. The battery monitoring device according to claim 1, wherein
 the integrated circuit further includes a signal application unit that applies a control signal to a control terminal of the transistor, and
 the signal application unit applies the control signal having a plurality of frequency components to the control terminal.
3. The battery monitoring device according to claim 2, wherein
 the signal application unit is capable of changing a frequency and a voltage value of the control signal.
4. The battery monitoring device according to claim 2 or claim 3, wherein
 the control signal has a burst waveform.
5. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 4, wherein
 the integrated circuit further includes a signal generation unit that generates a first signal which is a sine wave; and
 a phase shift unit that shifts a phase of the first signal by 90 degrees to generate a second signal.
6. The battery monitoring device according to claim 5, wherein
the first calculation unit: 
 converts the first current into a second current which is a complex current, by multiplying each of the first signal and the second signal generated and the first current measured; and 
 calculates the AC impedance based on the second current.
7. The battery monitoring device according to claim 5 or claim 6, wherein
the first calculation unit: 
 converts the first voltage into a second voltage which is a complex voltage, by multiplying each of the first signal and the second signal generated and the first voltage measured; and 
 calculates the AC impedance based on the second voltage.
8. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 7, wherein
 the integrated circuit further includes a second calculation unit that calculates at least one of a state of charge (SOC) or a state of health (SOH) of the battery using the AC impedance calculated.
9. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 8, wherein
 the first calculation unit further includes a Kalman filter unit that calculates a low frequency impedance using at least one of a charging current during charging of the battery or a discharging current during discharging of the battery.
10. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 9, wherein
 the integrated circuit further includes a second temperature measurement unit that measures a temperature of the resistor, and
 the first calculation unit calculates the AC impedance by further using the temperature of the resistor that was measured.
11. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 10, wherein
 the integrated circuit further includes a temperature control unit that controls a temperature of the resistor to be constant.
12. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 11, wherein
 the first calculation unit calculates the AC impedance during charging of the battery.
13. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 12, wherein
 the first calculation unit calculates the AC impedance during discharging of the battery.
14. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 13, wherein
 the first calculation unit calculates the AC impedance during a stoppage of charging and discharging of the battery.
15. The battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 14, wherein
 the battery is one of a plurality of batteries included in a battery pack.
16. An integrated circuit, comprising: 
 a signal application unit that applies a control signal to a control terminal of a transistor for passing a current from a battery to a resistor disposed in a path different from a path of current flowing from the battery to a load; 
 a current measurement unit that measures a first current flowing through the resistor; 
 a voltage measurement unit that measures a first voltage of the battery; and 
 a first calculation unit that calculates an AC impedance of the battery based on the first current measured and the first voltage measured.
17. The integrated circuit according to claim 16, wherein
 the battery is one of a plurality of batteries included in a battery pack, and
 the voltage measurement unit includes a plurality of analog-to-digital (AD) converters each for measuring the voltage of a different one of the plurality of batteries,
 the integrated circuit further comprising:
 a reference bias generation unit that supplies a common reference voltage to the plurality of AD converters.
18. The integrated circuit according to claim 16 or claim 17, wherein
 the battery is one of a plurality of batteries included in a battery pack, and
 the voltage measurement unit includes a plurality of analog-to-digital (AD) converters each for measuring the voltage of a different one of the plurality of batteries,
 the integrated circuit further comprising:
 a timing signal generation unit that supplies each of the plurality of AD converters with a timing signal for synchronizing measurement timings of the plurality of AD converters.
19. A battery monitoring system, comprising: 
 a plurality of battery monitoring devices each of which is the battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 15; and 
 an integrated control unit that obtains the AC impedance from each of the plurality of battery monitoring devices.
20. A battery monitoring system, comprising: 
 the battery monitoring device according to any one of claims 1 to 15; and 
 a server device disposed at a location away from the battery monitoring device, wherein 
 the server device obtains the AC impedance from the battery monitoring device.

Title: Online battery pack maintenance system
Inventor:
HAO SHUXING
QI TIEDONG
LIANG CHAOHUI
Abstract: The invention provides an online battery pack maintenance system which is configured to maintain a battery pack composed of a plurality of batteries connected in series and in a float-charged state. The online battery pack maintenance system includes a monitoring terminal for detecting the operation of each battery in real time and issuing charging instructions and discharging instructions; and anactivation device connected to an AC grid and in communicative connection with the monitoring terminal. The monitoring terminal has a battery information storage section, an operation information acquisition section, an operation information storage section, an information identification section, an information judging section, a monitoring-side communication section, and an information processing unit. The activation device includes an activation-side receiving section, an operation control section, a state switch section, and a charging/discharging section. The online battery pack maintenance system can automatically activate the deteriorated battery to improve the reliability and the service life of the battery pack. Moreover, the energy of the charging process comes from the AC grid,and the energy is fed to the AC grid during the discharging process, thereby reducing energy consumption and saving energy.
Claims:
1. An online maintenance system for a secondary battery pack which is in a state of being float-charged by a charging device connected to an ac power grid and is constituted by a plurality of secondary batteries connected in series with each other, comprising:
 the monitoring terminal is used for detecting the operation of each storage battery in real time and sending a charging instruction and a discharging instruction; and
 an activation device connected with the AC power grid and in communication connection with the monitoring terminal,
 wherein the monitoring terminal is provided with a battery information storage part, an operation information acquisition part, an operation information storage part, an information identification part, an information judgment part, a monitoring side communication part and an information processing part,
 the activation device is provided with an activation side receiving part, an operation control part, a state switch part and a charging and discharging part,
 the battery information storage part stores battery information of all the storage batteries, the battery information at least comprises battery identification numbers of the storage batteries and corresponding rated voltages, theoretical working voltage ranges, theoretical capacity ranges, theoretical impedance ranges, theoretical discharge voltages and theoretical charge voltages,
 the operation information acquisition part acquires the operation information of each storage battery in real time, the operation information comprises the operation time of the storage battery and the corresponding working voltage and working current,
 the operation information storage unit stores the operation information of all the storage batteries in association with each other,
 the information identifying section identifies the operating voltage at the present time from each of the operation information stored in the operation information storing section and takes the operating voltage as a present operating voltage,
 the information judging section judges whether the current operating voltage is greater than or less than the corresponding theoretical operating voltage range,
 when the information judgment part judges that the current working voltage is larger than the corresponding theoretical working voltage range, the monitoring side communication part sends one discharge instruction to the activation device as a first discharge instruction,
 when the activation side receiving part receives the first discharge instruction, the operation control part controls the state switch part to work to electrically connect the storage battery with the charge and discharge part and controls the charge and discharge part to discharge the storage battery to the corresponding theoretical discharge voltage,
 the information identifying section identifies operation information during discharge as first operation information from the operation information stored in the operation information storage section,
 the information processing section processes the first operation information to obtain a capacity and an impedance of the storage battery, and takes the capacity and the impedance as a first present capacity and a first present impedance, respectively,
 the information judgment section judges whether the first present capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range and judges whether the first present impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range,
 upon the information judgment section judging that the first present capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range or the present impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range, the monitor-side communication section transmits one of the charge commands as a first charge command and one of the discharge commands as a new first discharge command to the activation device,
 when the activation-side receiving unit receives the first charge command and the new first discharge command, the operation control unit controls the charge/discharge unit to output a charge voltage corresponding to the rated voltage of the battery according to the first charge command to charge the battery to the corresponding theoretical charge voltage, and then controls the charge/discharge unit to discharge the battery to the corresponding theoretical discharge voltage according to the new first discharge command,
 when the information judgment part judges that the current working voltage is smaller than the corresponding theoretical working voltage range, the monitoring side communication part sends one charging instruction to the activation device as a second charging instruction,
 when the activation-side receiving unit receives the second charging command, the operation control unit controls the state switching unit to operate to electrically connect the battery to the charging/discharging unit, controls the charging/discharging unit to output a charging voltage corresponding to the rated voltage of the battery, and charges the battery to the corresponding theoretical charging voltage,
 the information identifying part identifies operation information during charging as second operation information from the operation information stored in the operation information storing part,
 the information processing section processes the second operation information to obtain a capacity and an impedance of the storage battery, and takes the capacity and the impedance as a second present capacity and a second present impedance, respectively,
 the information judgment section judges whether the second present capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range and judges whether the second present impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range,
 upon the information judgment section judging that the second present capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range or the second present impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range, the monitor-side communication section transmitting one of the discharge commands as a second discharge command and one of the charge commands as a new second charge command to the activation device,
 when the activation-side receiving unit receives the second discharge command and the new second charge command, the operation control unit controls the charge/discharge unit to discharge the battery to the corresponding theoretical discharge voltage according to the second discharge command, and then controls the charge/discharge unit to output a charge voltage corresponding to the rated voltage of the battery according to the new second charge command to charge the battery to the corresponding theoretical charge voltage.
2. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 1, wherein:
 wherein the monitoring terminal is also provided with a counting part,
 when the information judging part judges that the current working voltage is larger than the corresponding theoretical working voltage range, the counting part counts the discharging times of the storage battery to obtain the current discharging times every time the storage battery is discharged,
 once the information judgment section judges that the first present capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range or the first present impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range, the information judgment section further judges whether the present discharge number is smaller than a predetermined discharge number,
 the monitoring-side communication section transmits the first charge instruction and the new first discharge instruction to the activation device upon the information judgment section judging that the current discharge number is smaller than the predetermined discharge number,
 when the information judging part judges that the current working voltage is smaller than the corresponding theoretical working voltage range, the counting part counts the charging times of the storage battery to obtain the current charging times every time the storage battery is charged,
 once the information determination portion determines that the second current capacity is smaller than the corresponding theoretical capacity range or the second current impedance is larger than the corresponding theoretical impedance range, the information determination portion further determines whether the current number of charges is smaller than a predetermined number of charges,
 the monitoring-side communication section transmits the second discharge instruction and the new second charge instruction to the activation device, upon the information determination section determining that the current number of times of charging is smaller than the predetermined number of times of charging.
3. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 2, wherein:
 wherein the monitoring terminal further comprises a monitoring side screen storage section, a monitoring side input display section, a monitoring side display control section, and a monitoring side flag setting section,
 the monitoring side picture storage part stores a monitoring picture of the monitoring side battery pack, the monitoring picture of the monitoring side battery pack contains a monitoring side battery state display area,
 the monitoring side input display part displays the monitoring side battery pack monitoring screen and displays the battery identification numbers of all the storage batteries in the monitoring side battery state display area,
 once the information judgment part judges that the current discharge frequency is greater than the preset discharge frequency, the monitoring side display control part controls the monitoring side mark setting part to mark the battery identification number corresponding to the storage battery as a first abnormal mark, controls the monitoring side input display part to redisplay the changed monitoring screen of the monitoring side battery pack,
 once the information judgment part judges that the current charging frequency is greater than the preset charging frequency, the monitoring side display control part controls the monitoring side mark setting part to mark the battery identification number corresponding to the storage battery as a second abnormal mark, and controls the monitoring side input display part to redisplay the changed monitoring picture of the monitoring side battery pack.
4. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 3, wherein:
 wherein the monitoring terminal is also provided with a monitoring side mark deleting part,
 the monitor side screen storage section further stores a monitor side flag deletion confirmation screen,
 the monitoring side battery pack monitoring picture also comprises a monitoring side mark deleting key,
 when the monitor-side mark deletion key is selected, the monitor-side input display unit displays the monitor-side mark deletion confirmation screen, displays the marked battery identification number on the monitor-side mark deletion confirmation screen, and allows an operator to select the battery identification number requiring mark deletion,
 once the operator selects the battery identification number, the monitoring side display control unit controls the monitoring side mark deletion unit to delete the first abnormal mark or the second abnormal mark corresponding to the battery identification number, and controls the monitoring side input display unit to redisplay the modified monitoring screen of the monitoring side battery pack.
5. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 3, wherein:
 wherein the monitoring side picture storage part also stores a monitoring side battery operation information display picture,
 the monitoring side battery pack monitoring picture also comprises a monitoring side battery operation information display key corresponding to the battery identification number,
 the monitoring side input display part displays the monitoring side battery operation information display key in the monitoring side battery state display area,
 once the monitoring-side battery operation information display key is selected, the monitoring-side display control section controls the monitoring-side input display section to display the monitoring-side battery operation information display screen and display the operation information corresponding to the storage battery in the monitoring-side battery operation information display screen.
6. The battery pack online maintenance system of claim 4, further comprising:
 at least one user terminal, respectively in communication connection with the monitoring terminal, held by the operator, each user terminal having a unique user terminal identification code,
 wherein the user terminal has a user-side screen storage section, a user-side input display section, a user-side display control section, a user-side communication section, and a user-side flag setting section,
 the monitor terminal further has a performance state setting section and an abnormal battery information storage section,
 the battery information also includes performance status information,
 the user side picture storage part stores a user side battery pack monitoring picture which contains a user side battery state display area,
 the user-side input display section displays the user-side battery pack monitoring screen and displays the battery identification numbers of all the storage batteries in the user-side battery state display area,
 when the information determination section determines that the current discharge count is greater than the predetermined discharge count or the current charge count is greater than the predetermined charge count, the performance state setting section sets the performance state information of the storage battery to a first abnormal state or a second abnormal state, and the abnormal battery information storage section stores all the performance state information set to the first abnormal state and the second abnormal state and the corresponding battery identification numbers in association with each other to form abnormal battery information,
 the monitoring side communication part transmits the abnormal battery information to the user terminal,
 upon receipt of the abnormal battery information by the user-side communication portion, the user-side display control portion controls the user-side flag setting portion to mark the battery identification number of the secondary battery corresponding to the performance state information set to the first abnormal state as a first abnormal battery flag, mark the battery identification number of the secondary battery corresponding to the performance state information set to the second abnormal state as a second abnormal battery flag, and controls the user-side input display portion to display the modified user-side battery pack monitoring screen.
7. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 6, wherein:
 wherein the user terminal further has a user-side flag deleting section,
 the user-side picture storage section further stores a user-side mark deletion confirmation picture,
 the user side battery pack monitoring picture also has a user side marker delete key,
 when the user-side mark deletion key is selected, the user-side input display unit displays the user-side mark deletion confirmation screen and displays the marked battery identification number on the user-side mark deletion confirmation screen to allow an operator to select the battery identification number requiring mark deletion,
 once the battery identification number is selected by the operator, the user-side display control unit controls the user-side mark deletion unit to delete the first abnormal battery mark or the second abnormal battery mark corresponding to the battery identification number, and controls the user-side input display unit to redisplay the changed user-side battery pack monitoring screen.
8. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 7, wherein:
 wherein the user terminal further has a marker deletion information generation section,
 the marker deletion information generation unit generates marker deletion information including the battery identification number when the operator selects the battery identification number,
 the user side communication part sends the mark deleting information to the monitoring terminal,
 once the monitoring side communication unit receives the marker deletion information, the monitoring side display control unit controls the monitoring side marker deletion unit to delete the first abnormal battery marker or the second abnormal battery marker corresponding to the battery identification number stored in the marker deletion information, and controls the monitoring side input display unit to redisplay the modified monitoring screen of the monitoring side battery pack.
9. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 6, wherein:
 wherein, the communication mode between the user terminal and the monitoring terminal is a wireless network,
 and the communication mode between the activation device and the monitoring terminal is a wired network.
10. The battery pack online maintenance system according to claim 1, wherein:
 wherein the charge and discharge part is composed of a bidirectional AC/DC conversion unit and a bidirectional DC/DC conversion unit connected in series with each other,
 the bidirectional AC/DC conversion unit is connected with the alternating current power grid,
 the bidirectional DC/DC conversion unit is connected with the state switch part.

Title: Method for calibrating temperature-sensitive frequency band by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy characteristic quantity in whole life cycle of battery
Inventor:
WANG LIMEI
QIAO SIBING
SONG MINGCHAO
LI GUOCHUN
ZHAO XIULIANG
PAN, Chaofeng
Abstract: The invention discloses a method for calibrating a temperature-sensitive frequency band by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy characteristic quantity in a whole life cycle of a battery. The method comprises the following steps: (1) obtaining an electrochemical impedance phase shift value, in which an electrochemical workstation carries out an EIS test on four single batteries with different health states at ambient temperatures of 5 DEG C, 25 DEG C and 55 DEG C and in a 0-100% SOC range to obtain electrochemical impedance phase shift values with different temperatures, different statesof charge and different health states; (2) analysis on characteristic of the electrochemical impedance phase shift value by respectively analyzing the relationship between an electrochemical impedance phase shift value and the health state and the relationship between the electrochemical impedance phase shift value and a state of charge within a test excitation frequency range, and searching a frequency interval with the minimum interference of the state of health and the state of charge on the phase shift value; and (3) determining a temperature sensitive frequency interval by collecting theelectrochemical impedance phase shift values of the battery at the temperatures of 5 DEG C, 10 DEG C, 15 DEG C, 20 DEG C, 25 DEG C, 30 DEG C, 35 DEG C, 40 DEG C, 45 DEG C, 50 DEG C and 55 DEG C whenthe state of charge is 50%, and searching the frequency interval of the phase shift values sensitive to the internal temperature of the battery.

Title: Apparatus for diagnosis of battery
Inventor:
MYUNG, HUI GYEONG
LEE, YOUNG JAE
Abstract: The present invention relates to a simple battery diagnostic device. According to an embodiment of the present invention, the simple battery diagnostic device comprises: an AC impedance analyzer detecting battery AC impedance; a control unit selectively controlling operation of the AC impedance analyzer; a power supplier supplying power to a battery management system (BMS) of a battery; a server communication unit performing communication with an external server; and a BMS communication unit performing communication with the BMS of the battery.
Claims:
1. A battery management system (BMS) comprising: an AC Impedance Analyzer configured to detect an AC impedance of a battery; a controller configured to selectively control an operation of the AC Impedance Analyzer; a battery management system (BMS) of the battery: A battery management system (Battery Management System); a server communication unit configured to perform communication with an external server; and a BMS communication unit configured to perform communication with a battery management system of the battery.
2. The battery-to-battery diagnosis apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance analyzer detects a battery alternating-current impedance during battery charging, a battery alternating-current impedance during battery discharging, and a battery alternating-current impedance during battery charging and discharging.
3. The battery-to-battery diagnostics according to claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance analyzer detects battery alternating-current impedance by measuring at least one of a resistor (R), an inductor (L) and a capacitor (C) at a predetermined frequency or frequency range.
4. The battery-to-battery diagnosis apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance analyzer detects battery alternating-current impedance by measuring at least one of a resistor (R), an inductor (L), and a capacitor (C) at a predetermined frequency or frequency range and configuring an equivalent circuit.
5. The battery simplified diagnostic device of claim 1, wherein the alternating-current impedance-analyzer further comprises a temperature meter that measures a temperature of the battery.
6. The battery simplified diagnosis apparatus of claim 1, further comprising: a simplified diagnosis unit that calculates SoC, SoH, SoE, SoQ, SoB, SoH, and the like of the battery using data detected by the alternating-current impedance analyzer.
7. The battery simplified diagnostic device of claim 1, further comprising: a battery connector connected to the battery terminal to measure a temperature and a voltage of the battery.
8. The battery simplified diagnostic device of claim 1, further comprising an insulation resistor that measures insulation resistance of the battery.
9. The battery-to-battery diagnostics according to claim 1, further comprising: a first connector connected to the alternating-current impedance-analyzer and providing a connection circuit for detecting a battery alternating-current impedance by the alternating-current impedance-analyzer.
10. The battery-to-battery diagnostics according to claim 1, further comprising: a voltmeter that measures a voltage of the connection circuit to ascertain a connection relationship between the first connection and the battery and ascertain whether the battery is disconnected from the MSD.
11. The battery-to-battery diagnostics according to claim 1, further comprising: a second connection connected to the power supply and providing a connection circuit in which the power supply supplies power to a battery management system (BMS).
12. The battery simplified diagnostic device according to claim 1, further comprising an information receiving unit configured to receive unique information of the battery from the battery.
13. The battery simplified diagnostic device of claim 1, further comprising an auxiliary power supply unit configured to supply power to the battery diagnostic system.

Title: Method for determining an ageing condition of a battery, computer program, memory means, control device and vehicle
Inventor:
NOERING FABIAN 
WNSCH MARTIN 
JONAS KONSTANTIN 
FSSLER RAINER
Abstract: The present invention relates to a method for investigating an ageing condition of a battery (10) which is provided for power supply to an electric motor (20), comprising the steps of: determining at least one graphical progression of at least one operating parameter of the battery (10), checking the at least one graphical progression on at least one sinusoidal curve portion, if at least one sinusoidal curve portion is recognised, extracting the at least one sinusoidal curve portion, calculating an impedance of the battery (10) by means of impedance spectroscopy with reference to the at least one sinusoidal curve portion, and determining the ageing condition of the battery (10) with reference to the calculated impedance. The invention further relates to a computer program (30), a memory means, a control device (40) and a vehicle (100).

Title: Determining battery DC impedance
Inventor: PARYANI ANIL
Abstract: A controller for use in a battery charging system includes processing circuitry configured to perform certain tasks during battery charging operations, and other tasks during operational use of the battery. During a charging operation, the controller receives a measured DC impedance of a propulsion battery measured by a battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem, obtains a reference DC impedance of a hypothetical battery, and determines an impedance degradation factor of the propulsion battery using the measured DC impedance and the reference DC impedance. During operational use of the propulsion battery, the controller obtains an operational reference impedance of the propulsion battery, determines a real-time effective impedance for the propulsion battery based on the impedance degradation factor and the operational reference impedance, and generates a feed-forward parameter based on the real-time effective impedance.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A controller for use in a battery charging system, the controller including processing circuitry configured to:
  during a charging operation:
  initiate a relaxation period in response to a state of charge (S.O.C.) of a propulsion battery reaching a predetermined level during the charging operation;
   receive a D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery from a battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem, the D.C. impedance determined by the battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem during the charging operation;
   obtain a reference D.C. impedance, the reference D.C. impedance indicating an impedance associated with a new battery;
   determine an impedance degradation factor of the propulsion battery using the D.C. impedance and the reference D.C. impedance;
  during operational use of the propulsion battery:
  obtain an operational reference impedance of the propulsion battery;
   determine a real-time effective impedance for the propulsion battery based on the impedance degradation factor and the operational reference impedance; and
   generate a feed-forward parameter based on the real-time effective impedance.
2. The controller of claim 1, wherein:
 the propulsion battery includes a plurality of cells forming a multi-cell battery pack; and
  the processing circuitry is further configured to determine the impedance degradation factor for individual cells included in the multi-cell battery pack.
3. The controller of claim 1, wherein the processing circuitry is further configured to:
  determine that the propulsion battery is at a predetermined temperature prior to initiating the charging operation.
4. The controller of claim 1, wherein:
 the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery corresponds to a measurement made after the relaxation period.
5. The controller of claim 4, wherein the processing circuitry is further configured to:
  instruct a battery charger to provide a charging current to the propulsion battery until the S.O.C. the propulsion battery reaches the predetermined level.
6. The controller of claim 5, wherein the processing circuitry is further configured to:
  set the charging current provided to the propulsion battery to zero amperes for a duration of the relaxation period.
7. The controller of claim 5, wherein the processing circuitry is further configured to:
  obtain a first voltage of the propulsion battery upon conclusion of the relaxation period;
 instruct the battery charger to resume providing a charging current to the propulsion battery;
  obtain a second voltage of the propulsion battery after the battery charger has resumed providing the charging current to the propulsion battery; and
  determine the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery based, at least in part on a difference between the first voltage of the propulsion battery and the second voltage of the propulsion battery.
8. A method for use in a battery charging system controller, the method comprising:
 during a charging operation:
   initiating a relaxation period in response to a state of charge (S.O.C.) of a propulsion battery reaching a predetermined level during the charging operation;
   receiving at the battery charging system controller, a D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery from a battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem, the D.C. impedance determined by the battery data acquisition and
   monitoring subsystem during the charging operation;
  obtaining a reference D.C. impedance, the reference D.C. impedance indicating an impedance associated with a new battery;
   determining an impedance degradation factor of the propulsion battery using the D.C. impedance and the reference D.C. impedance; during operational use of the propulsion battery:
   obtaining an operational reference impedance of the propulsion battery;
  determining a real-time effective impedance for the propulsion battery based on the impedance degradation factor and the operational reference impedance; and
   generate a feed-forward parameter based on the real-time effective impedance.
9. The method of claim 8, wherein the propulsion battery includes a plurality of cells forming a multi-cell battery pack, the method further including:
  determining the impedance degradation factor for individual cells included in the multi-cell battery pack.
10. The method of claim 8, further comprising:
 determining that the propulsion battery is at a predetermined temperature prior to initiating the charging operation.
11. The method of claim 8, wherein the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery corresponds to a measurement made after a relaxation period.
12. The method of claim 11, further including:
 instructing a battery charger to provide a charging current to the propulsion battery until the S.O.C. of the propulsion battery reaches a predetermined level.
13. The method of claim 12, further including:

14. The method of claim 12, further including:
 obtaining a first voltage of the propulsion battery upon conclusion of the relaxation period;
  instructing the battery charger to resume providing a charging current to the propulsion battery;
 obtaining a second voltage of the propulsion battery after the battery charger has resumed providing the charging current to the propulsion battery; and
  determining the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery based, at least in part on a difference between the first voltage of the propulsion battery and the second voltage of the propulsion battery.
15. A battery charging system comprising:
  a battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem;
  a battery charger;
  a controller coupled to the battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem and the battery charger, the controller configured to:
  during a charging operation:
  initiate a relaxation period in response to a state of charge (S.O.C.) of a propulsion battery reaching a predetermined level during the charging operation;
   receive a D.C. impedance of a propulsion battery from the battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem;
   obtain a reference D.C. impedance, the reference D.C. impedance indicating an impedance associated with a new battery;
   determine an impedance degradation factor of the propulsion battery using the D.C. impedance and the reference D.C. impedance;
  during operational use of the propulsion battery:
  obtain an operational reference impedance of the propulsion battery;
   determine a real-time effective impedance for the propulsion battery based on the impedance degradation factor and the operational reference impedance; and
   generate a feed-forward parameter based on the real-time effective impedance.
16. The battery charging system of claim 15, wherein the controller is further configured to:

 wherein the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery corresponds to a measurement made by the battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem after the relaxation period.
18. The battery charging system of claim 17, wherein the controller is further configured to:

19. The battery charging system of claim 17, wherein the controller is further configured to:

 obtain a second voltage of the propulsion battery, the battery data acquisition and monitoring subsystem, after the battery charger has resumed providing the charging current to the propulsion battery; and
  determine the D.C. impedance of the propulsion battery based, at least in part on a difference between the first voltage of the propulsion battery and the second voltage of the propulsion battery.

Title: Method of operating a bidirectional DC DC converter
Inventor:
KRZYWINSKI EUGENE F 
REED WILLIAM B 
ALLEN JR JAMES A
Abstract: Method of operating a bidirectional DC DC converter that transfers power among an energy source (for example, a solar PV array), an energy storage system, and an energy usage system (for example, a DC AC inverter) to control the charge and discharge times of the energy storage system so that power harvested during peak energy source production can be stored and can later be released to the energy usage system at predetermined times.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method of operating a bidirectional DC DC converter connected to a power source, an energy storage system and an energy usage system, in response to voltage and current measurements at connections from sensors and business rules, to cause (a) power output from the power source to be transferred to and stored in the energy storage system, (b) the power output to be transferred to the energy usage system, and (c) power stored in the energy storage system to be transferred to the energy usage system, wherein the converter comprises a controller that receives the voltage and current measurements, the method comprising:
  step 1.1 wherein the controller obtaining the business rules;
 step 1.2 wherein the controller, in response to the voltage and current measurements, determining impedance and power at the connections;
  step 1.3 wherein, if the controller determines: (a) that the power source is not outputting power, and in response to one of the business rules, that transfer of power from the energy storage system is not allowed, or (b) that the energy usage system is off, then the controller causing an impedance of the converter to be so large that no power is transferred from the energy storage system to the energy usage system;
  step 1.4 wherein, if the controller determines that the power source is outputting power, and in response to a second one of the business rules that all that power output is to be transferred to the energy usage system, then the controller causing the impedance of the converter to be so large that no power is transferred from the energy storage system to the energy usage system;
  step 1.5 wherein, if the controller determines: (a) that the power source is outputting power, and in response to a third one of the business rules that none of that power output is to be transferred to energy usage system, or (b) that the energy usage system is off and that no power is to transferred to or from the energy storage system, then the controller causing the impedance of the converter to be so large that no power is transferred from the power source to the energy storage system and no power is transferred from the energy storage system to the energy usage system;
  step 1.6 wherein, if the controller determines that the power source is outputting power, and in response to a fourth one of the business rules that that power output is to be transferred to the energy usage system and to the energy storage system, then the controller causing the impedance of the converter to be set so that amounts of power transferred are in accord with further business rules; and
  step 1.7 wherein, if the controller determines that the power source is not outputting power, and in response to a fifth one of the business rules that power is be transferred from the energy storage system to the energy usage system; the controller causing the impedance of the converter to be set so that power is transferred from the energy storage system to the energy usage system.
2. The method of claim 1 which further comprises:
 the controller collecting operational data comprised of one or more of the amount of power transmitted from the power source to the energy usage system as a function of time, the amount of power transmitted from the power source to the energy storage system as a function of time, the amount of power transmitted from the energy storage system to the energy usage system as a function of time, the amount of power transmitted to the energy usage system as a function of time, voltage and current at the connection terminals as a function of time, and averages of the aforementioned amounts over time periods including hours, days and weeks; and
  the controller transmitting the operational data to a user using data lines and/or the internet.
3. The method of claim 1 wherein the business rules comprise one or more of: (i) a fraction of power output from the power source to be delivered to the energy storage system, (ii) a fraction of power from the energy storage system to be delivered to the energy usage system, (iii) a parameter indicating how much power the energy usage system can accept, (iv) a parameter indicating maximum power the energy storage system can accept, (v) Time of Day rules that specify when power output by the power source is to delivered as input to the energy storage system, and (vi) Time of Day rules that specify when power is to be discharged from the energy storage system and delivered to the energy usage system.
4. The method of claim 1 wherein:
 the converter comprises a first section magnetically coupled by a transformer to a second section and the power source and the energy usage system are connected to the first section and the energy storage system is connected to the second section;
  the first section comprises a first and a second controller operable switch and a voltage divider comprising a first and second capacitor; wherein: (a) a first end of the first capacitor is connected a first end of the first switch; (b) a second end of the first switch is connected to a first end of a primary winding of the transformer and to a first end of the second switch; (c) a second end of the primary winding is connected to a second end of the first capacitor and a first end of the second capacitor; and (d) a second end of the second switch is connected to a second end of the second capacitor; and
  the second section comprises an inductor, a capacitor, and a third and a fourth controller operable switch; wherein: (a) a first end of the third switch is connected to a first end of a first secondary winding of the transformer; (b) a second end of the first secondary winding of the transformer is connected to a first end of the second secondary winding of the transformer and a first end of the inductor; (c) a second end of the inductor is connected to a first end of the capacitor; (d) a second end of the second secondary winding of the transformer is connected to a first end of the fourth switch; and (e) a second end of the third switch is connected to a second end of the fourth switch and a second end of the capacitor.
5. The method of claim 4 wherein step 1.3 further comprises the controller causing the first, the second, the third, and the fourth switches to be off, step 1.4 further comprises the controller causing the first, the second, the third, and the fourth switches to be off, and step 1.5 further comprises the controller causing the first, the second, the third, and the fourth switches to be off.
6. The method of claim 4 wherein step 1.1 comprises the controller obtaining the business rules: (a) as controller configuration parameters; (b) by input sent over data lines and/or over the internet; or (c) as a combination of the configuration parameters and the input.
7. The method of claim 4 wherein:
 the energy storage system comprises a battery system which includes a battery management system; and
  the controller communicating with the battery management system using a signal port to obtain battery information.
8. The method of claim 7 wherein the business rules and/or the battery information include: a state of health of the battery system, a battery system power charge limit, a battery system power discharge limit, a battery system power charge rate, a battery system power discharge rate, power stored in the battery system, and a portion of power output from the power source to divert to the energy storage system.
9. The method of claim 8 wherein step 1.6 further comprises:
  in response to business rules, the controller setting the impedance of the converter to divert a predetermined portion of power output from the power source to the energy storage system; and
  the controller monitoring the voltage and current at the connection to the energy storage system to determine whether the power transferred to the energy storage system or the power transfer rate exceed predetermined limits, if so, the controller causing the impedance of the converter to increase.
10. The method of claim 9 wherein step 1.6 further comprises the controller causing the first and second switches to be operated 180 degrees out of phase to each other and causing synchronous switching of the third and fourth switches.
11. The method of claim 9 wherein step 1.6 further comprises the controller causing the first and fourth switches to be simultaneously closed and the second and third switches to be simultaneously open, then causing the first and fourth switches to be simultaneously opened and the second and third switches to be simultaneously closed during a different time period, wherein the impedance of the converter is adjusted by varying the ratio of conduction time relative to the off time of the first, second, third and fourth switches, whereby causing the conduction time to be increased reduces the impedance of the converter and causing the conduction time to be reduced increases the impedance.
12. The method of claim 8 wherein step 1.7 further comprises:
  the controller monitoring the voltage and current at the connection to the energy storage system to determine whether the power transferred to the energy usage system or the power transfer rate exceed predetermined limits, if so, the controller causing the impedance of the converter to increase; and
  if the controller determines that the current flowing out of the connection exceeds a predetermined amount, the controller causing the impedance of the converter to increase by a second predetermined amount; and if the current flowing out of the connection is less than the predetermined amount, the controller causing the impedance of the converter to decrease by a third predetermined amount.
13. The method of claim 12 wherein step 1.7 further comprises the controller causing: the first and second switches to be off so they act as diodes, and causing the third and fourth switches: (a) to both be on for a first time period; (b) then the third switch to be on and the fourth switch to be off for a second time period; (c) then both be on for a third period, and (d) then the third switch to be off and the fourth switch to be on for a fourth period.
14. The method of claim 13 wherein the impedance of the converter is adjusted by varying the duration of the first and third periods, whereby causing the duration of the first and third periods to increase decreases the impedance and causing the duration of the first and third periods to decrease increases the impedance.
15. The method of claim 4 wherein the power source comprises a solar photovoltaic array.
16. The method of claim 4 wherein the energy power comprises a wind generation power system.
17. The method of claim 1 wherein:
 the energy storage system comprises a battery system which includes a battery management system; and
  the controller communicating with the battery management system using a signal port to obtain battery information.

Title: Internal impedance detection device and vehicle
Inventor:
TSUCHIYA SHINGO
KAMATA SEIJI
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide an internal impedance detection device of a secondary battery in a simple device configuration that can also be applied to a power control unit not equipped with a boost converter.
SOLUTION: An internal impedance detection device for detecting internal impedance of a secondary battery for outputting DC power to a power control unit at least equipped with an inverter for converting DC power to AC power and outputting it to a running motor of a vehicle includes: a component extraction part for capturing a battery voltage and a battery current of the secondary battery, extracting an AC voltage component from the battery voltage, extracting an AC current component from the battery current, and extracting a fundamental frequency component from the battery voltage or the battery current; and an impedance calculation part for calculating internal impedance of the secondary battery on the basis of the AC voltage component, AC current component, and fundamental frequency component extracted by the component extraction part.
SELECTED DRAWING: Figure 1
COPYRIGHT: (C)2019,JPO&INPIT
Claims:
1. An internal impedance detection device that detects an internal impedance of a secondary battery that outputs DC power, the secondary battery being connected to a power control unit including at least an inverter that converts DC power to AC power and outputs the AC power to a running motor of a vehicle, the device comprising: Capturing a battery voltage of the secondary battery and a battery current flowing in the secondary battery, and extracting an AC voltage component from the battery voltage; A component extraction unit that extracts an alternating current component from the battery current and extracts a fundamental frequency component from the battery voltage or the battery current; and An impedance calculation unit that calculates an internal impedance of the secondary battery on the basis of the alternating current component and the fundamental frequency component.
2. The device according to claim 1, wherein the component extraction unit includes: a DC cutoff circuit that operates by high-voltage system power supplied from a high-voltage power supply system, and extracts the AC voltage component by removing the DC voltage component from the battery voltage, and extracts the AC current component by removing the DC current component from the battery current; and The AC voltage component and the AC current component input from the DC cutoff circuit; and A high-voltage system communication unit that converts the alternating current component and the fundamental frequency component into a signal of a predetermined communication format and outputs the signal, wherein the impedance computation unit is communicably connected to the high-voltage system communication unit in a power-sourced state, and operates by low-voltage system power; The internal impedance detection device according to claim 1, further comprising a low-voltage system calculation unit that calculates an internal impedance of the secondary battery on the basis of the AC voltage component, the AC current component, and the fundamental frequency component received from the high-voltage system communication unit.
3. An internal impedance detection device that detects an internal impedance of a secondary battery that outputs DC power, the secondary battery being connected to a power control unit including at least an inverter that converts DC power to AC power and outputs the AC power to a running motor of a vehicle, the device comprising: Capturing a vehicle speed detection signal indicating a battery voltage of the secondary battery, a battery current flowing in the secondary battery, and a vehicle speed of the vehicle; A component extraction unit that extracts an AC voltage component from the battery voltage, an AC current component from the battery current, and a fundamental frequency component from the vehicle speed detection signal; and An impedance calculation unit that calculates an internal impedance of the secondary battery on the basis of the alternating current component and the fundamental frequency component.
4. The internal impedance detection device according to claim 3, wherein the component extraction unit takes in an PWM signal input to the inverter as a control signal in addition to or instead of the vehicle speed detection signal, and extracts the fundamental frequency component on the basis of the vehicle speed detection signal and/or the PWM signal.
5. The device according to claim 1, wherein the component extraction unit includes: a DC cutoff circuit that operates by high-voltage system power supplied from a high-voltage power supply system, and extracts the AC voltage component by removing the DC voltage component from the battery voltage, and extracts the AC current component by removing the DC current component from the battery current; and A high-voltage system communication unit that operates by the high-voltage system power, extracts the AC voltage component and the AC current component input from the DC cutoff circuit, converts the AC voltage component and the AC current component into a signal of a predetermined communication format, and outputs the signal; and In a power-isolated state, communicably connected to the high-voltage system communication unit, and operated by low-voltage system power, receives the AC voltage component and the AC current component from the high-voltage system communication unit, and receives the vehicle speed detection signal or/ And a low-voltage system calculation unit that extracts fundamental frequency components from the PWM signal, wherein the impedance calculation unit is provided as a part of a function of the low-voltage system calculation unit.
6. A vehicle riding comfort evaluation apparatus, comprising: a running inverter that converts first direct current electrical power into alternating current electrical power and outputs the alternating current electrical power to a running motor of a vehicle; An inverter for generating power that converts an output of a generator driven by an engine into second DC power, the internal impedance detecting device detecting an internal impedance of a secondary battery that outputs and outputs first DC power and second DC power, the internal impedance detecting device comprising: a battery voltage of the secondary battery; A component extraction unit that takes in a battery current flowing in the secondary battery and an engine rotation detection signal indicating rotation of the engine, extracts an AC voltage component from the battery voltage, extracts an AC current component from the battery current, and extracts a fundamental frequency component from the engine rotation detection signal; An impedance computation unit that computes an internal impedance of the secondary battery on the basis of the AC voltage component, the AC current component, and the fundamental frequency component extracted by the component extraction unit.
7. Wherein the component extraction unit takes in a PWM signal input to the inverter as a control signal in addition to or instead of the engine rotation detection signal, and The internal impedance detection device according to claim 6, wherein the fundamental frequency component is extracted on the basis of the engine rotation detection signal or/and PWM signals.
8. The device according to claim 1, wherein the component extraction unit includes: a DC cutoff circuit that operates by high-voltage system power supplied from a high-voltage power supply system, and extracts the AC voltage component by removing the DC voltage component from the battery voltage, and extracts the AC current component by removing the DC current component from the battery current; and A high-voltage system communication unit that operates by the high-voltage system power, extracts the AC voltage component and the AC current component input from the DC cutoff circuit, converts the AC voltage component and the AC current component into a signal of a predetermined communication format, and outputs the signal; and In a power-isolated state, communicably connected to the high-voltage system communication unit, and operated by low-voltage system power, receives the AC voltage component and the AC current component from the high-voltage system communication unit, and generates the engine rotation detection signal or/ And a low-voltage system calculation unit that extracts fundamental frequency components from the PWM signal, wherein the impedance calculation unit is provided as a part of a function of the low-voltage system calculation unit.
9. A vehicle, comprising: the internal impedance detection device according to claim 1 or 2; the secondary battery; the power control unit; anda current detector that detects the battery current.
10. A vehicle, comprising: the internal impedance detection device according to any one of claims 3 to 5; the secondary battery; the power control unit; a current detector for detecting the battery current; and rotation detection means for outputting the vehicle speed detection signal and/or the PWM signal.
11. A vehicle, comprising: the internal impedance detection device according to any one of claims 6 to 8; the secondary battery; the power control unit; the generator; the engine; a current detector for detecting the battery current; androtation detection means for outputting the engine rotation detection signal and/or the PWM signal.

Title: Vertical circulating stereo garage wireless power supply system capable of charging electric car
Inventor:
SHEN JINFEI
WAN HAISONG
SHENG SHAOHUI
Abstract: The invention discloses a vertical circulating stereo garage wireless power supply system capable of charging an electric car. The vertical circulating stereo garage wireless power supply system capable of charging the electric car comprises a wireless power energy emission part arranged on a fixed machine frame and a wireless power energy receiving part arranged on a carrier hanging frame and used for receiving a wireless power energy signal. According to the vertical circulating stereo garage wireless power supply system capable of charging the electric car, two modes of wired charging and wireless charging can be applied to the electric car, and the problems that the charging mode power supply of a traditional stereo garage is unstable, and waterproofing is difficult are solved. The twomodes are adopted for charging, and the purpose that an existing stereo garage stably charging the electric car is achieved.

Title: Apparatus and system for storing battery and method for managing battery

Abstract: Embodiments of the present invention relate to a battery storage device and system, and a battery management method. The battery storage device can be disposed in a case through a battery management module and manage a state of a plurality of batteries by adjusting impedance of the plurality of batteries connected in at least one of a series and a parallel connection.
