Title: SOF monitoring method of vehicle power battery
Inventor:
XIA SHUNLI
LEI TING
ZHAO JIUZHI
QIN LIWEI
Abstract: The invention provides an SOF monitoring method of a vehicle power battery; and the method uses a mode of combining dynamic limit current monitoring with static limit current monitoring for fully considering the dynamic change of internal resistance of the battery in the working process to enable a monitored SOF value to become more accurate.

Title: Frequency based battery model parameter estimation
Inventor: LEE TAE-KYUNG
Abstract: A hybrid powertrain system includes a battery and at least one controller. The at least one controller is configured to determine instantaneous battery power limits during operation of the system using filtered battery voltage signals and current input signals. The at least one controller is further configured to separate medium-to-high frequency dynamics of the measured battery voltage. The filtering process, in certain examples, is realized using a low pass filter or a high pass filter. The at least one controller is further configured to correlate the medium-to-high frequency loads to estimate battery parameters and determine battery dynamics using, in one example, an Extended Kalman Filter.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A vehicle comprising: 
 a battery pack; and 
 at least one controller programed to 
  control operation of the battery pack in response to (i) parameter values indicative of an internal resistance of the battery pack that are based on terminal voltage data of the battery pack having frequency content less than a threshold frequency and (ii) parameter values indicative of an internal impedance of the battery pack that are based on terminal voltage data of the battery pack having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency.
2. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the internal resistance is an active electrolyte resistance of the battery pack.
3. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the internal impedance includes a capacitance and an active charge transfer resistance of the battery pack.
4. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the threshold frequency is based on electrochemical characteristics of the battery pack.
5. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the at least one controller is further programed to apply a frequency selective filter to obtain one of (i) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency or (ii) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency.
6. The vehicle of claim 5, wherein the at least one controller is further programed to generate the other of (i) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency and (ii) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency based on a difference between an input voltage of the battery pack and the one of (a) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency or (b) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency.
7. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the at least one controller is further programed to output a maximum discharge power available during predetermined periods based on the parameter values.
8. The vehicle of claim 1, wherein the at least one controller is further programed to output a maximum charge power available during predetermined periods based on the parameter values.
9. A battery management method comprising: 
 controlling operation of a battery pack in response to parameter values indicative of an internal resistance of the battery pack that are based on terminal voltage data of the battery pack having frequency content less than a threshold frequency and in response to parameter values indicative of an internal impedance of the battery pack that are based on the terminal voltage data having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein the internal resistance is an active electrolyte resistance of the battery pack.
11. The method of claim 9, wherein the internal impedance includes a charged capacitance and active charge resistance of the battery pack.
12. The method of claim 9, wherein the threshold frequency is based on electrochemical characteristics of the battery pack.
13. The method of claim 9, further comprising applying a frequency selective filter to obtain one of (i) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency or (ii) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency.
14. The method of claim 13, further comprising generating the other of (i) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency and (ii) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency based on a difference between an input voltage of the battery pack and the one of (a) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content greater than the threshold frequency or (b) the terminal voltage data of the battery back having frequency content less than the threshold frequency.
15. The method of claim 9, further comprising outputting a maximum discharge power available during predetermined periods based on the parameter values or a maximum charge power available during predetermined periods based on the parameter values.
16. A hybrid powertrain system comprising: 
 a battery pack having one or more battery cells; and 
 at least one controller programed to 
  implement a model of the battery pack, 
  filter terminal voltage data of the battery pack into high-frequency content having frequencies greater than a threshold and low-frequency content having frequencies less than the threshold, and 
  control operation of the battery pack in response to predicted available battery power derived from (i) parameter values indicative of an internal resistance of the battery pack that are based on the low-frequency content and (ii) parameter values indicative of an internal impedance of the battery pack that are based on the high-frequency content.
17. The hybrid powertrain system of claim 16, wherein the internal resistance is an active electrolyte.
18. The hybrid powertrain system of claim 16, wherein the internal impedance includes a capacitance and an active charge transfer resistance.
19. The hybrid powertrain system of claim 16, wherein the predicted available battery power includes a maximum discharge power available during predetermined periods.

Title: Method of diagnosing fault by using impedance of output terminal of power supply device for environmentally-friendly vehicle
Inventor:
LEE DONG JUN 
CHOI WON KYOUNG
Abstract: A method of diagnosing a fault by using impedance of an output terminal of a power supply device for an environmentally-friendly vehicle is provided. The method estimates impedance of the output terminal of the power supply device and diagnoses a fault by using the estimated impedance, thereby preventing an auxiliary battery from being discharged. Whether or not the fault is generated according to the impedance when the estimated impedance exceeds a reference value is determined.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method of diagnosing a fault by using impedance of an output terminal of a power supply device for an environmentally-friendly vehicle, wherein the power supply device includes a high voltage battery, an inverter for converting a direct-current voltage of the high voltage battery into an alternating current voltage and supplying the converted voltage to a motor for driving, a 12 V auxiliary battery for supplying a direct-current voltage to an electric component of the vehicle when the vehicle starts to drive and supplying a voltage necessary for operating a main relay of the high voltage battery, and a DC-DC converter for converting the direct-current voltage received from the high voltage battery to charge the auxiliary battery or to supply the converted voltage to a 12 V electric load, 
 the method comprising steps of: 
 estimating, by the power supply device, the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter; and 
 determining, by the power supply device, when the estimated impedance exceeds a reference value, that the fault is generated according to an increase in the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter, 
 wherein the step of estimating the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter includes steps of: 
 estimating, by the power supply device, a voltage difference between an output voltage of the DC-DC converter and an input voltage of an intelligent battery sensor (IBS) of an auxiliary battery; and 
 comparing, by the power supply device, the measured voltage difference and a charge/discharge current to calculate the impedance.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the step of determining that the fault is generated by the increase in the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter includes steps of: 
 increasing, by the power supply device, a fault count value when the estimated impedance exceeds the reference value; 
 determining, by the power supply device, that the fault is generated by the increase in the impedance when the fault count value is larger than a reference fault count value.
3. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 resetting a fault count value when the estimated impedance does not exceed the reference value.
4. The method of claim 1, wherein the DC-DC converter and the auxiliary battery are connected through a cable.
5. The method of claim 1, wherein the IBS diagnoses a general state of the auxiliary battery.
6. A method of diagnosing a fault by using impedance of an output terminal of a power supply device for an environmentally-friendly vehicle, wherein the power supply device includes a high voltage battery, an inverter for converting a direct-current voltage of the high voltage battery into an alternating current voltage to supply the converted voltage to a motor for driving, a 12 V auxiliary battery for supplying a direct current voltage to an electric component of the vehicle when the vehicle starts to drive and supplies a voltage necessary for operating a main relay of the high voltage battery, and a DC-DC converter for converting the direct current voltage received from the high voltage battery to charge the auxiliary battery or to supply the converted voltage to a 12 V electric load, 
 the method comprising steps of: 
 estimating, by the power supply device, the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter; and 
 determining, by the power supply device, when the estimated impedance exceeds a reference value, that the fault is generated according to an increase in the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter, 
 wherein the step of estimating the impedance of the output terminal of the DC-DC converter includes steps of: 
 measuring, by the power supply device, a voltage difference between an output voltage of the DC-DC converter and an input voltage of an electric load; and 
 comparing, by the power supply device, the measured voltage difference with a charge/discharge current to calculate the impedance.

Title: Apparatus for estimating voltage of hybrid secondary battery and method therefor
Inventor: JOE WON-TAE
Abstract: An apparatus and a method for estimating voltage of a hybrid secondary battery are provided, in which the hybrid secondary battery includes a first secondary battery and a second secondary battery having different electrochemical characteristics from each other and being connected in parallel with each other. The apparatus includes a sensor unit which measures an operating current of the hybrid secondary battery, and a control unit which estimates the voltage of the hybrid secondary battery using the operating current, and a voltage equation derived from a circuit model including a first circuit unit which simulates a voltage variation of the first secondary battery by a first open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a first impedance element, and a second circuit unit which is connected in parallel with the first circuit unit and simulates a voltage variation of the second secondary battery by a second open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a second impedance element.
Claims:
1. An apparatus for estimating voltage of a hybrid secondary battery, wherein the hybrid secondary battery comprises a first secondary battery and a second secondary battery having different electrochemical characteristics from each other and being connected in parallel with each other, the apparatus comprising: 
 a sensor unit configured to measure an operating current of the hybrid secondary battery; and 
 a control unit configured to estimate the voltage of the hybrid secondary battery using the operating current, and a voltage equation derived from a circuit model comprising a first circuit unit configured to simulate a voltage variation of the first secondary battery by a first open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a first impedance element, and a second circuit unit connected in parallel with the first circuit unit and configured to simulate a voltage variation of the second secondary battery by a second open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a second impedance element.
2. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the first secondary battery and the second secondary battery are packaged in different packages from each other as independent batteries, or packaged together in a single package.
3. The apparatus of claim 1 or 2, wherein at least one of the first secondary battery and the second secondary battery includes a plurality of unit cells or a plurality of battery modules.
4. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the control unit
 determines a first open-circuit voltage formed by the first open-circuit voltage element, based on a pre-defined first correlation between a first state of charge of the first secondary battery and the first open-circuit voltage, and
 determines a second open-circuit voltage formed by the second open-circuit voltage element, based on a pre-defined second correlation between a second state of charge of the second secondary battery and the second open-circuit voltage.
5. The apparatus of claim 4, wherein the first correlation is a look-up table or a look-up function obtained from an open-circuit voltage profile according to state of charge variation of the first secondary battery, and
 the second correlation is a look-up table or a look-up function obtained from an open-circuit voltage profile according to state of charge variation of the second secondary battery.
6. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the first impedance element and the second impedance element includes at least one resistor, at least one capacitor, at least one inductor, or a combination thereof.
7. The apparatus of claim 6, wherein the first impedance element and the second impedance element includes at least one RC circuit in which a resistor and a capacitor are connected in parallel, and a resistor connected in series thereto.
8. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the first open-circuit voltage element and the first impedance element, and the second open-circuit voltage element and the second impedance element are connected in series with each other.
9. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the control unit
 determines a first impedance voltage formed by the first impedance element, by using a first impedance voltage equation derived from a connection relation and electrical characteristic values of circuit elements included in the first impedance element, and
 determines a second impedance voltage formed by the second impedance element, by using a second impedance voltage equation derived from a connection relation and electrical characteristic values of circuit elements included in the second impedance element.
10. The apparatus of claim 1, wherein the control unit
 determines, from the circuit model, a first current and a second current flowing through the first circuit unit and the second circuit unit, respectively,
 time-updates a first state of charge of the first secondary battery and a second state of charge of the second secondary battery, by adding up the first current and the second current, respectively,
 time-updates a first impedance voltage formed by the first impedance element and a second impedance voltage formed by the second impedance element, by using the time-updated first state of charge and the time-updated second state of charge, and the first current and the second current,
 determines a first open-circuit voltage of the first secondary battery and a second open-circuit voltage of the second secondary battery corresponding to the time-updated first state of charge and the time-updated second state of charge, and
 estimates the voltage of the hybrid secondary battery by substituting the determined first open-circuit voltage and the determined second open-circuit voltage, the time-updated first impedance voltage and the time-updated second impedance voltage, and the measured operating current, into the voltage equation.
11. A method for estimating voltage of a hybrid secondary battery comprising a first secondary battery and a second secondary battery having different electrochemical characteristics from each other and being connected in parallel with each other, by using a circuit model comprising a first circuit unit configured to simulate a voltage variation of the first secondary battery by a first open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a first impedance element, and a second circuit unit connected in parallel with the first circuit unit and configured to simulate a voltage variation of the second secondary battery by a second open-circuit voltage element and optionally, a second impedance element, the method comprising: 
 measuring an operating current of the hybrid secondary battery; 
 determining, from the circuit model, a first current and a second current flowing through the first circuit unit and the second circuit unit, respectively; 
 time-updating a first state of charge of the first secondary battery and a second state of charge of the second secondary battery, by adding up the determined first current and the determined second current, respectively; 
 time-updating a first impedance voltage formed by the first impedance element and a second impedance voltage formed by the second impedance element, by using the time-updated first state of charge and the time-updated second state of charge, and the first current and the second current; 
 determining a first open-circuit voltage of the first secondary battery and a second open-circuit voltage of the second secondary battery corresponding to the time-updated first state of charge and the time-updated second state of charge, respectively; and 
 estimating the voltage of the hybrid secondary battery by substituting the determined first open-circuit voltage and the determined second open-circuit voltage, the time-updated first impedance voltage and the time-updated second impedance voltage, and the measured operating current, into a voltage equation derived from the circuit model.
12. The method according to claim 11, further including measuring an operation initiating voltage of the hybrid secondary battery; and
 determining initial conditions for the state of charge of the first secondary battery and the state of charge of the second secondary battery based on the states of charge corresponding to the operation initiating voltage.
13. The method according to claim 11, further including determining initial conditions for the first impedance voltage and the second impedance voltage.
14. The method according to claim 11, wherein the first current and the second current are respectively determined based on a first current distribution equation and a second current distribution equation, wherein the first and the second current distribution equations include input parameters including the first open-circuit voltage and the second open-circuit voltage, the first impedance voltage and the second impedance voltage, and the operating current.

16. A computer-readable recording medium recording therein a program for implementing the method as defined in claim 11.

Title: System for estimating real time catenary impedance using the synchronized measuring power data between operation train and substation
Inventor:
JUNG, Ho Sung
KIM, HYUNG-CHOL
CHANG SANG HOON
PARK, Young
SHIN, Seung-Kwon
Abstract: The present invention relates to a real-time catenary impedance calculation system using power data synchronized between a running vehicle and a substation which obtains power data of a vehicle running in a AC feeding system of catenary and a substation in real time, calculates an impedance of catenary based on the synchronized power data in real time, uses the calculated electric railway impedance to setting a protection region of AC feeding system protection relay and setting a informing function of failure point informing device, and easily predicts an electric railway impedance even if the railway conditions of the AC feeding system are changed, and provides the information. In order to achieve the purpose mentioned above, the present invention includes: a substation measurement system for measuring voltage information of feeding bus and current information of electric line and feeding line of uptrack/downtrack, and transmitting the measured voltage and current information and time information to a catenary impedance calculation unit; a vehicle measurement unit for measuring voltage and current information of the vehicle and transmitting the measured voltage and current information, time information and location information of running vehicle to the catenary impedance calculation unit; and the catenary impedance calculation unit for synchronizing the information measured through the substation measurement unit and vehicle measurement unit, calculating substation impedance and vehicle impedance based on the synchronized information, and calculating the final catenary impedance by distance.
Claims:
1. A substation measuring unit (100) that measures voltage information of the power supply bus, and current information of an electric lane line of an ascending/descending line and a power supply line, and transmits the measured voltage and current information to a line impedance calculating unit (300) including time information and voltage information; A vehicle measuring unit (200) that measures voltage and current information of the vehicle and transmits the measured voltage and current information to a line impedance calculating unit (300) including time information and position information of the moving vehicle; And synchronizing the information measured through the substation measuring unit (100) and the vehicle measuring unit (200) according to time information, calculating a substation impedance and a vehicle impedance based on the synchronized information, And a line impedance calculation unit (300) for calculating a line impedance for each final distance, wherein the line impedance calculation unit (300) is configured to calculate, based on time information transmitted from the substation measurement unit (100) and the vehicle measurement unit (200), A synchronizing module (310) for synchronizing information measured through the substation measuring unit (100) and the vehicle measuring unit (200) with time; a substation impedance calculating module (320) for calculating a substation impedance based on the synchronized information; A vehicle impedance calculation module (330) for calculating a vehicle impedance based on the synchronized information; and a line impedance calculation module (340) for calculating a line impedance for each distance finally; Wherein the line impedance calculation module (340) is configured to calculate, in a disconnection system, a difference between a substation impedance calculated through the substation impedance calculation module (320) and a vehicle impedance calculated through the vehicle impedance calculation module (330), A real-time electric vehicle line impedance calculation system using synchronized electric power data between a traveling vehicle and a substation, wherein the line impedance calculation system calculates the line impedance.
2. AMEND STATUS: Delete
3. AMEND STATUS: Delete
4. The vehicle impedance calculation device according to claim 1, wherein the vehicle impedance calculation module (330) is configured to accurately calculate the line impedance of an ascending line regardless of the magnitude of the vehicle impedance in a double line system of an ascending line and a descending line vertical tie system, A real time electric lane impedance calculation system using synchronized power data between a traveling vehicle and a substation, wherein the real time electric lane impedance calculation system calculates the vehicle impedance using a current measured at the substation other than the current measured at the vehicle.
5. The real-time electric lane line impedance calculation system using the synchronized electric power data between the traveling vehicle and the substation according to claim 1, wherein the line impedance calculation module (340) calculates the line impedance per distance regardless of the vehicle impedance according to the traveling of the vehicle.

Title: On-line secondary battery simplified impedance spectroscopy model parameter estimating method based on fractional order united Kalman filtering

Abstract: The invention discloses an on-line secondary battery simplified impedance spectroscopy model parameter estimating method based on fractional order united Kalman filtering, relates to an on-line estimation method of battery parameters, and aims to improve the accuracy, the estimation speed and the working condition adaptability of secondary battery parameter estimation. The method is based on a simplified battery impedance spectroscopy equivalent circuit model, a state equation and an observation equation required by an algorithm are established, the diffusion polarization end voltage (UW), the open-circuit voltage (OCVe), the internal ohm resistance (Ro) and the diffusion parameter (XW) of a battery are taken as the estimators by using a fractional order united Kalman filter, the end voltage (UL), the load current (IL) and the sampling time interval Ts being 1s which are measured in real time are taken as known amount, noise covariance is excited and measured according to the sensor precision selection process, and the estimation values of the open-circuit voltage (OCVe), the internal ohm resistance (Ro) and the diffusion parameter (XW) of a battery model are obtained. The on-line secondary battery simplified impedance spectroscopy model parameter estimating method is applicable to on-line estimation of secondary battery parameters.

Title: Online estimation method for direct current resistance of power battery of electric vehicle
Inventor:
DU CHANGQING
ZHANG CHI
ZHAO YIFAN
YAN FUWU
Abstract: The invention relates to an online estimation method for direct current resistance of a power battery of a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle or a pure electric vehicle. The online estimation method includes that in the process of charging through a vehicle-mounted charger, charging to appointed equally spaced SOC points in sequence in a constant-current charging mode, and then using a constant-voltage charging mode; when the current is reduced to an equalizing current designed by a monomer equalizer, casually opening and closing the equalizer of each monomer in sequence, using the equalizer to generate a composite pulse excitation on each monomer, recording the change curve of the terminal voltage thereof changed along with the time, substituting into a corresponding mathematical model of direct current resistance of the power battery to obtain the direct current resistance and open-circuit voltage of the battery, and calculating the direct current resistance and open-circuit voltage of a power battery pack according to the direct current resistance and open-circuit voltage of the battery. The online estimation method for the direct current resistance of the power battery of the electric vehicle is simple and reliable and has high practicability and performability.
Claims:
1. An online estimation method for direct current impedance and open-circuit voltage of a power battery pack of an electric automobile is characterized by comprising the following steps:
 charging the power battery through a vehicle-mounted charger, and charging at constant voltage and low current at preset equal-interval SOC points;
 constant current pulses in positive and negative 2 directions are generated by utilizing the opening and closing actions of the equalizer distributed to each battery monomer;
 collecting voltage signals of each battery monomer, and carrying out curve fitting on the change relation data of each monomer voltage to time to obtain a mixed pulse power characteristic curve;
 performing parameter identification on the obtained fitted curve, and calculating direct current impedance and open-circuit voltage parameters of each battery monomer;
 according to the connection form of the battery, the obtained battery monomer parameters are subjected to mathematical operation, so that the direct current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the whole power battery pack are obtained, specifically,
 the BMS estimates the dc impedance and the open circuit voltage of each battery cell using the following equations:

then, according to the connection form of the single batteries, the direct current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the whole battery pack are obtained through mathematical operation, and the specific calculation process is as follows:
 the total open circuit voltage of the battery pack is as follows:
 
 the total ohmic internal resistance and the polarization internal resistance are respectively as follows:
 
 
 the total polarization capacitance is:
 
 in the above formula, t1To start the pulse discharge start time, t2At the discharge cutoff time, t3At the start of the standing process, t4At the end of the stand, t5The pulse charging cut-off time; corresponding get t1The voltage value at the end of time is U1The value after the voltage dip is U1', the voltage value at the time t2 is U2,t3The voltage value at the moment is U3,t4The voltage value at the moment is U4,t5The voltage value at the moment is U5The voltage value after charging and standing is U6?
2. The on-line estimation method for the direct-current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the power battery pack of the electric automobile according to claim 1, characterized in that: the vehicle-mounted charger charges the power battery in a constant-current charging mode, calculates the charging electric quantity by an ampere-hour integration method, and changes the charging mode into a constant-voltage low-current charging mode when the power battery is charged to a preset equal-interval SOC point.
3. The on-line estimation method for the direct-current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the power battery pack of the electric automobile according to claim 1, characterized in that: the equalizer should employ a bi-directional buck-boost circuit to generate constant current pulses with plus and minus 2 directions.
4. The on-line estimation method of the direct current impedance and the open circuit voltage of the power battery pack of the electric automobile according to claim 3, characterized in that: the time of generating 2 pulse currents by the buck-boost circuit and the time of standing the intermediate equalizer are consistent with the pulse curve required by the mixed pulse power characteristic test.
5. The on-line estimation method for the direct-current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the power battery pack of the electric automobile according to claim 1, characterized in that: the voltage of the battery monomer is collected through the BMS collection unit, and data are transmitted to the BMS main control unit through the CAN network.
6. The on-line estimation method for the direct-current impedance and the open-circuit voltage of the power battery pack of the electric automobile according to claim 1, characterized in that: and taking the voltage after pulse discharge and standing and the voltage after pulse charge and standing as the open-circuit voltage of the battery at the time.

Title: Dehumidification element degradation detecting device, and dehumidification element degradation detecting method
Inventor:
MORIMURA, Hideyuki
NODA, Seiji
FURUKAWA Seiji
MIYA, Kazuhiro
KURAHASHI, Masato
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To enable performance evaluation of a dehumidification element with high accuracy, regardless of peripheral temperature and humidity.
SOLUTION: A dehumidification element degradation detecting device includes: an impedance measuring portion 8 connected to an anode 3 and a cathode 4, and measuring the impedance of a dehumidification element 5 by a frequency of 1 or more Hz; thermo-hygrometers 7a and 7b installed in a space with which the anode 3 and the cathode 4 of the dehumidification element 5 are contacted; and a performance degradation detecting portion 9 considering an average value of two absolute moisture contents calculated on the basis of measurement values of the thermo-hygrometers 7a and 7b as a peripheral absolute moisture content, and detecting performance degradation by comparing an impedance reference value of the dehumidification element which is measured and stored in a space of the same absolute moisture content as the peripheral absolute moisture content and has no performance degradation,with an impedance value measured by the impedance measuring portion 8.
COPYRIGHT: (C)2015,JPO&INPIT
Claims:
1. A dehumidification element deterioration detecting device that detects deterioration in performance of a dehumidification element constituted by a solid electrolyte membrane and an anode and a cathode provided on both sides of the solid electrolyte membrane, the device comprising: 2 temperature and humidity meters that are respectively installed in spaces with which the anode and the cathode of the dehumidification element are in contact and that respectively measure temperature and humidity of the spaces; and 2 temperature and humidity meters that are respectively connected to the anode and the cathode of the dehumidification element and that are connected to the anode and the cathode of the dehumidification element, An impedance measurement unit that measures an impedance of the dehumidification element; and a performance degradation detection unit that detects performance degradation of the dehumidification element using a measurement value of the temperature and humidity measured by the 2 temperature and humidity meters and a value of the impedance of the dehumidification element measured by the impedance measurement unit; The device according to claim 1, wherein the performance degradation detecting unit stores, in advance, as an impedance reference value, a measurement result of measuring an impedance value of the dehumidification element without performance degradation for each absolute moisture content in a space in which the measurement is performed; and Absolute moisture amounts of 2 spaces in which the anode and the cathode are in contact are calculated on the basis of the measurement values of the 2 temperature and humidity meters, and an average value of the absolute moisture amounts is taken as an absolute moisture amount in the vicinity of the dehumidification element, and Reads out the impedance reference value at the same absolute moisture level as the value of the ambient absolute moisture level; and detects performance degradation of the dehumidification element by comparing the value of impedance of the dehumidification element measured by the impedance measuring unit with the read out impedance reference value.
2. A dehumidification element deterioration detecting device that detects performance deterioration of a dehumidification element including a solid electrolyte membrane and an anode and a cathode provided on both sides of the solid electrolyte membrane, the device comprising: A temperature and humidity meter that measures temperature and humidity of the space; an impedance measuring unit that is connected to the anode and cathode of the dehumidification element and measures impedance of the dehumidification element; and A performance deterioration detection unit that detects performance deterioration of the dehumidification element using a measurement value of the temperature and humidity measured by the temperature and humidity meter and a value of impedance of the dehumidification element measured by the impedance measurement unit; Title: Apparatus and Method for Forecasting Life Cycle of Battery
Inventor:
LEE, JONG-HAK
KIM, TAE-HYUNG
IN, DONG SEOK
Kwon,Byung-Ki
Abstract: A device for predicting lifecycle of a battery which can predict the lifecycle of a battery during an operation of the battery according to an embodiment of the present invention includes an impedance value calculation unit for calculating a battery internal impedance value by each unit cycle; a trend function calculation unit for calculating a battery internal impedance trend function which takes the battery internal impedance as a variable with a cycle of the battery by using a battery internal impedance value calculated for each unit cycle when the cycle of the battery reaches a target cycle; and a battery lifecycle calculation unit for calculating the lifecycle of the battery by assigning the battery internal impedance value to the battery internal impedance trend function when the lifecycle of the battery ends.
Claims:
1. A battery pack comprising: an impedance value calculation unit configured to calculate a battery internal impedance value for each cycle; a trend function calculation unit configured to calculate a battery internal impedance trend function using the battery internal impedance value calculated for each cycle and the battery internal impedance as variables when the cycle of the battery reaches a target cycle; And a battery life calculation unit configured to calculate a life cycle of the battery by substituting a battery internal impedance value with the battery internal impedance trend function at the end of life of the battery, A first extraction unit configured to extract a magnitude and a phase of a current component at a target frequency from a reference current having a target frequency component; a second extraction unit configured to extract a magnitude and a phase of a voltage component at the target frequency from a voltage of the battery that varies due to application of the reference current; And a calculation unit configured to calculate an internal impedance value of the battery at the target frequency using a magnitude and a phase of a voltage component at the target frequency and a magnitude and a phase of a current component at the target frequency.
2. The battery life control device according to claim 1, wherein the battery life calculation unit is configured to calculate the battery life of the battery according to Eq. Calculate a battery internal impedance value at the end of the life of the battery using Zfrepresents a battery internal impedance value at the end of the battery life, and Z.irepresents a battery internal impedance value when the cycle of the battery is 0, and n represents a predetermined battery impedance value increase rate.
3. The battery life prediction device of claim 1, further comprising: a battery replacement determination unit configured to compare a current cycle of a battery with a life cycle of the battery to determine replacement of the battery if the current cycle of the battery is equal to or greater than the life cycle of the battery.
4. The battery life prediction device according to claim 1, wherein the trend function calculation unit calculates the trend function of the battery internal impedance by using battery internal impedance values calculated in m+ 1 cycles determined by dividing the target cycle by m among the internal impedance values calculated for each unit cycle.
5. The battery control device according to claim 1, wherein, when the unit cycle is k, the impedance value calculation unit calculates the battery internal impedance value for each time point when an accumulated discharge capacity of the battery becomes k times a nominal capacity of the battery, When the target cycle is p, calculate a trend function of the battery internal impedance every time point at which an accumulated discharge capacity of the battery becomes p times a nominal capacity of the battery.
6. The battery life predicting device according to claim 1, further comprising a reference current generating unit configured to generate the reference current and apply the reference current to the battery in order to calculate an internal impedance value of the battery during operation of the battery.
7. The battery life predicting device according to claim 6, wherein the target frequency component is a frequency component of a battery internal impedance value corresponding to a life of the battery in the spectrum of the battery internal impedance.
8. AMEND STATUS: Delete
9. A battery internal impedance calculation method comprising: calculating a battery internal impedance value at a target frequency for each unit cycle; calculating a battery internal impedance trend function using the battery internal impedance value calculated for each unit cycle when the battery cycle reaches the target cycle, Calculating a life cycle of the battery by substituting a battery internal impedance value at the end of life of the battery with the battery internal impedance trend function; and determining whether the battery is replaced by comparing a current cycle of the battery with the life cycle of the battery, Extracting a magnitude and a phase of a current component at a target frequency from a reference current having a target frequency component applied to the battery, and extracting a voltage component magnitude and a phase at the target frequency from a voltage of the battery that varies due to application of the reference current; And calculating a battery internal impedance magnitude at the target frequency by dividing a magnitude of a voltage component at the target frequency by a magnitude of a current component at the target frequency, Calculating a battery internal impedance phase at the target frequency by subtracting a phase of a current component at the target frequency from a phase of a voltage component at the target frequency.
10. The method according to claim 9, wherein in the step of calculating the battery internal impedance value, when the unit cycle is k, the battery internal impedance value is calculated for each time point when the accumulated discharge capacity of the battery becomes k times the nominal capacity of the battery, Wherein in the calculating the life of the battery, when the target cycle is p, a trend function of the battery internal impedance is calculated every time point when an accumulated discharge capacity of the battery becomes p times a nominal capacity of the battery.
11. AMEND STATUS: Delete

Title: Impedance measurement system and method for secondary batteries
Parent Assignee: TSINGHUA UNIVERSITY (CHINA), YIXING QINGNENG NEW ENERGY TECHNOLOGY
Assignee:
YIXING QINGNENG NEW ENERGY TECHNOLOGY
TSINGHUA UNIVERSITY
Inventor:
XIE XIAOFENG
GU AODA
PAN JIANXIN
DING XIAOLI
WANG SHUBO
Abstract: The invention discloses an impedance measurement system and method for secondary batteries and belongs to a battery measurement technology. The system comprises a battery module, a charging and discharging module, an alternating current frequency scanning module and a signal collecting and processing module. A 203c point of a 203 three-position switch of the charging and discharging circuit is connected with the negative electrode of the battery module 1, and by selecting a switch arm connected with the 203c point, the negative electrode of the battery module 1 is connected with a 202 electronic load and the positive electrode of the battery module 1 through a 203a point to form a discharging circuit. The impedance measurement system and method for the secondary batteries are applied to tests on impedance of the secondary batteries in the working state and can be used for measuring all the single secondary batteries contained in a secondary battery pack in parallel through multiple channels. The Ohm internal resistance, the electrochemical polarization impedance and the concentration polarization impedance of each secondary battery are tested out, the impedance of each secondary battery is analyzed, and the impedance measurement system and method are used for analyzing the charging and discharging performance of the batteries. The service life of the batteries is estimated, and the batteries can run more safely, stably and reliably.

Title: Storage-device-state detection method
Inventor: HEBIGUCHI HIROYUKI
Abstract: [Object] To provide to a storage device state detection method of accurately detecting the state of health (SOH) and state of charge (SOC) of a storage device. [Solution] In a state detection method, for a storage device (1), in which the SOH or SOC of the storage device (1) is inferred from the internal impedance of the storage device (1): the internal resistance of the storage device (1) is measured by using a signal with a first frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device (1) is reduced as a temperature is raised, and the initial SOH or initial SOC of the storage device (1) is calculated from the measured value of this internal resistance; the internal impedance of the storage device (1) is measured by using a signal with a second frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device (1) is increased as a temperature is raised, and the internal temperature of the storage device (1) is calculated from the measured impedance value of this internal impedance; and the SOH or SOC is inferred by using the calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOH or initial SOC.
Claims:
1. A storage device state detection method in which an SOH of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device is reduced as a temperature is raised, and an initial SOH of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device is increased as a temperature is raised, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOH is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOH.
2. A storage device state detection method in which an SOH of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency at which a capacitance component of the internal impedance of the storage device becomes more dominant than an inductance component, and an initial SOH of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency at which the inductance component of the internal impedance of the storage device becomes more dominant than the capacitance component, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOH is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOH.
3. A storage device state detection method in which an SOH of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency that an ion in the storage device is capable of following, and an initial SOH of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency that is hard for the ion in the storage device to follow, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOH is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOH.
4. A storage device state detection method in which an SOH of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency of 1 kHz or lower, and an initial SOH of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is calculated by using a signal with a second frequency of 10 kHz or higher, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOH is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOH.
5. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 4, characterized in that an SOC at a time of measuring the internal resistance is substantially the same at each time.
6. The storage device state detection method according to Claim 5, characterized in that the internal resistance is measured within a prescribed time after the storage device has been fully charged.
7. A storage device state detection method in which an SOC of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device is reduced as a temperature is raised, and an initial SOC of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency at which the internal impedance of the storage device is increased as a temperature is raised, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOC is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOC.
8. A storage device state detection method in which an SOC of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency at which a capacitance component of the internal impedance of the storage device becomes more dominant than an inductance component, and an initial SOC of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency at which the inductance component of the internal impedance of the storage device becomes more dominant than the capacitance component, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOC is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOC.
9. A storage device state detection method in which an SOC of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency that an ion in the storage device is capable of following, and an initial SOC of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a second frequency that is hard for the ion in the storage device to follow, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured impedance value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOC is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOC.
10. A storage device state detection method in which an SOC of a storage device is inferred from an internal impedance of a storage device, characterized in that: 
 an internal resistance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with a first frequency of 1 kHz or lower, and an initial SOC of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal resistance; 
 the internal impedance of the storage device is calculated by using a signal with a second frequency of 10 kHz or higher, and an internal temperature of the storage device is calculated from a measured value of the internal impedance; and 
 the SOC is inferred by using a calculated value of the internal temperature to correct the initial SOC.
11. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 10, characterized in that the internal resistance is measured before and after a large change of a current, and the internal resistance is obtained from before and after measured values that have been measured.
12. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 11, characterized in that: 
 the storage device is mounted in an automobile; and 
 the automobile is stopping during a measurement of the internal resistance.
13. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 12, characterized in that: 
 the storage device includes an anode collector, an electrolyte, a separator, and a cathode collector; and 
 the second frequency is a frequency at which at least one of the anode collector, the electrolyte, the separator, and the cathode collector is measured as a resistance in electronic conduction.
14. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 13, characterized in that a transient response signal induced by a pulse signal given to the storage is converted to a frequency component by a Fourier transform, the internal impedance at the second frequency is calculated, and a calculated value is used as the measured impedance value.
15. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 14, characterized in that the storage device is a secondary battery.
16. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 15, characterized in that noise at the second frequency, the noise being in a signal generated in the charging circuit, is removed by a low-pass filter provided between the storage device and a charging circuit connected to the storage device.
17. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 15, characterized in that noise at the second frequency, the noise being in a signal generated in the charging circuit, is removed by a low-pass filter provided between the storage device and a load connected to the storage device.
18. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 17, characterized in that the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with the second frequency, the signal being generated from a switch power supply for a power converter connected to the storage device.
19. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 15, characterized in that the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with the second frequency at which an impedance of the storage device is lower than an impedance, as viewed from the storage device, of a charging circuit connected to the storage device.
20. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 15, characterized in that the internal impedance of the storage device is measured by using a signal with the second frequency at which an impedance of the storage device is lower than an impedance, as viewed from the storage device, of a load connected to the storage device.
21. The storage device state detection method according to any of Claims 1 to 20, characterized in that a phase of a current and a phase of a voltage due to a signal with the second frequency are matched by a phase compensating circuit connected to the storage device.
22. The storage device state detection method according to Claim 21, characterized in that a resonant circuit is formed with the storage device and the phase compensating circuit.
23. The storage device state detection method according to Claim 21 or 22, characterized in that the phase compensating circuit includes a capacitor.
