Title: The real-time monitoring device of fourier transform electrochemical impedance and method.
Assignee: PUKYONG NATIONAL UNIVERSITY INDUSTRY- ACADEMIC COOPERATION FOUNDATION
Inventor: Byoung-YongChang
Abstract: The present invention relates to a real-time monitoring device of Fourier transform electrochemical impedance and a method thereof and, more specifically, to a real-time monitoring device of Fourier transform electrochemical impedance and a method thereof capable of being applied to monitor the characteristics, performance, and safety of an electrochemical generator such as a cell by providing a monitoring device which measures and calculates Fourier transform electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (hereinafter, FTEIS) in real time. The present invention can monitor the characteristics, performance, and safety of the electrochemical generator such as the cell in real time by providing the monitoring device which measures and calculates the Fourier transform electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (hereinafter, FTEIS) in real time. [Reference numerals] (100) Voltage/current applying unit; (200) Voltage/current measuring unit; (300) Real-time recording unit; (400) Impedance spectrum calculator; (500) Electrochemical information output unit; (600) Parallel processing unit; (AA) Electrochemical cell
Claims:
1. A Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring apparatus comprising: a voltage/current applying unit (100) for applying a voltage or current of a step waveform to an electrochemical cell; a voltage/current measuring unit (200) for measuring a current/voltage formed by the applied voltage/current, respectively; A real-time recording unit (300) for recording the measured value measured by the voltage/current measuring unit in real time; a control unit for differentiating the voltage and current recorded in the real-time recording unit, converting the differentiated value into a function of the frequency domain through Fourier transform, an impedance spectrum calculation unit 400 for calculating an impedance spectrum using Ohm 's law again; an electrochemical information output unit 500 for acquiring the impedance spectrum calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit and outputting the acquired impedance spectrum as electrochemical information; a voltage/current measurement unit, A parallel processing unit (600) for transmitting a command signal to each of the voltage/current measuring units, the impedance spectrum calculating units, and the electrochemical information output units, and the parallel processing unit (600) for transmitting a command signal to each of the impedance spectrum calculating units and the electrochemical information output units and independently repeatedly perform operations of the electrochemical information output units.
2. A Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring apparatus comprising: a voltage/current applying unit (100) for applying a voltage or current of a step waveform to an electrochemical cell; a voltage/current measuring unit (200) for measuring a current/voltage formed by the applied voltage/current, respectively; a real-time recording unit (300) for recording a measured value measured by the voltage/current measuring unit in real time; An impedance spectrum calculation unit 400 for differentiating the voltage and current recorded in the real-time recording unit, converting the differentiated value into a function of the frequency domain through Fourier transform, and calculating an impedance spectrum using Ohm 's law; an electrochemical information output unit 500 for acquiring the impedance spectrum calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit and outputting the acquired impedance spectrum as electrochemical information; And a parallel processing unit (600) for transmitting a command signal to each of the voltage/current measuring unit, the impedance spectrum calculating unit, and the electrochemical information output unit to independently and repeatedly perform operations of the voltage/current measuring unit, the impedance spectrum calculating unit, and the electrochemical information output unit, an apparatus for real-time monitoring of Fourier transform electrochemical impedance, characterized in that the processing of the voltage/current application unit, the voltage/current measurement unit, the real-time recording unit, the impedance spectrum calculation unit, and the electrochemical information output unit are performed simultaneously without a delay in time, so that real-time impedance monitoring can be performed.
3. A Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring apparatus comprising: a voltage/current applying unit (100) for applying a voltage or current of a step waveform to an electrochemical cell; a voltage/current measuring unit (200) for measuring a current/voltage formed by the applied voltage/current, respectively; A real-time recording unit (300) for recording the measured value measured by the voltage/current measuring unit in real time; an impedance spectrum calculating unit (400) for differentiating the voltage and current recorded in the real-time recording unit, converting the differentiated value into a function of the frequency domain through Fourier transform, and calculating an impedance spectrum using Ohm's law; An electrochemical information output unit (500) for acquiring the impedance spectrum calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit and outputting the acquired impedance spectrum as electrochemical information; a command signal output unit (500) for independently repeating operations of the voltage/current measurement unit, the impedance spectrum calculation unit, and the electrochemical information output unit, And a parallel processing unit (600) for transmitting the electrochemical information output unit to the electrochemical information output unit, wherein the impedance spectrum calculation unit (400) calculates the impedance spectrum in real time even if the voltage/current measurement unit and the electrochemical information output unit are operated by the operation of the parallel processing unit.
4. A Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring apparatus comprising: a voltage/current applying unit (100) for applying a voltage or current of a step waveform to an electrochemical cell; a voltage/current measuring unit (200) for measuring a current/voltage formed by the applied voltage/current, respectively; A real-time recording unit (300) for recording the measured value measured by the voltage/current measuring unit in real time; an impedance spectrum calculating unit (400) for differentiating the voltage and current recorded in the real-time recording unit, converting the differentiated value into a function of the frequency domain through Fourier transform, and calculating an impedance spectrum using Ohm's law; An electrochemical information output unit (500) for acquiring the impedance spectrum calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit and outputting the acquired impedance spectrum as electrochemical information; a command signal output unit (500) for independently repeating operations of the voltage/current measurement unit, the impedance spectrum calculation unit, and the electrochemical information output unit, And a parallel processing unit (600) for transmitting the electrochemical information output unit to the electrochemical information output unit, wherein the electrochemical information output unit (500) outputs the electrochemical information in real time even if the voltage/current measuring unit and the impedance spectrum calculating unit are operated by the operation of the parallel processing unit.
5. The semiconductor device according to claim 1, wherein the parallel processing unit (600) includes a first step of sending a command signal to transfer the data collected by the voltage/current measuring unit to the real-time recording unit, a second step of sending a command signal to the voltage/current measuring unit while transferring the collected data to the impedance spectrum calculating unit, A third step of transmitting an operation command signal to the impedance spectrum calculation unit, a fourth step of transmitting impedance data calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit to an electrochemical information output unit while transmitting a next operation command signal to the impedance spectrum calculation unit, And repeatedly performs a fifth step of sending an operation command signal to the electrochemical information output unit.
6. The Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring device according to claim 1, wherein the voltage/current measurement unit, the impedance spectrum calculation unit, and the electrochemical information output unit are connected with calculated result data.
7. A Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring method comprising: a voltage/current application step (S100) in which a voltage/current application unit (100) applies a voltage or current of a step waveform to an electrochemical cell; a parallel processing unit (600) applies a voltage or current of a step waveform to the electrochemical cell, A real-time recording step (S200) of sending a command signal to deliver a current measurement value to a real-time recording unit (300); a first parallel processing step (S300) of sending a command signal to a voltage/current measurement unit (200) while sending the collected voltage and current measurement values to an impedance spectrum calculating unit (400) while sending a command signal to a voltage/current measurement unit (200); An impedance spectrum calculation step (S400) in which the parallel processing unit (600) sends an operation command signal to the impedance spectrum calculation unit (400); a second parallel processing step (S500) in which the parallel processing unit (600) sends the impedance data calculated by the impedance spectrum calculation unit to the electrochemical information output unit (500) while sending a next operation command signal to the impedance spectrum calculation unit; And an electrochemical information output step (S600) in which the parallel processing unit (600) sends an operation command signal to the electrochemical information output unit.
8. The method for real-time monitoring of Fourier transform electrochemical impedance according to claim 7, wherein the voltage/current measurement unit, the impedance spectrum calculation unit and the electrochemical information output unit are connected with calculated result data.
9. The real-time monitoring method of the Fourier transform electrochemical impedance according to claim 7, wherein in the real-time recording step (S200), the voltage/current measuring unit (200) measures the voltage and current in real-time irrespective of the arithmetic processing of the impedance spectrum calculating unit and the electrochemical information output unit.
10. The real-time monitoring method of the Fourier transform electrochemical impedance according to claim 7, wherein in the impedance spectrum calculation step (S400), the impedance spectrum calculation unit (400) calculates the impedance spectrum with voltage and current measured values collected in real time regardless of the arithmetic processing of the electrochemical information output unit.
11. The Fourier transform electrochemical impedance monitoring method according to claim 7, wherein in the electrochemical information output step (S600), the electrochemical information output unit (500) acquires the impedance spectrum in real time regardless of the arithmetic processing of the impedance spectrum calculation unit and outputs the impedance spectrum as electrochemical information.

Title: Method and device for estimating the impedance of a motor vehicle battery
Inventor:
SAINT-MARCOUX ANTOINE 
PEUCHANT THOMAS 
LE-VOURCH YVES
Abstract: A method for estimating the impedance of at least one component of a motor vehicle battery during a phase of charging said battery from the mains, comprising: controlling (40) the application, to said component, of a current signal from the mains and defining a harmonic frequency, so as to charge said component, receiving (41) at least two voltage values measured at the terminals of said component at respective times defining a time period less than or equal to half of a period corresponding to said harmonic frequency, and determining (42, 43, 44), from said at least two voltage values and from the applied current signal, an impedance value associated with the harmonic frequency. A device for estimating impedance comprising means for carrying out this method.
Claims:
Claims
1. Method for estimating impedance of at least one component of a motor vehicle battery during a charge phase sector of this battery, comprising: 
 - controlling (40) the application to said component of a signal from the current and defining a sector harmonic frequency, so as to load said component, 
 - receiving (41) at least two values of measured voltages across said respective instants component defining a period of time less than or equal to one half of a period corresponding to said harmonic frequency, and 
 - determining (42, 43, 44) from said at least two values of voltage and current signal applied an impedance value associated with the harmonic frequency.
2. Method according to claim 1, wherein the current signal from the mains and applied to the component is obtained by straightening the mains current signal.
3. Method according to any one of claims 1 to 2, wherein the period of time varies between a quarter of the period corresponding to said harmonic frequency and one hundredth of said period.
4. Method according to any one of claims 1 to 3, further comprising: 
 comparing the (46) estimated impedance value to at least one threshold value, and 
 outputting a fault detection signal as a function of the electrical circuit to the comparison result.
5. Method according to claim 4, wherein said threshold value is derived from (45) a map arranged to associate an impedance value to a temperature value and a state of charge value.
6. Method according to any of claims 4 or 5, wherein estimating a plurality of impedance values for a plurality of respective components of the battery, 
 characterized in that 
 for said at least one component, said threshold value is obtained from at least one other impedance value corresponding to at least one other component such that the respective average value - impedance calculated on all the equivalent components in the pack. 7. Method according to any one of claims 1 to 6, wherein the battery comprises a plurality of modules electrically connected together by bus bar, each module comprising a number of cells, characterized in that 
 estimating a value of impedance for a component comprising a bus bar electrically connecting two modules together, 
 determining from said estimated impedance value a phase shift value, 
 for at least one other component comprising a cell, estimating a value of said impedance component taking into account said phase shift value.
8. Estimating device impedance (12) of at least one component (C?I, ..., the C ' - N) of a battery of an automotive vehicle (10), comprising: 
 - control means for applying to said sector load current signal component from the sector and defining a harmonic frequency, so as to load said component, 
- means for receiving at least two voltage values measured at the terminals of said component at times defining a time period less than or equal to one half of a period corresponding to the harmonic frequency, and 
- processing means in communication with the charging means and the receiving means, and arranged to determine from the received voltage values and from the applied current signal a measured value of impedance of the component associated with the harmonic frequency.
9. Battery system comprising (1) the device (12) according to claim 8, as well as a loading device (1,1) for charging a battery (10) from the mains and/or the battery itself. 10. A motor vehicle comprising a battery (1) system according to claim 9.

Title: Method and apparatus for diagnosing fault within fuel cell stack
Parent Assignee: HYUNDAI MOTOR, KANGNAM UNIVERSITY INDUSTRY ACADEMIA COOPERATI
Assignee:
KANGNAM UNIVERSITY INDUSTRY ACADEMIA COOPERATION FOUNDATION 
HYUNDAI MOTOR 
HYUNDAI KEFICO
Inventor:
JEONG KWI SEONG 
KIM SAE HOON 
KIM UCK SOO 
PARK HYUN-SEOK 
LEE YOUNG-HYUN
Abstract: To diagnose a fault of a fuel cell stack, an alternating current having a first optimal frequency of a first frequency domain to diagnose a drop in cell voltage and an alternating current having a second optimal frequency of a second frequency domain to diagnose a cause of the drop in cell voltage are supplied to the fuel cell stack are provided. A distortion rate is then calculated based on voltage of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current of the first optimal frequency, and the drop in cell voltage is diagnosed based on the calculated distortion rate. Also, impedance is calculated based on voltage and a current of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current of the second optimal frequency and amount of water is calculated based on the calculated in the fuel cell stack, and the cause of the drop in cell voltage is diagnosed based on the calculated impedance and amount of water.
Claims:
What is claimed is:
1. A method of diagnosing a fault of a fuel cell stack, the method comprising: 
 supplying, to the fuel cell stack, a plurality of alternating currents having different frequency combinations by an alternating current (AC) current generator; 
 measuring, by a processor, a distortion rate and impedance of the fuel cell stack for each alternating current, and selecting an optimal frequency based on the measured distortion rate and impedance; 
 supplying, to the fuel cell stack, an alternating current having the selected optimal frequency by the AC current generator; 
 calculating, by the processor, the distortion rate of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current having the optimal frequency, and diagnosing a drop in cell voltage based on the calculated distortion rate; and 
 calculating, by the processor, the impedance of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current having the optimal frequency, amount of water in the fuel cell stack based on the calculated impedance, and diagnosing a cause of the drop in cell voltage based on the calculated impedance and amount of water, 
 wherein the selecting of the optimal frequency comprises: 
  selecting a first frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest distortion rate as a first optimal frequency to diagnose the drop in cell voltage, based on the distortion rates measured for the respective alternating currents; and 
  selecting a second frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest impedance as a second optimal frequency to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage, based on the impedances measured for the respective alternating currents.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein: 
 supplying of the plurality of alternating currents to the fuel cell stack includes supplying, to the fuel cell stack, an alternating current having a first frequency of a first frequency domain to diagnose the drop in cell voltage and an alternating current having a second frequency of a second frequency domain to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage, wherein the plurality of alternating currents has the first frequency and the second frequency that are different from each other.
3. A method of diagnosing a fault of a fuel cell stack, the method comprising: 
 supplying, to the fuel cell stack, an alternating current having a first optimal frequency of a first frequency domain to diagnose a drop in cell voltage and an alternating current having a second optimal frequency of a second frequency domain to diagnose a cause of the drop in cell voltage by an alternating current (AC) current generator; 
 calculating, by a processor, a distortion rate based on voltage of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current of the first optimal frequency, and diagnosing the drop in cell voltage based on the calculated distortion rate; and 
 calculating, by the processor, impedance based on the voltage and a current of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current of the second optimal frequency and amount of water in the fuel cell stack based on the calculated impedance, and diagnosing the cause of the drop in cell voltage based on the calculated impedance and amount of water, 
 wherein a first frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest distortion rate is selected as the first optimal frequency to diagnose the drop in cell voltage, based on the distortion rate for each alternating current, and 
 wherein a second frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest impedance is selected as the second optimal frequency to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage, based on impedances measure for each alternating current.
4. The method of claim 3, wherein: 
 diagnosing of the drop in cell voltage includes diagnosing the drop in cell voltage based on a total harmonic distortion analysis (THDA) method, and 
 diagnosing of the cause of the drop in cell voltage includes measuring the impedance using an electromechanical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and diagnosing the cause of the drop in cell voltage.
5. An apparatus to diagnose a fault of a fuel cell stack, the apparatus comprising: 
 an alternating current (AC) injector connected to the fuel cell stack and applying an alternating current to a current which flows from the fuel cell stack to a load; 
 an AC current generator configured to generate the applied alternating current; and 
 a diagnosis processor configured to measure voltage and a current of the fuel cell stack, to diagnose a drop in cell voltage of the fuel cell stack and to diagnose a cause of the drop in cell voltage based on the measured voltage and current, 
 wherein an optimal frequency is selected by an optimal frequency selection processor based on measured distortion rates and impedance of the fuel cell stack for a plurality of alternating currents, 
 wherein the optimal frequency selection processor is configured to: 
  select a first frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest distortion rate as a first optimal frequency to diagnose the drop in cell voltage, based on distortion rates measured for the respective alternating currents; and 
  select a second frequency of an alternating current corresponding to a largest impedance as a second optimal frequency to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage, based on impedance measured for the respective alternating currents.
6. The apparatus of claim 5, wherein: 
 the diagnosis processor includes: 
  the optimal frequency selection processor configured to select the first optimal frequency to diagnose the drop in cell voltage and the second optimal frequency to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage; 
  an alternating current control section configured to control the AC current generator; 
  a distortion rate calculating section configured to measure the voltage of the fuel cell stack, and to calculate the distortion rate of the fuel cell stack based on the measured voltage; 
  an impedance/water calculating section configured to measure the voltage and the current of the fuel cell stack, and to calculate the impedance based on the measured voltage and current and amount of water in the fuel cell stack based on the calculated impedance; and 
  a diagnosis section configured to diagnose the drop in cell voltage of the fuel cell stack based on the distortion rate, and to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage based on the impedance and amount of water.
7. The apparatus of claim 6, wherein: 
 the AC injector includes electronic devices configured to supply an alternating current according to an alternating signal output from the AC current generator.
8. A non-transitory computer readable medium containing program instructions executed by a processor, the computer readable medium comprising: 
 program instructions that measure a distortion rate and impedance of the fuel cell stack for each alternating current, and selecting an optimal frequency based on the measured distortion rate and impedance; 
 program instructions that control supply of an alternating current having the selected optimal frequency by an alternating current (AC) current generator; 
 program instructions that calculate the distortion rate of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current having the optimal frequency, and diagnosing a drop in cell voltage based on the calculated distortion rate; and 
 program instructions that calculate the impedance of the fuel cell stack according to the alternating current having the optimal frequency, and diagnosing a cause of the drop in cell voltage based on the calculated impedance, 
 wherein the program instructions selecting of the optimal frequency comprises: 
  program instructions that select a first frequency of an alternating current corresponding to the largest distortion rate as a first optimal frequency to diagnose the drop in cell voltage, based on the distortion rates measured for the respective alternating currents; and 
 program instructions that select a second frequency of an alternating current corresponding to the largest impedance as a second optimal frequency to diagnose the cause of the drop in cell voltage, based on the impedance measured for the respective alternating currents.

Title: Method for estimating of battery's state by measuring battery impedence and battery management apparatus
Inventor: CUI CHANGLIE
Abstract: The disclosure relates to a method for estimating of battery's state by measuring battery impedence and a battery management apparatus using same; the method for estimating of battery's state by measuring the battery impedence comprises the following steps: at least sensing voltage, current and temperature of at least one cell of a cell pack formed by the cells; measuring a charging state or impedence of the cell according to the sensed information; extracting reference impedence of the cell from a lookup table according to at least one index from a group formed by frequency, temperature and charging state; comparing the reference impedence with the measured impedence, thereby deciding the cell state. When the cell impedence is calculated, the temperature and charging state are taken into consideration, so the cell impedence can compensate the changes along with the temperature and charging state; degradation of the cell can be informed to a user as a warning, thereby preventing impedence abnormal increasing phenomenon before happening.
Claims:
1. A method of measuring a state of a battery by measuring impedance, comprising:
 a stage of inducing at least one of voltage, current and temperature of at least one battery in a battery pack composed of a plurality of batteries;
 measuring the charging state of the battery and the impedance of the battery based on the sensed information;
 a stage of extracting from a lookup table a reference impedance of the battery corresponding to at least one of a frequency, a temperature and a state of charge of a signal applied to the battery; and
 a phase of comparing the reference impedance with the measured impedance to determine the state of the battery;
 the induction phase is that the induction phase is,
 applying a 1 st signal having a frequency higher than a set frequency to the battery, inducing at least one of a voltage and a current of the battery,
 the extraction stage is that the extraction stage is,
 extracting in a look-up table a reference impedance of said battery at least according to one of a frequency of said 1 st signal, said sensed temperature and said measured state of charge;
 it is determined that the phase of the state is,
 determining that the measured impedance is within a predetermined range with respect to the reference impedance based on the 1 st signal as a reference,
 the measured impedance is determined to be abnormal state when the measured impedance is out of the preset range relative to the reference impedance by using the 1 st signal as a reference, and a detection lamp can be lighted after the engine of the automobile using the battery as power is turned ON,
 if the battery is judged to be in a normal state, applying a 2 nd signal with a frequency lower than the set frequency to the battery, and additionally inducing at least one of the voltage and the current of the battery;
 additionally measuring the impedance of the battery based on the additionally induced information; and
 a step of additionally extracting a reference impedance of the battery according to at least one of the frequency of the 2 nd signal, the sensed temperature, and the measured state of charge from a lookup table; and
 comparing the reference impedance with the measured impedance, and determining the state of the battery;
 wherein the 1 st signal is a signal having a frequency in the range of 500 to 2000Hz, the predetermined range with respect to the reference impedance is less than 120% times of the reference impedance,
 the stage of adding and determining the state is that,
 when the measured impedance is within a predetermined range with respect to the reference impedance based on the 2 nd signal, the measured impedance is determined to be in a normal state,
 the abnormal state is additionally determined when the measured impedance is out of a predetermined range with respect to the reference impedance based ON the 2 nd signal, and a detection lamp may be turned ON after an engine of a vehicle using the battery as power is turned ON.
2. The method of measuring battery state by measuring impedance according to claim 1,
 the 2 nd signal is a signal having a frequency in the range of 1 to 4Hz,
 the predetermined range with respect to the reference impedance means less than 125% times the reference impedance.
3. The method of measuring battery state by measuring impedance according to claim 1,
 the temperature is sensed within a set time after the engine of the vehicle using the battery as power is turned OFF,
 the state of charge is measured based on the sensed temperature within the set time.
4. A battery management apparatus, comprising:
 a signal generation unit that generates a 1 st signal having a frequency higher than a set frequency and a 2 nd signal having a frequency lower than the set frequency;
 a calculation unit that measures a state of charge of the battery and an impedance of the battery based on at least one of the sensed voltage, current, and temperature of the battery applied to the 1 st signal or the 2 nd signal;
 a storage section that stores, as a lookup table, reference impedance of the battery corresponding to at least one of a frequency, a temperature, and a state of charge of a signal applied to the battery; and
 a control unit for comparing the reference impedance with the measured impedance to determine the state of the battery;
 the control part is used for controlling the operation of the motor,
 a reference impedance when the 1 st signal is applied, and the state of the battery is confirmed 1 st time by comparing the impedance measured by applying the 1 st signal,
 a reference impedance when the 2 nd signal is applied, comparing with the impedance measured when the 2 nd signal is applied, confirming the state of the battery 2 nd time,
 if the 1 st confirmation result and the 2 nd confirmation result are both confirmed to be normal, determining that the final state of the battery is normal;
 wherein the 1 st signal is a signal having a frequency in a range of 500 to 2000Hz, the control part determines the 1 st confirmation result as normal if the impedance measured by applying the 1 st signal is less than 120% of the reference impedance applied by applying the 1 st signal, and determines the 2 nd confirmation result as normal if the impedance measured by applying the 2 nd signal is less than 125% of the reference impedance applied by applying the 2 nd signal.

Title: - Method for vehicle battery pack management using cell-impedance
Inventor: SONG, Jung Yong
Abstract: Provided is a method of managing a vehicle battery pack using the cell-impedance. According to an embodiment of the present invention the method of managing the vehicle battery pack includes measuring the cell-impedance, which is the impedance of the cell mounted on the modules constituting the vehicle battery pack, for each cell and storing the history of the cell-impedance for each cell. Thus the present invention stores and monitors the change rate of the cell-impedance and the history of the cell-impedance therefor even during a vehicle is operating and so it becomes to be able to detect and manage the degradation difference for multiple cells constituting the battery pack ultimately so that it can improve the performance and the fuel efficiency of the vehicle as well as a battery system.
Claims:
1. A method of manufacturing a battery pack for a vehicle, the method comprising: measuring cell-impedance for each cell, the cell-impedance being an impedance of a cell included in modules constituting a battery pack for a vehicle; and storing a history of the cell-impedance for each cell, Calculating a comparison value between the cell-impedance measured in the measuring step and the reference impedance of the impedance map table for each cell; calculating a difference between the current comparison value and the past comparison value for each cell; storing the calculated difference between the comparison value for each cell and generating a cell-impedance change rate for each cell; Measuring a temperature change rate of the battery pack; and when the temperature change rate is less than a temperature change rate upper limit, performing the comparison value calculating step, wherein the measurement start condition of the cell-impedance includes, Wherein a microcontroller of a battery management system (BMS) requests a battery pack impedance measurement from an ECU through a can communication unit, and wherein a vehicle operating time has elapsed.
2. AMEND STATUS: Delete
3. The vehicular battery pack management method according to claim 1, wherein the impedance map table is an impedance map table according to at least one of a characteristic of the battery pack, a temperature of the battery pack, and a state of charge of the battery pack.
4. AMEND STATUS: Delete
5. The method of claim 1, further comprising: measuring a current of the battery pack, wherein the cell-impedance measuring is performed if the current exceeds a threshold current.
6. The vehicle battery pack management method according to claim 5, wherein the battery pack current measurement step is performed when there is a measurement request from an electronic control unit (ECU) and a vehicle running time exceeds a set running time.
7. The method of claim 6, further comprising guiding the abrupt change of the cell-impedance to at least one of the ECU and a hybrid control unit (HCU) when the cell-impedance change rate exceeds a standard.
8. The method according to claim 1, further comprising: shutting off power supply by the battery pack or notifying a driver when the cell-impedance change rate exceeds a standard.
9. AMEND STATUS: Delete

Title: - Method for vehicle battery pack management using module-impedance
Inventor: SONG, Jung Yong
Abstract: Provided is a method for managing a battery pack for a vehicle using module impedance. The method for managing a battery pack for a vehicle according to an embodiment of the present invention comprises measuring cell impedance, which is impedance of cells included in modules forming a battery pack for a vehicle, for each cell; outputting module impedance for each module by summing up cell impedance; outputting an maximum variation between cells of the cell impedance for each module; and if the maximum variation between the cells exceeds a permissible variation and storing the module impedance of the corresponding module to generate a module impedance variation rate, thereby sensing and managing a deterioration difference for a plurality of modules forming the battery pack by sensing and storing the impedance variation rate for each module forming the battery pack while driving the vehicle and ultimately improving performance and fuel efficiency of the vehicle as well as a battery system.
Claims:
1. A method of manufacturing a battery pack for a vehicle, comprising: measuring cell-impedance for each cell, the cell-impedance being an impedance of a cell included in modules constituting a battery pack for a vehicle; calculating a module-impedance by summing the cell-impedances for each module; calculating a maximum variation between cells of the cell-impedance for each module; and when the maximum variation between cells exceeds an allowable variation, Storing module-impedance of the module to generate module-impedance rate of change; and measuring a current of the battery pack, wherein the cell-impedance measurement is performed if the current exceeds a threshold current, and the threshold current is set proportional to a capacity of the battery pack.
2. The method of claim 1, further comprising: measuring a rate of temperature change of the battery pack; and if the rate of temperature change is less than an upper temperature change rate limit, calculating module-impedance.
3. AMEND STATUS: Delete
4. The vehicle battery pack management method of claim 1, wherein the battery pack current measurement step is performed when there is a measurement request from an electronic control unit (ECU) and a vehicle operation time exceeds a set operation time.
5. The method of claim 4, further comprising: notifying at least one of the ECU and the Hybrid Control Unit (HCU) of the fact that the maximum variation between the cells exceeds the allowable variation.
6. The vehicular battery pack management method according to claim 1, further comprising: shutting off the supply of power by the battery pack or notifying the driver when the maximum variation between the cells exceeds the allowable variation.
7. AMEND STATUS: Delete

Title: Method for determining the internal ohmic resistance of a battery module, battery management system and motor vehicle
Inventor: FINK HOLGER
Abstract: The invention relates to a method for determining the internal ohmic resistance of a battery module (100) comprising at least one battery cell, for example a lithium-ion battery cell of the type used in traction batteries (140) of electric or hybrid motor vehicles, that is, in motor vehicles comprising drives (150) that are at least partly or intermittently electrically driven. The invention also relates to a motor vehicle and a battery management system (160). The disclosed method comprises the determination of the internal ohmic resistance from measurements of voltage intensities. The invention is characterised in that the method comprises the connection of the battery module (100) to at least one other battery module (100) that is subject to a load current, and comprises the measurement of voltage intensities in the battery module (100) before and after said connection. This allows a measurement of current and voltage intensities to take place significantly closer to real time and thus almost simultaneously, which in turn allows the determination of the actual wear condition of the battery module (100) to be improved and the durability of individual battery cells or of battery modules (100) to be predicted.
Claims:
1. Method for determining the internal ohmic resistance of a battery module (100), wherein the method comprises the determination of the internal ohmic resistance from measurements of voltage intensities,
 characterized in that
 the method comprises the connection of the battery module (100) to at least one further battery module (100) that is subject to a load current, wherein the method comprises the measurement of voltage intensities of the battery module (100) before and after the connection.
2. Method according to Claim 1, wherein the method comprises a comparison of the determined internal ohmic resistance with a predefined internal ohmic resistance in order to determine a deviation.
3. Method according to Claim 1 or 2, wherein the battery module (100) and the at least one further battery module (100) can be connected or disconnected in series positively or negatively and can form a battery module bank (130) that is suitable, by connecting the battery modules (100), for generating an alternating voltage, and wherein the measurements are taken within the scope of a connection of the battery module (100) during the generation of the alternating voltage.
4. Method according to Claim 3, wherein the battery module bank is part of a battery system (140) comprising a number of battery module banks (130) and the battery system (140) is suitable for generating alternating voltages having at least two different alternating voltage profiles, and wherein the method comprises the determination of an internal ohmic resistance profile over time and a comparison of the determined internal ohmic resistance profile with an internal ohmic resistance profile fixed by one of the two alternating voltage profiles in order to determine a deviation profile, wherein the deviation profile is deemed to be an indicator for a state of excessive wear of the battery module (100) if it exceeds a threshold value in at least two measurement points.
5. Battery management system (160) for a battery module bank (130) comprising at least two battery modules (100) connectable and disconnectable in series positively and/or negatively, wherein the battery module bank (130) comprises a device for measuring battery module voltage intensities and furthermore a device for transmitting measured module voltage intensities to the battery management system (160),
 characterized in that
 the battery management system (160) is designed to determine a change of the transmitted battery module voltage intensities of one of the at least two battery modules (100) as a result of a connection of the first-mentioned of the at least two battery modules (100) to at least one other of the at least two battery modules (100) under load current, and to use this change to determine an impedance of the first-mentioned of the at least two battery modules (100).
6. Battery management system (160) according to Claim 5, wherein the battery management system (160) is also designed to compare a determined module voltage intensity change with a predefined module voltage intensity change in order to determine a deviation and to compare the determined deviation with a threshold value.
7. Battery management system (160) according to Claim 5 or 6, wherein the battery module bank (130) is suitable for generating an alternating voltage by connecting the battery modules (100), and wherein the battery management system (160) is designed to determine a module voltage intensity change as a result of a connection of the battery module (100) during the generation of the alternating voltage.
8. Battery management system (160) according to Claim 7, wherein the battery module bank (130) is suitable for generating alternating voltages having at least two different alternating voltage intensity profiles, and wherein the battery management system (160) is designed to determine an impedance profile over time and to compare this with a target impedance profile determined by one of the two alternating voltage intensity profiles in order to determine a deviation profile, wherein the deviation profile is deemed to be an indicator for a state of excessive wear of the battery module (100) if it exceeds a threshold value in at least two measurement points.
9. Multi-phase battery system (140) comprising a battery management system (160) according to one of Claims 5 to 8 and at least two parallel battery module banks (130), wherein the multi-phase battery system (140) is suitable for providing alternating voltages phase-shifted in relation to one another and thus a predetermined alternating current intensity with the aid of the at least two parallel battery module banks (130).
10. Motor vehicle comprising a drive unit (150) that can be electrically operated at least intermittently or partly, comprising a battery management system (160) according to one of Claims 5 to 8 and at least two parallel battery module banks (130) comprised by a multi-phase battery system (140), wherein the multi-phase battery system (140) is suitable for providing alternating voltages phase-shifted in relation to one another and thus a predetermined alternating current intensity of the drive unit (150) with the aid of the at least two parallel battery module banks (130) .

Title: Method for determining the state of exhaustion of a battery module, battery management system, voltage step battery system and motor vehicle
Inventor:
HORE SARMIMALA 
FINK HOLGER
Abstract: The present invention relates to a method for determining a state of exhaustion of a battery module (130) comprising at least one battery cell, for example a lithium ion battery cell, such as are used for example in traction batteries (140) of electric or hybrid motor vehicles, i.e. in motor vehicles having at least partly or intermittently electrically driven drives (150). The invention therefore also relates to a motor vehicle and a battery management system (160). The method described comprises the determination of the non-reactive internal resistance from measurements of current intensities. The battery module (100) can be connected electrically in series to at least one further battery module (100) or isolated electrically. The method is characterized in that the method comprises isolating the battery module (100) and measuring current intensities of the isolated battery module (100). The other use of the at least one further battery module is therefore not impaired by the determination of the state of exhaustion.
Claims:
Claims
1. Method for determining a wear state of a motor vehicle 
 Battery module (100), wherein the method comprises determining the ohmic internal resistance from measurements of current intensities, and wherein the battery module (100) can be electrically connected in series to at least one further battery module (100) or can be disconnected from the at least one further battery module (100), 
 characterized in that 
 the method comprising disconnecting the battery module (100) and measuring current intensities of the disconnected battery module (100) in an open circuit.
2. Method according to Claim 1, wherein the method is carried out when the battery module (100) is disconnected during the use of the battery module (100) and of the at least one further battery module (100) in order to generate a varying voltage.
3. Method according to Claim 1 or 2, wherein the method comprises an electrical impedance spectroscopy by applying a voltage modulation to the battery module (100) on the basis of the measured 
 Current intensities a current intensity modulation as a result of the 
 Voltage modulation and, in order to determine an ohmic internal resistance of the battery module (100), ratios the voltage modulation to the current intensity modulation.
4. The method of claim 3, wherein the electrical impedance spectroscopy alters the voltage modulation such that a 
 Phase shift between the voltage modulation and the determined current intensity modulation becomes zero and the ohmic internal resistance becomes zero as a quotient of the voltage modulation to 
Current intensity modulation. 
Method according to one of the preceding claims, wherein measurements of current intensities relating to different charge states of the 
Battery module (100). 
Method according to Claim 5, wherein an electrochemical process of the battery module (100) is carried out by means of the measurements of current intensities. 
 which is compared with at least one predetermined time constant in order to determine the state of wear of the battery module (100). 
Battery management system (160) for a battery module string (130) having at least two battery modules (100) which can be electrically connected to one another in series and can be disconnected individually, wherein the battery module string (130) is suitable for generating a varying voltage by connecting and disconnecting the battery modules (100), comprises an apparatus for measuring battery module amperages and further comprises an apparatus for transmitting measured amperages to the battery management system (160) wherein the battery management system (160) is adapted to receive measured amperages generated during a period of 
 varying voltage of the one of the at least two battery modules (100) for determining a state of wear of the one of the at least two battery modules (100). 
The battery management system (160) of claim 7, wherein the 
Battery management system (160) comprises an apparatus for generating an AC voltage and is further designed to cause the AC voltage to be applied to the disconnected battery module, to determine an alternating current intensity as a result of the alternating voltage, and to relate the alternating voltage to the alternating current intensity in order to determine an ohmic internal resistance of the battery module (100), wherein the battery management system (160) is further configured to change the AC voltage such that a phase shift between the AC voltage and the determined AC magnitude becomes zero and wherein the 
Battery management system (160) determines the internal ohmic resistance as a quotient of alternating voltage to alternating current strength. 
A voltage stage system (140) for generating varying voltages out of phase with each other comprising 
Battery module strings (130) and a battery management system (160) according to one of Claims 7 to 8. 
Motor vehicle having an at least time-or partially electrically operable drive unit (150) and having a voltage-controlled system (140) according to Claim 9.

Title: Microfluidic feedback using impedance detection
Inventor:
STURMER RYAN 
SRINIVASAN VIJAY 
SUDARSAN ARJUN
Abstract: Methods comprising measuring the impedance of the electrode produced by the excitation signal, wherein the impedance indicates presence of liquid at the electrode are disclosed. Computer readable mediums storing processor executable instructions for performing the method, and systems are also disclosed. The systems comprise a processor, memory and code stored in the memory that when executed cause the processor at least to: receive an output voltage signal, superimpose an excitation signal onto the output voltage signal to produce a superimposed signal, connect the superimposed signal to an electrode in a droplet actuator, suppress the output voltage signal, when detecting an impedance of the electrode, and measure the impedance of the electrode produced by the excitation signal, wherein the impedance indicates presence of liquid at the electrode.
Claims:
1. A method for measuring the impedance of an electrode (120, 122, 124) in a droplet actuator (100), the droplet actuator comprising electrodes arranged to conduct droplet operations by electrowetting, the method comprising: 
 (a) producing, by a power supply (1810), an output voltage signal for providing an electrowetting voltage to the electrodes (120, 122, 124) of the droplet actuator (100); 
 (b) superimposing an excitation signal (2110) onto the output voltage signal to produce a superimposed signal; 
 (c) connecting the superimposed signal to an electrode (120, 122, 124) in the droplet actuator (100); 
 (d) during impedance detection operations to detect an impedance of the electrode (120, 122, 124), stopping the output voltage signal from the power supply (1810); and 
 (e) measuring the impedance of the electrode (120, 122, 124) produced by the excitation signal, wherein the impedance indicates presence or absence of liquid at the electrode (120, 122, 124).
2. The method of claim 1, wherein superimposing the excitation signal (2110) comprises adding the excitation signal (2110) to the output voltage signal.
3. The method of claim 1, wherein stopping the output voltage signal comprises disabling a switching action of the power supply (1810).
4. The method of claim 1, wherein stopping the output voltage signal comprises disabling the power supply (1810).
5. The method of claim 1, further comprising determining a saturation of the impedance.
6. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) injecting the liquid into the droplet actuator (100); and 
 (b) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
7. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) injecting the liquid into a gap in the droplet actuator (100); and 
 (b) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
8. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) injecting the liquid into a reservoir (R1 to R7) in the droplet actuator (100); and 
 (b) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
9. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) injecting the liquid to fill a reservoir (R1 to R7) in the droplet actuator (100); and 
 (b) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed from the reservoir (R1 to R7) to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
10. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) establishing a fluid path in the droplet actuator (100) from an input port (128, 130, 134) to a reservoir (R1 to R7) to the electrode (120, 122, 124); 
 (b) injecting the liquid through the input port (128, 130, 134) to fill the reservoir (R1 to R7); and 
 (c) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
11. The method of claim 1, further comprising: 
 (a) arranging an input port (128, 130, 134) outside a boundary of a reservoir (R1 to R7) in the droplet actuator (100); 
 (b) forming a fluid path from the input port (128, 130, 134) to the reservoir (R1 to R7) to the electrode (120, 122, 124); 
 (c) injecting the liquid through the input port (128, 130, 134) to fill the reservoir (R1 to R7); and 
 (d) stopping injection when the impedance indicates the liquid has flowed to the electrode (120, 122, 124).
12. A system for measuring the impedance of an electrode (120, 122, 124) in a droplet actuator (100), the droplet actuator comprising electrodes arranged to conduct droplet operations by electrowetting, the system comprising: 
 (a) a processor; 
 (b) memory; and 
 (c) code stored in the memory that when executed causes the processor at least to implement the method of claim 1.
13. The system of claim 12, wherein said code, when executed, causes the processor at least to implement the method of any one of claims 2 to 4 and 6 to 11.

Title: Faulty protective earth ground circuit detection system and method
Inventor:
LI KANG 
SHOSHIEV ALEXANDER
Abstract: A system and method for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor which is coupled to a Protective Earth (PE) terminal (16c) associated with a power source (15). The power source is used to apply a voltage to a device (14). The system may use a high impedance device (20) coupled across a switch (K3), with the switch being in communication with a portion of the device. A control system (24) may monitor a voltage across the high impedance device and determine if the voltage across the high impedance device exceeds a predetermined threshold. Exceeding the predetermined threshold indicates that an unsafe voltage from the power source is present on the ground conductor. A natural high impedance path (17,18) between the device and the Earth is used to provide an Earth connection through the device to the Earth during operation of the system.
Claims:
1. A system for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor which is coupled to a protective Earth (PE) terminal associated with a power source, where the power source is being used to apply a voltage to a device, the system including: 
 a high impedance device coupled across a switch, with the switch being in communication with a portion of the device; 
 a control system for monitoring a voltage across the high impedance device and determining if the voltage across the high impedance device exceeds a predetermined threshold, thereby indicating that an unsafe voltage from the power source is present on the ground conductor; and 
 where a natural high impedance path between the Earth and the device is used to provide an Earth connection through the device during operation of the system.
2. The system of claim 1, further including a voltage measuring device which detects the voltage across the high impedance device.
3. The system of claim 1, wherein the control system prevents closing of the switch if the voltage across the high impedance device is detected to be above the predetermined threshold.
4. The system of claim 1, wherein the high impedance device and an impedance of the natural high impedance path from the vehicle to the Earth form a voltage divider arrangement.
5. A system for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor which is coupled to a protective Earth (PE) terminal associated with an alternating current (AC) power source, where the AC power source is being used to apply a charging voltage to a switch system of a charger associated with an electric vehicle, the system including: 
 a high impedance device coupled across a switch of the switch system, with the switch being in communication with a chassis of the vehicle; 
 a control system for monitoring a voltage across the high impedance device and determining if the voltage across the high impedance device exceeds a predetermined threshold, thereby indicating that an unsafe voltage from the AC power source is present on the ground conductor; 
 where a natural high impedance path between the Earth and the vehicle's chassis is used to provide an Earth connection through the vehicle's chassis during operation of the system; and 
 wherein the control system controls opening and closing of the switch system in response to the sensed voltage across the high impedance device.
6. The system of claim 5, further comprising a voltage measuring device which detects the voltage across the high impedance device.
7. The system of claim 5, wherein an impedance of the natural high impedance path from the vehicle's chassis to the Earth, and the high impedance device, together form a voltage divider circuit.
8. A method for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor which is coupled to a protective Earth (PE) terminal associated with a power source, where the power source is being used to apply a voltage to a device, the method including: 
 using a natural high impedance path including at least one of capacitance and resistance, between the device and the Earth, to form a connection with the Earth; 
 sensing a voltage across a high impedance device coupled across a switch while the switch is open, with the switch being in communication with the PE connection between the device and the Earth; and 
 using a control system in communication with the high impedance device to determine when a voltage across the high impedance device indicates the presence of an unsafe voltage from the power source being present on the ground conductor.
9. The method of claim 8, wherein said sensing a voltage comprises using a means for measuring the voltage across the high impedance device.
10. The method of claim 9, further comprising determining when the voltage across the high impedance device exceeds a predetermined threshold, thereby indicating that an unsafe voltage from the power source is present on the ground conductor.
11. The method of claim 8, wherein the device comprises an electric vehicle.
12. The method of claim 8, further comprising using the control system to control operation of the switch.
13. The method of claim 12, further comprising using the control system to maintain the switch in an open condition until the control system verifies that no unsafe voltage from the power source is present on the ground conductor, and then using the control system to close the switch.
14. The method of claim 13, further comprising using the control system to control additional switches in communication with a first phase line of the power source and a second phase line of the power source, wherein the second phase line comprises a neutral line, and wherein the power source comprises an AC power source with the first phase line and the second phase lines are used to communicate power from the AC power source to the device.
1. A system (10) for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor (T3) which is coupled to a protective Earth (PE) terminal (16c) associated with a power source (15), where the power source (15) is being used to apply a voltage to a device(14), the system including: 
 a high impedance device (20) coupled across a switch (K3), with the switch_(K3) being positioned in series between the ground conductor (T3) and the device (14) and being in communication with a portion of the device (14); 
 a control system (24) for monitoring a voltage across the high impedance device (20) and determining if the voltage across the high impedance device (20)_exceeds a predetermined threshold, thereby indicating that an unsafe voltage from the power source (15) is present on the ground conductor (T3); and 
 where a natural high impedance path (17, 18) between the Earth and the device (14) is used to provide an Earth connection through the device (14) during operation of the system (10).
2. The system (10) of claim 1, further including a voltage measuring device (28) which detects the voltage across the high impedance device (20).
3. The system (10) of claim 1, wherein the control system (24) prevents closing of the switch (K3) if the voltage across the high impedance device (20) is detected to be above the predetermined threshold.
4. The system (10) of claim 1, wherein the high impedance device (20)_and an impedance of the natural high impedance path (17, 18) from the device (14) to the Earth form a voltage divider arrangement.

 wherein the power source (15) comprises an AC power source (15), the AC power source (15) being used to apply a charging voltage to a switch system (12) of a charger associated with an electric vehicle (14),
 wherein the high impedance device (20) is coupled across a switch (K3) of the switch system (12), with the switch (K3) being positioned in series between the ground conductor (T3) and a chassis of the vehicle (14) and being in communication with the chassis of the vehicle (14),
 wherein the control system (24) monitors a voltage across the high impedance device (20) and determines if the voltage across the high impedance device (20) exceeds a predetermined threshold, thereby indicating that an unsafe voltage from the AC power source (15) is present on the ground conductor (T3),

6. The system (10) of claim 5, further comprising a voltage measuring device (28) which detects the voltage across the high impedance device (20).
7. The system (10) of claim 5, wherein an impedance of the natural high impedance path (17, 18) from the vehicle's chassis to the Earth, and the high impedance device (20), together form a voltage divider circuit.
8. A method for detecting the presence of a voltage on a ground conductor (T3) which is coupled to a protective Earth (PE) terminal (16c) associated with a power source (15), where the power source (15) is being used to apply a voltage to a device (14), the method including:

 sensing a voltage across a high impedance device (20) coupled across a switch (K3) while the switch (K3) is open, with the switch (K3) being in communication with the PE connection (16c) between the device (14) and the Earth; and

11. The method of claim 8, wherein the device (14) comprises an electric vehicle.

The method of claim 12, further comprising using the control system (24) to maintain the switch (K3) in an open condition until the control system (24)_verifies that no unsafe voltage from the power source (15) is present on the ground conductor (T3), and then using the control system (24) to close the switch (K3).

Title: Impedance measuring method, fuel cell system, and impedance measuring device
Inventor:
EGAMI MASAHIRO
WAKE KAZUHIRO
WATANABE SHINYA
YOSHIDA HIROMICHI
KOIWA Nobuki
KOTAKE TOMOHITO
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide an impedance measuring method for calculating a highly accurate impedance in a short time by simple device and configuration.
SOLUTION: In the impedance measuring method for a fuel cell in a fuel cell system including a fuel cell and supplying power to a load, time series data of the current and voltage of the fuel cell during the hunting phenomenon occurred when the load varies are acquired. The time series data of the current and voltage are subjected, respectively, to arithmetic processing by FFT method, and the impedance is calculated by two data thus processed.
COPYRIGHT: (C)2013,JPO&INPIT
Claims:
1. A method for measuring impedance of a fuel cell in a fuel cell system that includes the fuel cell and supplies power to a load, the method comprising the steps of: acquiring time series data of a current and a voltage of the fuel cell during a hunting phenomenon that occurs due to fluctuations in the load; Computationally processing each of the current time series data and the voltage time series data using a FFT method, and calculating impedance from the two computationally processed data.
2. A fuel cell and a storage battery, wherein the fuel cell and the storage battery are supplied to a load in accordance with a power instruction value or a current instruction value calculated by the control computation unit, and A method for measuring impedance of a fuel cell in a fuel cell system that includes an impedance measuring unit that measures impedance of the fuel cell, wherein a predetermined fluctuation state of the load at which a hunting phenomenon occurs is stored in the control computation unit, The vibration control device according to claim 1, wherein the control computation unit sends a hunting occurrence prediction signal to the impedance measurement unit when a fluctuating state of the predetermined load occurs or when the fluctuating state of the predetermined load is predicted to occur, and the impedance measurement unit is configured to: Acquiring time series data of a current and a voltage of the fuel cell; performing arithmetic processing on each of the current time series data and the voltage time series data using a FFT method; and calculating impedance from the two pieces of arithmetic processing.
3. A fuel cell and a storage battery, wherein the fuel cell and the storage battery are supplied to a load in accordance with a power instruction value or a current instruction value calculated by the control computation unit, and The method for measuring impedance of the fuel cell in a fuel cell system that includes an impedance measuring unit that measures impedance of the fuel cell, wherein a predetermined fluctuation state of the load at which a hunting phenomenon occurs is stored by the control computation unit, and while the fuel cell is in operation, The power generation apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the control computation unit generates a fluctuating state of the predetermined load and induces a hunting phenomenon, and the impedance measurement unit acquires time series data of a current and a voltage of the fuel cell during the hunting phenomenon, and Computationally processing each of the current time series data and the voltage time series data using a FFT method, and calculating impedance from the two computationally processed data.

The power generation device according to claim 1, whereinwhen the control computation unit instructs a fluctuation state of the predetermined load at which the fuel cell hangs, the control computation unit causes the output of the fuel cell to fluctuate at a rate greater than or equal to a predetermined rate, thereby causing the output of the fuel cell to fluctuate.4The impedance measurement method according to (1).

The power generation apparatus according to claim 1, wherein the control computation unit includes hardware designed to necessarily cause hunting in the case of a rate of change in the output of the fuel cell that is equal to or greater than a predetermined rate, and software having a rate limit for preventing the occurrence of hunting during normal operation, and when measuring impedance of the fuel cell, the control computation unit removes the limit of the software, and Intentionally causing hunting of the fuel cell by fluctuating current at a rate equal to or greater than a predetermined rate of change, the impedance measuring unit measures impedance of the fuel cell, and when the control computation unit intends to end the impedance measurement, The fuel cell is protected by assigning a rate limit to the software without waiting for the impedance measurement unit to calculate the impedance.3The impedance measurement method according to (1).

The fuel cell monitoring method according to claim 1, wherein the method by which the hunting determination unit determines that the fuel cell is in a hunting state includes constantly monitoring a current and a voltage of the fuel cell by the hunting determination unit, when a current indication value changes by a predetermined change width ?I and the change in the current indication value is completed within a predetermined time ?t, When the fluctuation range of the current of the fuel cell by a prescribed rate or more changes in the change range ?I are a prescribed number of times or more within a prescribed time period, and when the current and the voltage of the fuel cell fluctuate in phase opposition, The fuel cell according to claim 1, wherein the hunting determination unit determines that hunting has occurred, and the impedance measurement unit calculates the impedance of the fuel cell.7The impedance measurement method according to (1).

A fuel cell, an accumulator, and an impedance measurement unit comprising: a hunting determination unit that monitors a power-related value of the fuel cell and determines whether or not an output of the fuel cell is in a hunting state based on a status of the power-related value; A method for measuring impedance of the storage battery in a fuel cell system that supplies power of the fuel cell to a load, the method comprising the steps of: When it is determined that the storage battery is in a hunting state, the impedance measuring unit acquires time series data of a current and a voltage of the storage battery during the hunting event, and The current time series data and the voltage time series data are each computationally processed using a FFT method, and the impedance of the storage battery is calculated from the two computationally processed data.

A fuel cell system that supplies power to a load and an output value of the load, the fuel cell system including a fuel cell and an accumulator, wherein An impedance measurement device that measures impedance of a fuel cell in a fuel cell system in which the fuel cell and the accumulator are controlled in accordance with designated power values calculated by a control computation unit, the device comprising: a data accumulation unit that accumulates time series data of current and voltage of the fuel cell and the accumulator; An impedance calculation unit that calculates impedance on the basis of current and voltage, wherein the impedance calculation unit acquires time series data of current and voltage before and after hunching of the fuel cell and the storage battery from the data accumulation unit when a large fluctuation of the load by more than or equal to a predetermined value occurs within a predetermined time period; The impedance of the fuel cell is measured, and the impedance of the storage battery is also measured.

Title: Battery impedance measuring device
Inventor: OKADA SHUHEI
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a battery impedance measuring device capable of measuring the internal impedance characteristics of a battery, which is used for a battery monitoring device, in real time and on site such as on an automobile, power plant, and home power storage system.
SOLUTION: An impedance measuring device is used for a battery monitoring device that measures and monitors in real time a battery module which includes a plurality of serially connected battery cells and drives an actual load with a load variation including a high frequency band generated. The device comprises: a DFT calculation part that calculates impedance by performing a discrete Fourier transform for voltage waveform data and current waveform data of each of the cells and dividing the discrete Fourier transform result of the voltage waveform data by the discrete Fourier transform result of the current waveform data; and a circuit constant estimation calculation part that performs a weighting calculation for each data on the basis of the impedance, which is calculated by the DFT calculation part, and analysis conditions such as a weighting function and frequency range.
COPYRIGHT: (C)2013,JPO&INPIT
Claims:
1. An impedance measurement device used in a battery monitoring device that measures and monitors, in real time, a battery module in which a plurality of battery cells are connected in series, the battery module being driven in a state where load fluctuations including a high frequency range occur, the impedance measurement device comprising: performing discrete Fourier transform on voltage waveform data and current waveform data of each of the cells; An DFT calculation unit that calculates an impedance by dividing a result of discrete Fourier transform of the voltage waveform data by a result of discrete Fourier transform of the current waveform data; and an DFT calculation unit that calculates an impedance on the basis of the impedance calculated by the DFT calculation unit and analysis conditions including a weighting function and a frequency range.A weighting calculation is performed on a difference between the measured impedance and an impedance at the same frequency obtained from a circuit constant; the weighting is reduced in a frequency region where an amplitude of a voltage waveform or a current waveform of each of the cells is small, and the weighting is increased in a frequency region where the amplitude of the voltage waveform or the current waveform of each of the cells is large.A circuit constant estimation calculation unit.
2. An impedance measurement device used in a battery monitoring device that measures and monitors in real time a battery module that includes a plurality of battery cells connected in series and that drives an actual load in a state where load fluctuations including a high frequency range occur, the impedance measurement device comprising: a spike data correction unit that performs spike correction on voltage waveform data and current waveform data of each of the cells; An DFT calculation unit configured to calculate impedance by performing discrete Fourier transform on the spik-corrected voltage waveform data and current waveform data of each of the cells, and dividing a result of discrete Fourier transform of the voltage waveform data by a result of discrete Fourier transform of the current waveform data; Based on the impedance computed by the DFT computation unit, the analysis conditions including a weighting function, and the frequency range.A weighting calculation is performed on a difference between the measured impedance and an impedance at the same frequency obtained from a circuit constant; the weighting is reduced in a frequency region where an amplitude of a voltage waveform or a current waveform of each of the cells is small, and the weighting is increased in a frequency region where the amplitude of the voltage waveform or the current waveform of each of the cells is large.A circuit constant estimation calculation unit.

Title: Device for calculating impedances of battery cell and battery impedance measuring system

Abstract: There is provided a device for calculating impedances of a battery cell for respective frequency domains. The device includes: a Fourier transformation calculator configured to perform Fourier transformation on voltage waveform data and current waveform data, which are output from the battery cell, and calculate an impedance of the battery cell by dividing a Fourier transformation data of the voltage waveform data by a Fourier transformation data of the current waveform data; a circuit constant estimator configured to estimate circuit constants of a predetermined equivalent circuit model of the battery cell, based on the impedance calculated by the Fourier transformation calculator; and an impedance estimator configured to estimate impedances of the battery cell for respective frequency domains, based on the estimated circuit constants and the equivalent circuit mode.

Title: Impedance measuring apparatus
Inventor:
IIJIMA JUNJI
KAMATA YASUYOSHI
Abstract:
PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide an impedance measuring apparatus capable of measuring an internal impedance of a battery in a short period of time.
SOLUTION: An impedance measuring apparatus 1 supplies a battery 30 of a measuring object with an alternating current IAC from an AC supply 2 and measures the internal impedance of the battery 30 based on the supplied alternating current IAC and an interpolar AC voltage VAC generated between both the electrodes of the battery 30. In the impedance measuring apparatus, the AC supply 2 and the battery 30 are configured to be connected via a first DC voltage supply 3, a negative electrode of which is connected to the output end of the AC supply 2 and a positive electrode of which is connected to a positive electrode of the battery 30. The battery 30 and a differential amplifier may be connected via a second DC voltage supply 4.
